This vital film has all of the street-smart urgency of Moore's best work and precious little of the smug self-indulgence that has so often led us fellow lefties to roll our eyes in embarrassment.

Taking three of your favorite drag queens and some alcoholic contraband to this movie equals a windfall of instant camp.
[A] subtle, dreamlike spooker that pits a Seattle journalist against a sinister videotape full of ominous, threatening images.
Can't get enough of libidinous young city dwellers? Try this obscenely bad dark comedy, so crass that it makes Edward Burns' Sidewalks of New York look like Oscar Wilde.

Star-studded but tonally askew.
Streep and Cooper provide the support structure for two fine performances by Cage, which is two more than most pictures can claim.
Red Dragon reaffirms the Silence thesis that depravity is most unnerving when it appears to occur on the street where you live.
A suspense thriller with a brain and a heart.

One of those rare moviegoing experiences that simply flattens you with greatness from the word go.
Some of the concepts and production values have merit, but the film is long and disjointed, shirking the gradual descent into the supernatural that marks King's best work.
A good excuse to rent Animal House or Rodney Dangerfield's Back to School one more time.
A better-than -expected police thriller.
A big, bloated disaster of a movie you could almost call the Heaven's Gate of its generation.
For a lesson in how not to make a comic-book movie, look no further than this dull, derivative, sophomorically somber translation of Marvel's cult-hero strip.
It's a promising debut made even better by an impressive bunch of actors.
Strident and inelegant in its 'message-movie' posturing.
Young star Kevin Bishop plays the confused Paul with enough soul to sustain a movie that sometimes comes on like an ersatz training manual for parents of gay kids.
A shrill, unfunny litany of single-folk stereotypes that insults men and women with equal abandon.

Does little more than play an innocuous game of fill-in- the-blanks with a tragic past.

[A] relentlessly derivative horror cheapie.
Enjoy it for what it is; you can hate yourself later.

Base, venal and odd in all the wrong ways.

A pulsating group portrait of a country balancing youthful passion with the pull of adult responsibility.

A wearisome stab at screwball comedy.
A glorified installment of Ally McBeal.

Take any 12-year-old boy to see this picture, and he'll be your slave for a year.
This is not a crew to say 'no' to.

Makes up in indignation, passion and poetry what it lacks in filmmaking gloss.

movie_review_blurb: The path Ice Age follows most closely, though, is the one established by Warner Bros. giant Chuck Jones, who died a matter of weeks before the movie's release.

This may not be the best four-color adventure ever lensed, but it's the most affectionate and faithful to its source.

[T]here's nothing new to the picture, no creative chance taken.

Too bad writer/ director Bob Dolman can't think of anything better to do with the premise than turning it into Grumpy Old Sluts.
An imperfectly plotted but terrifically eerie thriller that turns on Williams' haunting performance as a voyeuristic photo developer.

Enjoyable black-comic romp.

A flawed but well-intended throwback to the creaking-door school of thrillers.

Holm's strong performance never sinks to caricature.
A latter-day appropriation of the 1950s giant-insect archetype that's not funny enough to qualify as parody yet too crass to be considered homage.

Following Sprecher's morally compromised New Yorkers through a funhouse maze of narrative overlap is never less than a tantalizing pursuit.
An extraordinarily silly thriller.
Whether verbal or visual, most of the few decent gags the sequel contains were already told twice in the original.
Easily outperforms A.I. as the most enjoyable film Kubrick never made.
A taut, fully realized thriller that's destined for canonization by suspense buffs and Art-heads alike.
Weirdly compelling.
A sight better than the Dead Poets Society in Drag you may have expected.
Quote not available.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

Shows some self-vindicating spunk and intelligence before it succumbs to a shortfall of ideas.

Beauchamp reaches this point without exploitation or cheap foreshadowing; there are no dramatic music stings underlying the outwardly innocuous biography before it methodically descends into true American tragedy.

movie_review_blurb: The leaden pacing and the lack of compelling performances eventually make even the most hardened ren-fair geeks in the house tune out.

Pleasantly undistinguished, this movie rests on a handful of crowd-pleasing plot points about true love, and on a few strong supporting turns: Oliver Platt, who plays an obese Genoan fop, has now saved two movies in as many months.

A loathsome low-budget thriller that's only distinguished by its ability to juggle grotesque sadism and stultifying boredom.
This souvenir of the film-turned-stage-hit accomplishes the tough task of getting third-generation laughs.

... fun and informative ...

An intermittently fearsome but clumsy colossus that keeps tripping over its own feet.

... an unpleasant and unfunny comedy ...

movie_review_blurb: Dingy and dark, using the trappings of rot to mask its central goody-two-shoedness.
It's official: Michael Winterbottom makes the best cinematic whatchamacallits around.

Though too many headstones are left unturned -- the incorporation of ancient folklore into the grimy ghoul hunting balances the Matrix-esque choreography quite nicely.

movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This is a movie that thinks a hit in the gut is a perfectly suitable punch line; as such, watching it often feels like enduring repeated blows to your own solar plexus.
Somehow, the plot remains emotionally coherent -- involving, even -- amid a minimum of dialogue.

movie_title: I am Cuba, the Siberian Mammoth (Soy Cuba, O Mamute Siberiano) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, Freedomland merely pits Some of Us against Some of Them, and you don't have to be a detective to know that's a big cop-out.

More sympathetic and interesting than the stars of Gunner Palace, these fellas are both a microcosm of society and individuals in their own right.

[Reduces] to zero the chances that any impartial observer will be genuinely swayed by this cinematic position paper.

The awww factor of these sequences is huge -- and undeniable.
With Domino, Tony Scott continues in his quest to make films expressly for the hard of hearing, the visually impaired and people on amphetamines, who find that all other movies move too darn slow.

Beyond the novelty of the setting -- which isn't even that novel when you have something similar a few exits south -- there's just not enough going on.

An affectionate, even triumphant bio of Waters' immortal leading "lady."

So 30 of the 150 or so minutes are a bust. There's still ample reason to see the thing in first run, if only for the chance to be part of an audience that cheers en masse at the exorcism of its darkest, most up-to-date fears.

It's essential viewing to prove to yourself that you're not so cynical after all.

Put-upon Jews weep on cue or stare defiantly into the camera, spouting impromptu speeches about getting some of their own back one day; all the while, violins wail in the background.
There are several moments of high, unheralded humor -- although whenever you find yourself laughing, you have to ask yourself if you aren't merely grateful that anything is happening at all.

Transfixing and transcendent.
At last, a movie that's unafraid to offend Renaissance aficionados and Sammy Hagar!

Stirring performances and well-aimed filmcraft.
A deadpan satire that's as fun as it is smart.

One hundred and eleven minutes: That's all the time it takes for a movie to go from indefensible to indispensable.

movie_review_blurb: This is the Altman of Nashville, back to inhabiting the performer's world with thoroughness and infectious affection.

The studio's best-ever work with humanoid forms.

Most of the music is as fine and fierce as you could want.
Brody, who has the lean-and-hungry charisma of a skinny young De Niro, turns his potentially cliched, tortured artist character into somebody from whom you'd actually want to buy a drink.
Parents can relax: Ron Howard's version of Dr. Seuss' tale of the Christmas-napping Grinch is a smartly stylized hoot.

movie_review_blurb: Why in the wide, wide, world of sports would anybody make a big-budget feature film from a decades-old, animated cartoon parody of Nelson Eddy/Jeanette MacDonald movies?
Low-budget but visually stunning.
movie_title: Othello (The Tragedy of Othello: The Moor of Venice) (1955)

movie_review_blurb: A low-budget but stylish recreation of the brief life and times of a pioneering LA punk band, What We Do Is Secret is fast and funny enough to make you overlook the fact that you've seen variants of this story before.

Insufferable, endearing, pretentiously arty, bracingly direct, humorless, hilarious, oddly distant and strangely touching, but always compulsively watchable -- in other words, a fabulous contradictory mess, much like Smith herself.
The performances are uniformly excellent, first-time director Washington keeps things moving with admirable efficiency.
The real problem, of course, is that Fish isn't all that interesting a protagonist.
Reasonably affecting despite uneven performances and a certain overfondness for familiar stock characters.
Easier to admire than actually enjoy.
Gives the word "forgettable" a bad name.
Scattershot, often beautiful to look at and just as often earnest to the point of self-parody.
The problem with the film, mostly, is that it's overstuffed with historical incidents that don't really cohere into a convincing story beyond the usual rise-fall-rebirth stuff.
Director Stephen Kijak's profile of reclusive pop icon Scott Walker is one of the most remarkable music documentaries in ages.
Even casual filmgoers should be intrigued, while film buffs and cineastes will find the doc's inside-show biz stories a real treat.
movie_title: Milton Glaser: To Inform and Delight (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Film buffs and cineastes will find the doc's inside-show biz stories a real treat.
movie_title: The Boys: The Sherman Brothers' Story (2009)

movie_review_blurb: On one level, Nobody Knows About Persian Cats is just another story about a bunch of indie-rock wannabes, but writer/director Bahman Ghobadi's vaguely vérité look at the underground music scene in contemporary Iran has a certain built-in drama factor.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: On the one hand, the film is a cautionary too-much-too-soon story that was a cliché even before what Casey Kasem refers to as the Rock Era; on the other hand, it also has enough touching, amusing and/or appalling episodes to make it compulsively watchable
movie_title: Who is Harry Nilsson (And Why is Everybody Talkin' About Him)? (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Let's be blunt: Bass can't really act.
Chris Smith's low-key coming-of-age film/slice of contemporary Indian life takes forever to get where it's going, which turns out to be pretty much nowhere.
Nothing about this movie is terribly fresh.
If this deeply lame Cinderella story, apparently the result of an unholy tryst between Pretty Woman and Working Girl, had an original idea in its head, that idea would swiftly die of loneliness.
It's hard to overstate just how awful this movie is, despite the efforts of the appealing cast.
A charming, low-key ensemble comedy that recalls the films of both John Cassavetes and Woody Allen.
A hip-hop Cheech and Chong picture crossed with Animal House that's about as cheerfully vulgar as you might expect.
Let's face it: 'To thine own self be true' is not exactly late breaking news.
If this is the Danish idea of a good time, prospective tourists might want to consider a different destination -- some jolly country embroiled in a bloody civil war, perhaps.
Quirky, original, and often very funny.
Needless to say, the dramatics that follow are utter hooey.
A surprisingly funny and much-smarter -than-it- needs-to-be, Animal House-style ensemble comedy.
The cast is uniformly excellent ... but the film itself is merely mildly charming.

While not for every taste, this often very funny collegiate gross-out comedy goes a long way toward restoring the luster of the National Lampoon film franchise, too long reduced to direct-to-video irrelevancy.
A reasonably entertaining sequel to 1994's surprise family hit that may strain adult credibility.
An uneasy mix of four-hankie tearjerker and surreal romantic comedy.
Think The Lion King redone for horses, with fewer deliberate laughs, more inadvertent ones and stunningly trite songs by Bryan Adams, the world's most generic rock star.
An amiable if inconsistent send-up of and tribute to blaxploitation flicks of the early 1970s.
On its own staggeringly unoriginal terms, this gender-bending comedy is generally quite funny.
A harmless, if ultimately inane, fantasy-comedy vehicle for youngsta-rapper Lil' Bow Wow.
An unintentionally surreal kid's picture ... in which actors in bad bear suits enact a sort of inter-species parody of a VH1 Behind the Music episode.
Isn't terribly original, but it does have the refreshing virtue of showing people smacked around by tsunami-sized waves that, for a change, are mostly not computer generated.
The film's center will not hold.
A psychological thriller that doesn't really hold up if you think about it too much, but is nonetheless highly entertaining in a low-budget, David Lynch-ian way.
Silberling's script is a feast of cornucopian proportions for the talented cast, and the acting is, without exception, world class.
Almost everything about the film is unsettling, from the preposterous hairpiece worn by Lai's villainous father to the endless action sequences.
Even generally sympathetic adults may eventually find their minds wandering, if only because of the characters' continual, annoying hopping; being vegetables, they have no legs, you see.
Really dumb but occasionally really funny.
Often painfully unfunny fish-out-of-water saga.
Something of a cop-out, lacking the courage of its convictions.
Beethoven's painful insecurities and petty squabbles are deftly balanced with generous musical examples.
Anvil! The Story of Anvil, a documentary destined to spark many a Tap reference, proves that in the world of heavy metal, the line between fiction and reality is even thinner.
Aaron Aites and Audrey Ewell's plainspoken music doc relies on firsthand testimony from band members and key observers.

Jon Else's taut chronicle, fashioned from vivid scenes of creativity and conflict, mostly coheres despite a few wayward strands. But disappointingly, Adams's purely musical choices are largely left unexamined.
movie_title: Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A transformative journey...
Morrison and Frisell infuse the film with warmth and, where appropriate, a touch of wit, causing its subject to breathe anew.
Although there is genuine horror in the way that many of these luminaries were cast into shadow, prematurely and brutally, there remains a certain triumph to be had in Pirozzi's film.
movie_title: Don't Think I've Forgotten: Cambodia's Lost Rock And Roll (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
movie_title: Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sure, the plot is paper thin like most reboots, but CHiPs is less about the story and more about the special effects and stunt riding, which are jaw-dropping.
Ultimately, though, this is a story about Xavier and Magneto, and McAvoy and Fassbender do not disappoint.
Had Super Troopers spent more time on the drawing board, or had it been pared down to a half-hour short film, it might have been a scream.

The mere fact that a 90-minute documentary about a corn farmer and his crops can manage to be both occasionally entertaining and thoroughly artistic makes Hybrid worth harvesting, if you're in the right farm -- err, frame -- of mind.
A superbly acted and funny/gritty fable of the humanizing of one woman at the hands of the unseen forces of fate.
In the end the film leaves audiences feeling almost as exploited as Elena herself.

Less a traditional movie than a lyrical photo essay of fictional characters in a world so real it's almost surreal, George Washington deserves to be seen simply because it's not quite like anything that's come before.
Jurassic Park III tries to be nothing more than a mindless munch-crunch-thanks-a-bunch thrill ride. And expectations or not, it does a roaringly good job.
Gets bogged down by an overly sillified plot and stop-and-start pacing.
While this completely computer-generated sci-fi tale breaks new ground visually, beneath its sleek digital surface lurks a dull and nonsensical mishmash of cliches, confusion and sterile characters.
Basically it's just an excuse to set up an uneven stream of sex jokes and toilet humour and movie spoofs.
One of the best documentaries of the last year, both in its ability to entertain and its importance as a snapshot of a crucial moment in the life of the new economy.
Nothing much else in Tomb Raider lives up to Jolie's sexy posturing and confident butt-kicking.
A strangely refreshing punch in the gut that puts the horror back in 'horror movie.'
The less you know about a Takashi Miike film before you see it, the better the experience will be.
Great performances, stylish cinematography and a gritty feel help make Gangster No. 1 a worthwhile moviegoing experience.
I'm all over the action in the movie, and the last half hour alone is literally worth the price of admission.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: This French-language film is fiercely intellectual and thoughtful.
movie_title: Code Unknown (Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: It deserves to be seen by anyone with even a passing interest in the events shaping the world beyond their own horizons.

Undisputed is the kind of flick that could put hair on your chest and a swagger in your stride, assuming you don't actually drown in the testosterone that pours off the screen like the sweat flying from Ving Rhames's bald head.

As bloody or breathtaking or heroic as these gussied-up Hollywood depictions of armed human conflict might try to be, none of them capture the true hellacious chaos of war like Israeli director Amos Gitai's Kippur.

The four male leads are so engaging, and their exploits laced with such slices of real life, that anyone who has been there, done that won't be able to help but have twinges of real feeling for the fresh-faced lads.

An easy, breezy and pleasantly uncheesy spin through the universe of Marvel Comics' beloved wall-crawling web-head.
It truly feels as though you're plunked down in the best seats the Mirage has to offer.

Far more entertaining and engaging that anything this silly has a right to be.
The return of Spidey marks what could end up being the best action film of the summer, and quite possibly the best superhero movie ever made.
There's a certain warmth and dumb, watchable charm about the whole thing, even when it's not being that funny.
There are so many genuine shocks, surprises and moments of gut-wrenching tension in this thriller of a film, its few flaws deserved to be overlooked.
The whole flick has an unsophisticated look to it, like it was hastily filmed.

A beautifully filmed, thought-provoking, disturbing and occasionally erotic dissection of jealousy and infidelity.

A fascinating and often funny look at a world many of us have never imagined, let alone seen.
This comedy with the deceptively glib premise is actually surprisingly funny, thanks to a chuckle-worthy performance by Robert De Niro.
Mission: Impossible looks poised to take over as the spy series moviegoers can get excited about.
A movie for people who find pop-up books too intellectually demanding and college keg parties too socially refined. It's that dumb. Maybe even dumber.
Viewers who loved GoldenEye and Tomorrow Never Dies will love this one as well.
It's the classic error of style over substance.
Ultimately flat farce.
A fun, brainless thrill ride.

Many of the fight scenes are boring to a fault.
The whole flick has an unsophisticated look to it, like it was hastily filmed.
Even with your +2 Ring of Histrionic Resistance, you're hosed. For the rest of the movie, you will suffer the effects of some of the worst acting in recent memory.
Simply blow away every martial arts flick ever made.
Offers an imaginative -- and darkly funny -- bit of revisionist history that's sure to please horror fans and film buffs alike.
Has a weird kind of loud, dumb but innocent charm.
Not even the cables on the Golden Gate Bridge would be able to suspend enough disbelief to make Along Came a Spider a truly worthwhile experience.
Nicely balances high-energy pop music, teen comedy and plenty of not-so-subtle digs at the business of star-making.
An eye-opening feat of technical prowess and storytelling.
The ensemble cast turns in a collectively stellar performance, and the writing is tight and truthful, full of funny situations and honest observations.
Action movies are supposed to be dumb, but they're not supposed to be stupid.
It's only intermittently funny.
Younger kids will probably love George's slapstick antics, but adults hoping for wink-wink jokes working on another level may well be bored into oblivion.
Could be called Batman is Back, And it's About Time, Too.

Although it does stagger and groan and stumble around, you wouldn't necessarily say it's alive.
Sandler is solid, and a supporting cast that includes Steve Buscemi, Melonie Diaz and Method Man are all very watchable. But the movie is never able to find its footing.
The script is as leaden as the actors are fleet-footed.
It's like a chocolate wrapped in poop and then dipped in more chocolate. There's no way to enjoy it without tasting some crap.
It's thoughtful and timely, offering an unsettling look at the two faces of modern warfare.
The performances are universally great, and the subject matter is captivating.
An entire movie about them feels like eating a bowl of pure sugar. Which means very young kids will love it, while adults might feel a bit nauseous by the end.
Ant-Man is an entertaining blend of a superhero origin story and a caper film, the funniest and most grounded Marvel movie to date.
While certainly not a disappointment, Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation sticks too closely to the franchise formula. And unlike its buff star, the whole thing is starting to show its age.
While nothing about Sinister 2 is especially memorable, it's reasonably entertaining with sufficiently lowered expectations.
Wild Card doesn't really do [Statham] any favours, despite its rock-solid supporting cast and storied pedigree.

It's all completely over-the-top and loaded with cheese, and the mix of comedy, arch melodrama, sweeping CGI vistas and plentiful if improbable action doesn't quite gel.
Fortunately, The Visit has a lot of (intentional!) laughs between the creepy bits and jump scares, and never takes itself too seriously.

I Smile Back isn't a candy-coated, noble depiction of addiction and the toll it takes on families, but rather a bleak yet honest look at how regular people lose themselves, and how difficult it can be to find the way back.

What it does do - is allow you to park your brain in neutral for 100 minutes, laugh at some silly jokes... and then walk out of theatre and immediately forget it ever happened. And there's nothing wrong with that. In fact, it's kind of refreshing.
To be fair, this homage to The Little Prince is a lovely story, lovingly told. And for the first two-thirds of the movie, it feels like one of the freshest animated films in ages.

The story strives for a complexity that gets undermined again and again by cliche-riddled dialogue, pacing problems and performances that sometimes feel like they came out of a high school adaptation of The Lord of the Rings.
Animation can be a safe place to explore some trickier topics, and Kubo and the Two Strings has a dash of bitter mixed with the sweet.

Despite the occasional pothole, Cop Car is an arresting ride.
The Expendables 3 is like a joke that's been told too many times to still be funny.
If you're yearning for a smart, thoughtful sci-fi film that wonders how first contact with aliens might go down, this tight little gem of a film is a gift from beyond the stars.
It's got bad acting, atrocious dialogue and plot holes you could fly a Harrier jet through -- but the result is more exasperating than comical.
[A] sometimes engaging but often meandering mishmash of a movie.
If you can sit through Saw II without gagging, gasping or covering your eyes, you are made of stern stuff indeed. And you should seek psychiatric help, since you might be a closet sociopath.
Allen's capable direction makes the most of the film's tiny $1-million budget, and Dupuis' performance is a revelation.

Better than you might expect. But given the ultimate source material (Frank Miller's moody and moving Daredevil comics from the mid-'80s), it's a squandering of character and story that would make Comic Book Guy weep.
Sadly, it's not human and gritty enough that we'll take anything away from it after the neatly tied-up climax and epilogue play themselves out and the credits roll.
A throwback to the classic heist flicks of the '70s but with a 21st-century sensibility, Inside Man is the kind of twisty, cerebral thriller that they don't make any more.
I never thought I'd say these words, but here they are: I wish there was more Michael Bay in this movie.
American Dreamz puts reality TV and U.S. politics in its crosshairs, then fails to pull the trigger. It's less entertaining than an average episode of American Idol. And that's saying something.
Silent Hill starts out promisingly -- atmospheric and creepy -- but degenerates into a muddle of nonsensical plotting, dull characters and unintentional hilarity.

Shifting the action to Japan makes this third movie in the over-the-top street racing series a lot fresher, but you'll still need to shift your brain into neutral to keep your suspension of disbelief from bottoming out.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's weirdly fitting that a movie about going down into the inky depths to face monsters both physical and psychological has actually raised the horror genre to a bright new height.
What starts out as a strained, silly and strictly-for-the-chitlins collection of talking animal shenanigans redeems itself through sheer force of personality.
When the lights come up after a mercifully short 88 minutes, you'll want to bolt for the exit. Faster than a speeding bullet.
It might not be a classic for the eons, but Ice Age: The Meltdown is so delightfully fun, funny and action-packed that it's hard to find cracks in its slick surface.
Saw III is gross and squirmy, but it's got a lot of brains and heart to go along with its guts. Better than Saw and Saw II combined.
Saw III isn't just by far the best film of the series, it's one of the better horror movies of the year.
Need for Speed is not Fast & Furious. For better or for worse. Mostly for worse.
What we have here is a competent if not exactly memorable sci-fi action movie. A movie that is RoboCop in name only.
Fans know exactly what they're in for when going to a Paranormal Activity movie, and in that respect The Marked Ones delivers.
It's too self-aware, and doesn't back up this winky-winky-hey-look-we're-back-again with enough genuine laughs.

The Lego Movie is the kind of fine-tuned family-friendly flick that serves two audiences simultaneously, with a non-stop firehose of eye candy for the kids and lots of sharp wit and subtle parody for the grownups.
It's been a while since we've seen anyone attempt to riff on/rip off Quentin Tarantino, which is why Seven Psychopaths feels fresher than it might have, say, a decade ago or two.
It feels like a throwback to a time when action movies were simply movies with action in them, and didn't have to rely on relentless CGI setpieces to hold viewers' attention.
All traces of fun are sucked into a black hole of dense, inescapable comedic mediocrity.
A Fan's Hope is (appropriately) hopeful, likening the attendees whose stories it follows to comic book heroes seeking their own type of redemption.
movie_title: Comic-Con: Episode IV - A Fan's Hope (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Chances are you will love The Fountain. Or, you will absolutely hate it.
Despite a fertile premise about the 1% of the 1% living on a pristine space station orbiting above earth's teeming and impoverished masses, this movie has far more brawn than smarts.
As entertainment for kids, or for adults, it misjudges its audience by at least a millennium.
movie_title: The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: If I really want to watch Attack of the Giant Leeches, then why wouldn't I just watch the original?
An intelligent and improbably touching film that is atmospheric as hell and never once feels fake or forced.
Too often I felt like I was watching a feature-length R-rated "America's Most Wanted" re-enactment segment
Overall B.T.K. is a decent watch if you enjoy delving into the depths with real serial killers.

As the credits began to roll, I thought to myself, "I can't believe this was a theatrical release." Neither will you if you pay to see it.
Grace is very much the antidote to what plagues most of the horror genre today. It will restore your faith that there is still an artistic vision within the horror genre.

[Blu Ray] Only the hi-def obsessed should double-dip for this one, DVD owners can still sit pretty.

Every element comes together to create a piece of gonzo genius we won't soon forget... I dare you not to love every minute of it.
Plays a bit like a children's movie...for adults. What you get is a good time on a Saturday afternoon with a full bucket of popcorn and a crowd that can shut the hell up.
Martyrs is an absolute recommend, but only to those who are willing to accept the film on its own uncompromising terms. All others are advised to stay well clear away.
If you're looking for a good time killer, look elsewhere. The Poker Club fails miserably at everything it attempts to do. Sigh.
While it may seem like making a horror comedy about an alien penis that takes itself kind of seriously is the epitome of an oxymoronic idea, it plays really well.
High on ambition and originality and the closest we've come to a true H.P. Lovecraft film.
This film was MADE to be seen in a dripping, shitty Grindhouse held together with paint and cockroach droppings.
When Wolvesbayne was over I kind of had the feeling I'd just spent 90-minutes watching the superhero origin movie for a minor supporting sidekick.
Not a single one of these vignettes are given sufficient enough time to develop and thus every minute of The Telling ends up feeling pointless.
I think it is high time to create a brand new edition to the Dread Central ratings system to be used only on the most special occasions like right now.
The She-Beast is a must own for fans of Sixties schlock. In the end it was even more fun than I had remembered. Not good, mind you. Hell, not even mediocre. Just fun.

movie_review_blurb: Even after over thirty years The Centerfold Girls holds its own. It's a classic whose intentions are still very clear and -- for what it is -- very effective.

I'll probably take heat for saying so, but this flick kind of sucks.

Its knack for combining scary, funny, angsty, bleak, and philosophical ideas into one very compelling package.

Supernatural: The Complete Third Season still packs a powerful punch and is without a doubt the best of the bunch.

An in name only third installment that is void of any character, depth, integrity, scares, or feeling.

I can't even bring myself to say, drop in, turn your brain off and enjoy, as the material presented is just not anywhere near as entertaining as the first run.

Hannibal Rising is a slick and horrifying ride you are forced to experience at the edge of a knife. Washed out scenes ease your senses in counterpoint to high contrast visuals depicting the worst things human beings are capable of.

...a dark, moody fairytale set in modern day, perfect for a date with that special someone who doesn't want to be subjected to the usual gore overkill we've been treated to in the past couple of years
Swing on the spirals, down into the darkness. The Descent will leave you exhausted and screaming for more.
Easter Bunny, Kill! Kill! revels in its obscenity and packs enough punch to knock out even the most jaded of viewers. You've been warned.
Somewhere in here there is a great flick hiding. However as is, it's dreadfully too long.
File this one under fun while it lasts, but easily forgettable.
The end product packs enough punch to please both children and Miike fans alike. That in itself is a great achievment.
The only problem is that there's just not that much of a reason to sit up and check out what all of the noise is about.
Is A Sound of Thunder a great movie? Not even close.
As incoherent as it is enjoyable, The Jacket hits the marks that it set out to, yet leaves the audience a bit cold with its squeaky clean ending.
Solid acting, at times brilliant camera work, and superb sound design all contribute to make this a truly frightening winner.
Bhoot could have easily taken its place among some of the better horror films out there.
... a well crafted, solid little film that will thrill you, chill you, and at times make your skin crawl.
...despite its shortcomings, The Cave does deliver on some of its promises.
This film chills and hits every paranoia button perfectly.
This isn't even mediocre. These Voices need to shut up. Do not bother. You've been warned.

I wanted this to be great. Hell, I would have settled for just above average. This just sucks. All of the key elements are in place -- a solid story, great gore F/X, good sound work ... everything except Dario.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Devil's Chair delivers everything that a movie should while shattering just about every film convention possible.
I'm just going to summarize C Me Dance with two simple words: HOLY CRAP!
What I like here is that Hall was able to create a slasher film with characters we care about but definitely does not take anything too seriously either.
A true love letter to genre days gone by, Alien Trespass delivers on its promise to bring back a slice of the good old days to horror cinema.
Riddled with nail-biting tension and scenes that are quite simply scary as hell, Pontypool as of now is on my best of list for 2009.

The movie dissolves into Cage running around trying to warn people about the numbers, but he doesn't know exactly what is going to happen or where it's coming from, so we get the crazy doomsayer routine by day and boozing while lamenting by night.
Lohman takes a Bruce Campbell-style beating through Raimi's wonderful world of swoop-cams, attacking furniture and pus-spewing creatures...Take a deep sigh of relief, horror fans. Sam's back!
A stylish but pointless exercise that wastes all the great talent involved.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Just like the classic From Dusk Till Dawn, if not for the ridiculous title, you wouldn't have any idea this was a genre film for the first third of the movie. The acting is top notch and notable. This is a TV geek's dream what with favorites from three st
True to form, the folks at Platinum Dunes have once again worked their signature brand of ultra-stylish, faux-gritty mediocrity, thus stripping Friday the 13th of its low-budget charm.
Coraline is a spectacle you'll enjoy from start to finish.
The Uninvited packs in some impressive imagery that will keep you engaged, even while the dialogue suggests you'd be better off sleeping.
It's clear a great deal of effort was put into creating a completely immersive world...a fantastic, bloody good time!
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's effective as hell and is a prime example of how to win an audience over and keep their attention in a highly constrained, claustrophobic atmosphere in the most unpretentious way possible.
This is an R-rated horror film through and through. My Bloody Valentine is bursting with gory kills and loads of nudity, all delivered in three glorious dimensions.
I'm not sure if it's the fault of the script or studio tampering, but The Unborn's watered-down approach to WWII makes Isla: She Wolf of the SS seem downright sensitive in comparison
This one should have been released around Thanksgiving instead of Christmas because it is indeed a turkey!
Fox has sucked all the color out of The Day The Earth Stood Still...
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Looking to experience poo at its stinkiest? Look no further than Moscow Zero
Gone is the really black humor of the first film. Gone is the insane twist. Gone are the inventive kills. And gone is nearly all of the charm that has kept this franchise alive.
Gordon hits the proverbial ball not only directly out of the park, but also through the windshield of a ... well, maybe I should just start from the beginning.
Hell Ride is a smoldering yet completely dull wreck of a movie.
This is unmistakably one of the worst horror films of the year. It's the last dying gasp of a series that was already past its expiration date.
Trick 'r Treat ranks alongside John Carpenter's Halloween as traditional October viewing and I can't imagine a single horror fan that won't fall head over heels in love with it.
There's nothing bright and sunny about Dead Space: Downfall. It's brutal, unrelenting, and savage. Bodies are torn, eviscerated, and mutilated ... This is no kids' show.
Manages to kick a copious amount of ass by breathing some much needed fresh air into the flattened lungs of our genre.
It's cheap fun, better than expected, but come the next day you'll hardly remember its name...
45 minutes of two girls becoming friends, talking about their troubled pasts, and going to clubs. And did I mention how incredibly, excruciatingly, fantastically boring it all is?
The Mist divides those who want cheap escapist thrills from those who like their horror with real heart, brains, and courage.
This is a blacker than black comedy, with some truly side-splitting moments (in a weird way)
movie_title: How to Be a Serial Killer (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For those who watch Romero's zombie movies for the thrill of the kill, there are plenty of scenes to entertain. [It} is (arguably) one of the best in the series
The Haunting in Connecticut 2: Ghosts of Georgia is a good time killer and perfect for a rainy day inside
movie_title: The Haunting in Connecticut 2: Ghosts of Georgia (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Prison is a gritty and gorgeous horror flick that's not only well acted and engaging but also delivers some shockingly fun and grisly deaths.
It's non-stop bloody fun from start to finish and one that you certainly should invite some friends over to dig on with you... again and again.
Grave Encounters 2 delivers a sick, intense, and scary white-knuckled spookshow that reveres the groundwork set up by the original and expands upon it on every level.
The Victim is a film that will most likely be ignored by those who can't handle the explicit yet chilling prologue, but those who can survive it are in for an unexpectedly amusing sleazefest.
It hits way more than it misses, and there are some truly shining moments strewn throughout the flick to keep even the hungriest of gorehounds satisfied.
If you're looking for a spooky way to kick off the summer movie season, Chernobyl Diaries more than fits the bill.
No, this was not your daddy's Gremlins movie. This was an entirely different kind of beast that was just made up of the same DNA.
The flick rises above the usual pack of copycats to deliver a world mostly of its own
Pandorum isn't all that bad. It's a perfectly middle-of-the-road genre flick not quite worthwhile enough to wholeheartedly recommend. And the creatures know kung-fu.
The flick is delightful, spooky, and sleazy fun and should NOT be missed by anyone. Do not hesitate a second.
Leberecht and company have delivered to us a smart, intense, and unpredictable film that is tons of ghoulish fun from beginning to end.
The Devil Inside is home to moments that will shock, scare, disturb, and leave you gasping. It's a trip to the dark side that's well worth taking.
Quick, fun, and blissfully brutal, it stands head and shoulders above the usual direct-to-video sequels that are shoved down our throats at a steady pace.
Blue Underground's release of Zombie is nothing short of a gift for fans. A time-capsule-worthy look at one of horror cinema's most infamous and fun movies.
Paranormal Activity 3 defies all odds and delivers yet another hellish reason to be afraid of the dark.
In the end we crawled deep into this Spiderhole and all we found was a truly beaten dead horse.
The Ward, while not stellar by any means, is absolutely worth your time.
Bikini Girls on Ice has effectively dethroned Suicide Girls Must Die as the worst slasher flick of the last ten years.

ChromeSkull: Laid to Rest 2 is an uncompromising, unflinching, and thoroughly insane little film which will have you gasping and cheering every kill until the very last frame. It's exactly what we watch slasher flicks for.
A circus of ridiculousness! Yes, it's bad. Yes it's juvenile. Yes, it's mindless, but I'd watch it again in a heartbeat.
Mimic: The Director's Cut on Blu-ray is a true gift for fans.
Elevator is a taut, intense, and surprisingly violent little movie that is home to some great performances, awesome sound design, and some truly slick thrills.
The Caller delivers tons of thrills, chills, twists, and turns. It may not be perfect, but it's damned effective.
Watching InSight is like realizing that menacing shadow on your wall is being cast by nothing more than an ill placed stuffed animal. It has no real claws, no real fangs, and ultimately no real bite.
In the end we have a movie with an excellent premise that's executed in the most standard of ways.
The flick delivers an epic-sized bloodbath that's top to bottom fun, laughs, action, and gore. It serves as a bloody exclamation point to one of modern horror's best trilogies.
Sadako 3D is like having beer goggles that possess the miraculous power to make even the silliest of CG deers look absolutely terrifying.
The Conjuring is a masterclass in absolute terror that's destined to become a classic within the genre.
At the end of the dayHellraiser: Judgment, while not perfect nor as good as the classic Hellraiser films, delivers a rather striking vision that feels as new as it does familiar.
The film - though rife with Creeper action - is fairly light on any actual scares, [but] at the end of the day if you're a fan of the franchise, you'll be happy with this latest entry...
The flick is a speeding freight train of terror that flies gloriously off the rails and leaves you desperately wanting more. Welcome back, Mr. Crowley.

Despite the titular killer, this is very much [Deanna Russo's] movie... The Ice Cream Truck delivers more than just two scoops of lunacy covered in psychotic nuts and sprinkles. Chill out, and eat it up!

The Dark Tapes ends up doing more right than it does wrong ... you'll find some really cool creatures and a few truly frightening and original moments that will send more than just a chill down the old spine.
Life is one the most realistic - and terrifying - monster movies to come along in decades.
Get Out will have you laughing one moment, gasping the next, and cheering the whole way through.
The scares come fast and furious, and they do not relent until the very last frame, leaving the audience thoroughly shaken.
Lights Out is an experience that reminds you why you love horror movies.
The Phoenix Incident is a thought-provoking and frightening account of an already scary event.
Here it is. The one you've been asking for. Unfortunately that doesn't mean what you're getting will be good or even what you wanted.
This is nothing more than a failed experimental attempt at making an exploitation film.
Super 8 is the perfect summer movie riddled with the kind of action, heart, and fun that most filmmakers would kill to be able to conjure.
Overall Rebound is wonderfully written and beautifully shot.
We Are Still Here is the first incredibly scary and pure horror film of 2015.
Living up to its moniker, this is one hell of a wrong turn for the franchise
Tis the season, kids, and this is a great Halloween-time tale of absolute terror. Revel in it!
If you're looking for a spooky little film that's free of pretension and sometimes logic and are into getting some quick shivers, you really cannot go wrong with The Taking of Deborah Logan
At the end of the day Annabelle is not a bad movie... it's just not a very good one.
If making zero sense and having absolutely no real resolution at the end was the point of As Above/So Below, then it did its job tenfold.
There's a special kind of effort that must go into turning out a flick this impossibly bad.
The Purge: Anarchy stands firm on its own two feet and has more in common with classics like The Warriors and Escape From New York
Director Mike Mendez brings his homage to those wacky creepy-crawly flicks of yesteryear to life with enough energy for several films.

It's nothing short of an absolute gift to the passionate fans of this storied franchise. The Marked Ones proves without a shadow of a doubt that Paranormal Activity is back in top form... with a wicked and evil vengeance.
Skip this one until you happen to catch it for free on cable.

Pacific Rim is an awesome good time that will leave you cheering. It's one of the few perfect summer films in existence. See it on the big screen. Yes, even pay the extra for 3D. Bask in its fun and glory.
2015 belongs to Max!
It truly plays like one person's nightmarish descent into a world of total madness. It gives you a feel for who Martin Bristol is and why he's so lethal. On that level the film is a complete success.
The Dead reveres the films that came before it and wears its love for them on its sleeve.
This is a rare sequel that complements and enhances the original without betraying the elements that made it work in the first place.
Night of the Dribbler can go back in the vault in Montreal from which they found it. Disaster Movie and Meet the Spartans look like a Peter Sellers comedy by comparison.
An earnest attempt to make an old school haunted house movie, just not a scary or even intriguing one to anyone whose age has reached double digits.
It's clear that Nishimura wants to push the envelope and shock audiences.
iMurders is fairly typical, predictable, and often times scattered.
[REC] 2 returns to something that is both charming and bloody, heartwarmingly cinematic and really, really scary and gross.
Daybreakers offers a flawed but thoroughly enjoyable, happy-making trip.
Truly enjoyable, truly independent, truly scary.
This new cleaner-looking version of The New Blood is miles ahead of what fans had access to previously on DVD
movie_title: Friday the 13th Part VII - The New Blood (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Taking the serial killer and putting him on a boat isn't the silliest thing you could do -- you could always send him to space.
movie_title: Friday the 13th Part VIII - Jason Takes Manhattan (1989)

movie_review_blurb: While Devil Girl won't be setting the mainstream on fire, those who share my curiosity for experimental type films should find it to be well above average.
After watching this film, the only emotion I'm left with is confusion.
movie_title: The Haunted World of El Superbeasto (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Seamstress is more yawn than yarn.
As a game Open Graves is passable enough for one roll of the dice but definitely not a game with any replay value.
This is disturbing, merciless horror ... the way it should be. See it now.
Is it worth a watch? The fantastic villain makes this worth a rental, or a view on cable.
Doghouse is a very entertaining time-waster and definitely one for the boys %u2013 break out the beers and just have some fun.
With Vanishing on 7th Street Anderson turns in his scariest experience since [his] initial outing as a filmmaker.
It delivers a film school semester's worth of knowledge in 1 tight & thoroughly entertaining feature and goes a long way toward validating horror as a respectable film genre.
movie_title: Nightmares in Red, White and Blue (2009)

movie_review_blurb: I cannot fathom anyone watching Mutants and finding anything about it worth recommending.
If horror fans are going to shell out their hard-earned money for a movie, there needs to be more than just a prettier picture on the DVD case.
The one saving grace for this low-budget film falls within the capable hands of the actors. Staunton Hill has some really impressive talent.
Offspring is as lame as they come.
The Thaw appears to borrow a tremendous amount of its plot from The X-Files. There was a good movie here that lost its way.
Seventh Moon is a badass and at times downright chilling little movie
While it's obviously aimed at the "tween" crowd, we fail to see where this movie would appeal to even young viewers.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Gate is a MUST HAVE movie for all horror fans and this special edition is absolutely worth the meager sixteen bucks!
The Stepfather is the full package: fast-paced, well-acted, suspenseful and brimming with bursts of nasty violence.
Rent Obsessed instead. That one you can at least laugh at.
It's a well crafted docu-drama-esque film that takes itself seriously, builds tension and scares the sh*t out of you through and through.
If you're looking for a senseless good time that goes a long way in terms of keeping you entertained, then this Piranha package may just be everything you've been hoping to sink your teeth into.
You really need to go back and see how it was done back in the day ... with reckless abandon and lots of splattery fun in mind
One thing's for certain ... it's a great time to be a Roger Corman fan.
movie_title: Galaxy of Terror (Mindwarp: An Infinity of Terror) (Planet of Horrors) (Quest) (1981)

movie_review_blurb: In a cinema landscape populated with all kinds of digitally created creatures and setpieces, it's nice to take a look back and witness the birth of these ideas.
As a promotional tool this is without a doubt a five-star affair, but beyond that? Not so much.
Roger Corman is the master of doing a lot with a little, and Death Race 2000 is but one shining example of the filmmaker's know-how.
Uncle Sam may never be widely considered as a classic horror flick, but it's leaps and bounds better than the usual crap that's shoved down our throats.
It's great to have Horror Hospital back in form. The flick plays like a time capsule of a time when love was free, gore flowed like a river, and filmmakers weren't afraid to go too far.
I got the impression Cornered! wanted to be a melding of Clerks and Scream, but all I wanted to do was scream "Get on with it!" and clock out early.
City of the Living Dead is a film that deserves its place within your horror library. Bless your black horror loving hearts, Blue Underground! Now bring on The Beyond and Zombie please!
movie_title: Paura nella città dei morti viventi (City Of The Living Dead) (The Gates of Hell) (1980)

movie_review_blurb: The Crazies knows what scares you, and once it pins you to your seat, it won't let go until the film's stark finale.
Shutter Island sets a tone straight out of the gate with dark, shadowy imagery, a muted color palette, and a splash of noir-esque style peppered across the top.

Mother's Day easily takes its place amongst the few successful remakes out there that manage to entertain while treating the audience with respect. Intense and at times shockingly violent, Mama's boys have once again made their mother very proud.
Kingdom of the Spiders plays just as good and just as fun as it always has. This, as far as we're concerned, is the very first MUST HAVE horror DVD package of 2010.
Phantasm II has a nice sense of fun to it which makes it the perfect viewing material for this time of year.
It's one of those movies whose fans will claim the naysayers just don't "get" when, in truth, it's not particularly hard to understand. It just isn't very good.
Its target audience is without question people who are just looking for a mindless good time and horny teenagers who find fart jokes to be the epitome of humor.
Night of the Creeps is a classic in every sense of the word.
At times it is a visually sumptuous, updated love letter to the classic film which inspired it; at others it seems a muddled mess.
You only need one finger to give Wrong Turn 3: Left for Dead a thumb's down.
What makes Skull Heads work is due to the performances, in particular that of Robin Sydney. She successfully carries the film on her shoulders - and boobs.
This may be one of the dumbest disaster films ever made, but they sure do blow up things real good.
A juvenile, overly dramatic love story that takes the Romeo and Juliet theme, duct tapes it around a giant, cartoonish hammer, and slams it into your head for 130 minutes.
The finished product is shockingly bad ... an exercise in futility. Spare yourself the agony.
[Writer/director Adam] Green has crafted a potent combination of absolute terror and compelling human drama that will stick with you long after you've left the theatre or turned off the DVD.
At best, this is an artsy indie film that would have played better on a smaller, more intimate scale with no name actors tearing their hearts out on the screen.
Saw VI is able to stand on its own as a wild and brutal thrill ride.
Quote not available.
42 Up engages you in ways that other movies can't; it works emotional muscles you may not know you have.
It's more disturbing now than ever.
movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Take a child to see this film and he or she will remember it forever.
movie_title: Beauty and The Beast (La Belle et la bête) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: Among the jewels that Arthur Freed's musicals unit turned out at MGM in the '40s and '50s, Singin' in the Rain is the Hope diamond.
Mirren is both audaciously funny and heartbreaking.
Chicago is a great movie musical.

Here [Spielberg] remains aware of his role as a popular interpreter, a dramatizer, and uses his resources as a filmmaker to convert a series of historic events into a gripping spy adventure, only to turn the genre on itself.
Bellocchio is driven by the idea that the reality of violence can sometimes remove even the most fervent partisan to a sphere beyond ideologies.
An alternately rollicking and mournful road comedy.

We are the checks and balances on government, and while a slightly more restrained, finessed film may have carried that message more effectively, Taking Liberties will inspire many viewers to reconsider their responsibilities and those of their government
A wonderfully poetic film offering a fresh perspective on America's early immigrants, Golden Door is as affecting as it is innovative
Goes beyond front-line journalism to show the men behind the guns.
A muzak rendition of Take That's 'Back For Good' plays over the montage that ends the film. It seems a fittingly empty conclusion to a story that never really engages with its audience.
A penchant for silliness and a tabloid-ready storyline mean The Serpent is a decent thriller that loses some of its impact as it unfolds, but remains a well-paced and enjoyable film.
A rich, inventive and atmospheric thriller that is somehow able to reveal the final twist while retaining its mysterious allure.
An interesting and unusual love story.
A rare innocence and a fresh approach to filmmaking make this a thoroughly charming and unconventional love story.
Simple message is powerful and compelling.
movie_title: A Crude Awakening: The Oil Crash (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A genuinely funny and absorbing documentary.
Tense until the murder, but Piddington assumes we all care as much about Chapman as he does.
With a strong performance from Isabelle Carré, Anna M. is an entertaining film, but it is also confused and slight, and like its anti-heroine, is in need of a firmer grip on reality.
Possibly the beginning of a new direction for the brothers, The Silence Of Lorna gathers force slowly and deliberately, yet lacks the intimacy of the directors' earlier films.
For anyone interested in the life and work of Lindsay Anderson, however, and indeed the British New Wave more generally, Never Apologize is an illuminating piece of film.
movie_title: Never Apologize: A Personal Visit With Lindsay Anderson (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An amiable but essentially empty film made enjoyable by a decent soundtrack, funny dialogue and Ben Kingsley's mad doctor.
It's all very sweet and there's no mistaking how the film's going to end. But it's also smart, funny and further proof of Michael Cera's comic talent.
Ingeniously uncomfortable but occasionally too opaque, Private Property is a darkly inventive family drama.
A strong drama clearly dedicated to exploring its real life events, if not hugely memorable in its own right.
Well acted and all the more engaging for having been based on a true story, ultimately Black Water lacks teeth.

A beautiful and ambitious film flawed by its dogged determination to cast Genghis Khan in a new light, the best that can be hoped is that Mongol provides a stage for better things in the forthcoming films.
This is essentially the same movie, mostly shorn of the former's shock value.
Doesn't quite reach the heights of the lofty ideals that it so ardently seeks to expound, but makes up for this with the sheer thrill of the journey Rian Johnson takes us on.
Unsatisfactory both as a low-budget schlocker and as a piece of entertainment.
Steps outside the boundaries of what seems like a rather conventional tale at the outset, and subsequently elevates itself into something else entirely.
Avoids becoming yet another Twilight clone. If a sequel happens, it will be interesting to see what direction it takes.
There's a halfway interesting movie in here somewhere. Beneath the rampant sexism and borderline schizophrenic mishmash of tones, that is.
The Age Of Adaline functions perfectly well as a harmless, fantasy-infused date movie. It's hard to really dislike.
Combined with the kind of breathtaking cinematography that gave the director his name, and a sense of diluted optimism running through it, and you have a film that sails through its lengthy run time.
The story just isn't as captivating as it needs to be.
movie_title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Even if it isn't the greatest Star Wars film ever, it's almost certainly the most affecting of them all.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Everything's stylishly shot by director Tom Paton, but the lack of anything beyond this gives us few reasons to actually care about what's going on.
Despite being 56 years old, and obviously of its time in a number of respects (the portrayal of the African tribesmen is vintage Hollywood), The Leech Woman is equally light years ahead in others.

Alan Moore probably wouldn't appreciate us saying it, but The Killing Joke story itself feels made for the screen. It's hard to truly critique something when it takes its cues from a truly excellent comic-book storyline.
It's tricky not to be ensnared by the beguiling yet intriguing nature of it all.
It falls firmly into the 'disposable fun' category, but ultimately it isn't much more than that.
Rogue One is still an achievement. Every other Star Wars movie has only ever had the responsibility of telling part of a story - this manages the whole thing in one go.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Essentially, think of this as Fritz Lang for beginners - which is in no way a bad thing.
Ride With the Devil works on the simple level of action and classic drama.
The opening credit sequence in Rush Hour outdoes anything that follows it.
Harold Ramis' Analyze This is the mob parody Billy Wilder or Preston Sturges might have made if they'd had access to Robert De Niro and the F-word.
The force is gone and George Lucas apparently has no idea where he left it!
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Jonathan Taylor Thomas is completely out of his element as the smooth-talking operator.
The entire cast is excellent, particularly Broadbent and Timothy Spall.
3 Strikes is depressing and grim, but not in any useful or interesting way.
Man on the Moon captures the mood of Kaufman's stand-up act while paying loving tribute to the late comic.
Much of A Map of the World is comparable to the work of Fritz Lang, Paul Schrader or any other filmmaker skilled at evoking panic and self-loathing.
Down to You has cute boys, cute girls and little else.
Entertaining and never sluggish.

The exposition that rushes us into the police standoff is so painfully forced and phony that the only way to keep watching the movie is to take it as either dark comedy or one of those cheap Die Hard knockoffs.
It's Kubrick telling a tediously elaborate joke at a party, using his eccentric genius and charisma to keep you captivated against all odds.
Most reminiscent of certain old Star Trek episodes, the especially horny ones in which Kirk spent most of his time in his quarters with some busty alien.
A pretty brave and ambitious feat.
Sunlight, light bulbs, lenses and shadows are more than suspense window-dressing in this one -- in many instances, they are the suspense.
At over two hours, it's too much junk food for one sitting.
The surprises are interesting, but not enough to save the film from itself.
Edward Norton and Brad Pitt in what may be the performances of their careers.
Lee has an incredible comic touch, and he pulls a solid performance from his entire cast.
The dialogue isn't aware it's cliched and hilarious; the soundtrack thinks it's backing an intense urban thriller.
The movie's percussive action scenes hardly mask its lack of inspiration.
For a movie directed by two Hong Kong legends, Tsui Hark and Ringo Lam, Twin Dragons drags!
movie_title: Twin Dragons (Shuang long hui) (Brother vs. Brother) (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Fiennes' and Moore's performances are strong enough to carry this film through even the slightly preposterous turn that puts the movie on the path to that conclusion.
The Mumford character requires an actor who doesn't try too hard, and Loren Dean doesn't.
An ideal summer movie!
One of the greatest horror film of the '90s!
Not pretty. And not scary, either.
Beautiful as she is, Elisabeth Shue is simply impossible to watch without cringing whenever she tries to do autistic.
The Bone Collector blows its budget on helicopters, fleets of cop cars, gory effects and the charisma of Denzel Washington to bring this pointless hackwork to theaters.
It's definitely not capable of being rescued.
Although The Haunting gets funnier, dumber, and less suspenseful as it goes on, it never loses the power to frighten, because it never had it.
Offensively phony and unintentionally hilarious!
What reads brutal and exhilarating in Blade and The Matrix is pure slapstick in this muddy-looking movie.
Schrader shows the Tarantino punks how it's done.
A widescreen epic adventure so beautifully designed and performed that it doesn't have to make a bit of sense.
American Pie stirs the adolescent heart and groin!
Charming as it is, the film is too thin to justify carfare and ticket money.
While the film has some interesting shifts in pace, mood and structure, it has nothing new or interesting to say.
End of Days is definitely in the top two or three worst studio films of the year.
Soderbergh, screenwriter Lem Dobbs and star Terence Stamp make a cool team.
Ulrich and Gooding just don't click as comic antagonists / buddies.
A film this dramatically inept doesn't test your faith in the Papacy nearly as much as it troubles your faith in movies.
The young actors playing Frank at various ages (Joe Breen, Ciaran Owens, Michael Legge) are all excellent.
Babbitt loves her actors and gives them fun stuff to do. If she works with similar themes in the future, I hope she gives her performers and her clearly fertile imagination more room to play.
"The Artist and the Model" is a simple, straightforward film about the wonder and awe that the natural world inspires in us.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Scattered moments of heat and light just don't add up to a forceful or vital movie about a subject that deserves one.
Daniels directs in about five styles at once, like a Bollywood maestro. No, it's not a musical, but it makes plenty of visual music.
A glorified trailer by Wong Kar Wai is still something to see.
I wish I could give four stars to Giamatti's big, sad eyes and outrageous Civil War beard.

movie_review_blurb: Theeb is everything you could possibly want from a film, from stand-out central performances to heart-stopping set-pieces and thought-provoking themes.
There is no denying the fact that The Love Witch is an exercise in self-indulgence, a nostalgia trip, but that doesn't mean it isn't worth indulging in.
A playful, compassionate film, with a winning turn from Field.
A remarkable achievement despite the handicap of being an unofficial look into a colossal creative machine.
What Juliet, Naked may lack in depth it makes up for in pure, uncut charm - especially from [Rose] Byrne.
The film builds an exacting, creeping tension that lasts almost the duration of the running time
It sounds gloomy and somber, it's true, but the emotionally rousing Monster does find threads of hope amid the despair.
Africa has long been exploited by the West: for ivory, for gold, for diamonds, for oil. And, more recently, for, and by, Hollywood.
A noisy, not particularly charming collection of skits and skirmishes.
It gallops along with a suspenseful, dead-on sense of dread.
Apocalypto is primal.
A hushed, emotionally intense study of a crumbling relationship and the existential gloom and doom that come with it, Climates is an old-school art pic
There's a formula here, and it's not the liquid being shot into popping veins.
It's a spiritual journey about the timelessness of true love. And it's a journey better not taken.
Baked and half-baked.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An earnest and altogether silly piece of conjectural melodrama.
Happy Feet offers dazzling cinematic family fun, and a mad medley of tunes (songs made famous by the Beatles, the Beach Boys, Earth, Wind & Fire, Queen, and Stevie Wonder, among others).
A movie star who can slip easily into high-beam mode, Smith gives a restrained and nuanced turn.
A rambling but potent ensemble piece.
Alan, Lawrence and Ellie, intersecting here and there with a circle of acquaintances and strangers, insinuate themselves into the viewer's heart like good friends.
Rocky Balboa puts the anything-is-possible fairy tale to rest with a lot of heart, and a lot of hooey.
But Smokin' Aces is all pumped up with no place to go, and the crashing letdown, as the rush fades and the ammo shells lie spent across the screen, is heavy indeed.
The Painted Veil is rich with history and heartbreak. It's stirring stuff.
...A spectacle for the eyes and for the soul.
[A] dark, terrifying and sometimes very funny film.

There's more voyeurism going on here, and less insight into a certain culture (the young and the wasted), than the filmmakers would probably admit to, but the performances are scarily real, and the outcome, well, is just scary.

Luc Besson, the most-Hollywoodish of Gallic directors, has adapted his own series of popular (in France) kid-lit tomes to produce a glossy, expensive ($84 million) and long-winded mix of live action and computer animation.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A cool, unique-looking animated feature (the Ike-era design elements make for great eye candy), director Brad Bird's tale of a small-town boy and his outer-space robot is hip and entertaining without pandering, or condescending, to the kiddie set.
The great thing about Venus -- apart from its sharp eye for the daily routines and drab details of senior citizenry in a buzzing metropolis -- is that it isn't soppy, or sentimental.
Old Joy's not-going- anywhere-ness is a big part of its charm.
What Hannibal Rising is, mostly, is a hoot. Gong Li cautions the nightmare-plagued Hannibal that 'Memory is a knife -- it can hurt you.' And let's not forget the classic, 'They ate my sister.'

Bridge to Terabithia the movie, like the book, is buckets-of-tears sad. Director Csupo and company manage to get that -- the simple power of a story about kindred souls, about loss, about the limitless possibilities of a lively mind -- just right.
A powerful indictment of Russia's illegal adoption industry -- and a story of pipsqueak resolve and resilience.
A numerological, super-dumb-ological thriller.

Filled with lovely images (the opening credit sequence, of Charlie in his spacesuit, riding the range on horseback, is a beaut) and nice character turns, The Astronaut Farmer nonetheless veers too close to cliche.

A cool-headed thriller, and a richly detailed character study that traces the birth and evolution of America's foreign espionage bureaucracy, The Good Shepherd also marks a significantly more mature, assured directing turn from Robert De Niro.

Filled with close-ups of Jesus and his apostles (all the better to hide the absence of elaborate period sets), mixing quotes from the Scripture with flat exposition, this low-budget affair is earnest and, alas, more than a little bit cartoonish.
The fractured narrative, with its era shifts, its talking-head soliloquies, and screenplay-style subtitles, gives an edgy, artsy pulse to what is essentially a well-honed exercise in nostalgia.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Little kids are sure to be bowled over by Roddy's reluctant heroism and Rita's resourcefulness, while the more grown up among us should appreciate the gleeful pokes at pop culture and Anglo-French relations.
... unnecessary ...

The absurdly funny Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby is at once a glorious send-up of NASCAR culture and a goofy celebration of the redneck, red state, red-blooded American culture that spawned it.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Boasts another formidable and fine-tuned performance from the great Charlotte Rampling.
This is the slightest and slimmest of sex comedies.

Bobby Moresco, who cowrote Crash and coproduced Million Dollar Baby, makes an undistinguished directing debut, assembling a band of actors who know but two modes: simmering rage and over-the-top histrionics.
No matter where one stands on the political map, no matter what one's views of Operation Iraqi Freedom and its aftermath, this film is compelling, troubling and illuminating.
Trapped between edgy art flick and exploitation psychothriller, The Quiet manages to be neither, and manages to be pretty awful in the bargain.
Conjures up a world of mystery, romance and suspense.

The film is exquisitely simple, and exceptionally tough, and its monochromatic visuals -- and cast of fascinating, hard-bitten faces -- make it impossible not to watch, even when events become close to unbearable.
An intriguing study of identity, marriage and, perhaps, madness.

With a more restrained, subtler actor, Hollywoodland could have been what it aspires to be: a study of twin trajectories (Reeves and Simo) caught in the spotlights of Tinseltown, where dreams crash headlong into hard reality -- and dubious ethics.
Gosling anchors the picture, and Epps ... has a kind of grace, presence and knowingness that far more experienced actors struggle vainly to find.
Sensual, dreamlike, both intimate and epic, The House of Sand is a cinematic tour de force.
... it would be nice to have some insight, and some artistry, along with the same old same old. The Last Kiss dispenses none of that.
A merrily macabre things-we-do- for-love yarn.
In essence, a wild soap opera disguised as a political allegory, it's a movie, with its over-the-map performances, that is worth catching only for the inadvertent laugh or two.
Flyboys has computer imaging and a fleet of vintage aircraft on its side, but it remains considerably less convincing than Wings (1927), and less exciting.
No heavy lifting here (except for a few stiff bodies), but Keeping Mum has a macabre merriment about it.
Renaissance is more than mere eye candy. It sneaks into deeper, darker places - a dream world of shadowy menace.
Costner is suitably Costneresque -- that is, low-key, stoic, and capable of a wry turn here or there.
Freed from iconic figures and weighty themes, Martin Scorsese, in The Departed, gets to riff and rock. And the audience gets a huge, bloody, profane entertainment in the bargain.
Wild Hogs isn't as jaw-droppingly awful as its trailers suggest.
Taken for what it is -- 'tweenage escapism -- Stormbreaker is moderately fun.
Suffers from a vague, ad lib-y script and a cast that, while hardly shy, isn't exactly charismatic.

It can and will be seen as 'patriotic,' a tribute to the armed forces. But it is also, in its clear-eyed depiction of the chaos and carnage of battle, of the soldiers' quaking fear, and the cruel finality of a bullet or a bomb, very much an antiwar film.
Siblings Jonathan and Christopher Nolan's adaptation of the novel by Christopher Priest offers three acts of exasperating muddle.
Luke is fine in the lead, proving that his good work in Antoine Fisher was no fluke.
If the book was deadpan, the movie is more -- or less -- dead.

Borat leaves no ethnicity, no religious or social order (well, maybe one or two) unmocked. Both the glorious U.S. and A. and the beautiful Kazakhstan get pilloried by Baron Cohen and his sublimely silly, unapologetically offensive shtick.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Take a cool premise, a smart director and a top-flight cast, then throw an ex-TV sketch comedy knucklehead into the mix - and voila, a thinking person's dramedy that grapples with issues of fate and free will, love and liberation. Look out, Oscars.

Humid and overwrought, with Ricci working at fever pitch and Jackson bringing fire, brimstone and some passable blues licks to the equation, Black Snake Moan is no polite little indie thing, and certainly no formulaic studio exercise.
A fine, slow-building affair.

300 is one breathtaking digi-tableau after another. But the dialogue is a joke, the performances have more to do with bodybuilding than character, and the lesson that the film imparts isn't anything to do with courage and military skill.
There's an old Zen saying, 'It's the journey, not the destination.' The Golden Door offers an extraordinary journey of its own.
Ultimately, Evan Almighty is too sappy, too sanctimonious.
You desperately want the story, and the characters, to make some kind of emotional sense. This, however, does not happen.
The tone and tenor of Waititi's effort are quieter, gentler [than Napoleon Dynamite]. This is low-key stuff, but strangely, goofily endearing.
An entertainingly hairy paranormal affair based on a King short story, 1408 sets up its star -- and its audience -- for a blood-curdling, bone-chilling night of horror.
It's the movie equivalent of a cop on the eve of retirement: he knows what he has to do, and he gets it done. But his heart isn't really in it anymore.
With Ratatouille, Bird once again delivers not just a great, witty story, but dazzling visuals as well.

A long, but never lazy, celebration of the natural world, of sexual desire and discovery, and of the peculiar social order of early-20th-century Britain, Lady Chatterley is also a heartbreaking story of true love.
If Rescue Dawn isn't about heroism, then it's about something deeper, more primitive: survival instinct.
A sleek little meditation on beauty, desire, love and time. Now and then, it's fairly sophisticated stuff.
The Simpsons Movie is finally here. And guess what? It's funny. But not that funny.
... a mild-mannered farce ...
At a certain point, like a dying star about to pop into eternal nothingness, the movie can't be seen as anything -- it just implodes.

Although FF:ROTSS comes from the same place as Spider-Man (New York, and Marvel editor Stan Lee's noggin), this sequel to the 2005 Fantastic Four debut is lackluster, even by comparison to the lackluster Spider-Man 3.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [A] moderately engaging pseudo-Brit-lit piffle.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Gripping, powerful, heart-breaking.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's hardly surprising that Gypsy Caravan, a lively and lovely music documentary, is rife with whirling rhythms, wild, soaring melodic lines, the ululations of singers steeped in centuries of Romany tradition.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Day Watch deploys head-spinning cinematography and cool special effects. It's a trippy affair, even if it's just about impossible to track.
Quote not available.
It brings too much of everything to the table: It's the cinema equivalent of a long, winding, run-on sentence.
An innovative mix of sophisticated puppetry and special effects, Labyrinth has all the components of classic myth.

A well-crafted British farce -- albeit one with an American director, Frank Oz, working the controls - this throwback to the haughty high jinks of vintage Ealing comedies begins with an obvious, but effective, gag.
The Invasion is mostly about delivering thrills, and chills, and this it does with moderate success and a bunch of fast, no-nonsense edits.
A crazed odyssey of booze, lust, thwarted sex and undying friendship.
Satire should be knife-sharp and whip-smart, and The Nanny Diaries never is.
While Balls of Fury is slightly more sophisticated in its comic strategies, 'slightly' remains the operative word.
This is a film about momentum, gravity, trajectory. It's a physics lesson wrapped up in an espionage thriller, and when director Greengrass yells 'Action!' he means it.
Severance will have you laughing one minute and feeling terribly unsettled the next.
Slickly shot, coolly edited, oozing dark, deadpan humor, Mr. Brooks finds Costner at the top of his game. His moves are subtle, his expressions flat, his emotions clamped down, contained.
It is possible to bring substance, as well as poetry, to the vignette form, but more often Paris, Je T'Aime is merely mundane.
