Not as good, nor as complex, as The Lost Boys, but that doesn't make the story of mass annihilation, sprawling refugee camps, the generosity of Americans, and the resilience of a handful of Sudanese survivors any less worthy of telling -- again.
Premonition is an odd little thing, with a protagonist in a protracted fugue state and a plot that doesn't know whether its coming or going.
Written by David Nicholls, adapting his own novel, and directed by Tom Vaughan, a British TV veteran making his feature debut, Starter for 10 clips along smartly.
There's an attention to detail in the visuals and sound design that pushes it up several notches above most kiddie fare. It's not art, dude, but it will do.
A generic against-the-odds underdog sports drama.
A chase movie and a pretty crafty thriller, Shooter owes a lot to Sydney Pollack's Three Days of the Condor.
Simply put, it's terrific.
A Spanish comedy that isn't quite as frenzied or farcical as its husband-and-wife writer-director team clearly intended it to be.
Dumb with a capital D, Blades of Glory takes its (almost) fleshed-out sketch-comedy idea as far as an ice-skating buddy movie with we're-not-gay jokes and a psycho stalker can go.
An effectively unsettling mix of Southern gothic and Old Testament hugger-mugger.
The Ten, admittedly, is not Krzysztof Kieslowski's Decalogue. [Director] Wain's pieces are just jumping-off points for screwball improv and inspired throwaways.
Blitz captures the melancholy, the rage, the wackiness and drama of adolescence, and he gets winning performances out of his young stars.
Like Rear Window before it, Disturbia is sly and suspenseful and full of mounting dread.
Although Hot Fuzz is a good 30 minutes too long (the ending -- or endings -- are endless), it is also good for long stretches of laughs.
Vacancy, in the end, simply offers a particularly aggressive brand of couples counseling.
For Piaf fans, La Vie en Rose is a must-see. For Piaf fans yet-to-be, [writer-directors] Dahan and Cotillard's extraordinary film is an opportunity rich with discovery.
Visually dazzling and outlandishly obscene.
Thoroughly engaging, even as it explores the ugly underbelly of competitive gaming.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cage is cool, quiet and a touch melancholy as Johnson -- carrying the burden of his gift with a brooding brow and a ready punch line.
Black Book doesn't let the grim facts of the Holocaust get in the way of some ripping pulp.
A transcendental piece of filmmaking.
Bland and compromised, it feels as if it's been fine-tuned and focus-grouped within an inch of its life.
Spider-Man 3 kicks off this Summer of Sequels in big, loud, occasionally clever, but more often meandering ways. It's not dull, exactly, but neither is it much fun.
After The Last Kiss and Garden State, not to mention Scrubs (second only to Law and Order when it comes to TV ubiquity), Braff's shtick, his bug-eyed, hangdog, goofy-grin thing, is getting tired.
The film meanders, sidetracks, and frustrates -- few of the rap songs, some of them boasting wildly inspired couplets, are shown and heard in their entirety.
Despite all the stock characters and scenarios, Fox and company manage to bring things to life. And cut some hair.
You have the slightest of romps, and one that ends so abruptly that you suspect the prolific Veber had already moved on to his next project.
Where Henry Fool was a resonant study of friendship, art, trust and politics, Fay Grim is just a throwaway joke.
[Director] Lawrence's compelling little film pursues a deep question: why people make the choices that they do - and how they then live with those decisions, right or wrong, weak or strong.
It may not be the real world of New York, or even of most relationships, but it's worth a visit.
It's a busy made-up universe -- with rules, rituals, and a deity-tree that could give the Hindu hierarchy a run for its rupee. And it's extremely silly.
By recording this all too commonplace and dehumanizing process, Puiu's film shows the sick old man and the strangers who deal with him to be all too human -- extraordinarily so.
Amiable if ragtag.
Lord of War would have worked better if its message had been more muted, muffled. Niccol could have used a silencer on his gun.
No great shakes, The Baxter nonetheless has a quiet loopiness going for it.
Cronenberg's movie is eerily compelling and darkly humorous. And chilling -- to the bone.

Tim Burton's Corpse Bride is easily the best stop-motion animated necrophiliac musical romantic comedy of all time. It is also just simply, wonderful: a morbid, merry tale of true love that dazzles the eyes and delights the soul.
As striking as Bertolucci's classic looks, there's even more powerful stuff in the storytelling.
Quiet, quirky gem.
A kicky mix of space-movie mayhem and cowboy-movie corn.
It's eye candy with snorkels and fins.
Nice folks, fun time, thanks for the peek (I guess), and so what?
It's the subtle, tricky ways in which Fellowes subverts the expected -- and unexpected -- in this high-end domestic thriller that make the film so much dark, roiling fun.
Two for the Money is "inspired by a true story." Problem is, it's just not that inspired.
A funny, sad and absolutely lovely film.
movie_title: Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's a harrowing tale, but one that gets phonied up with unnecessary slo-mos, manipulative soundtrack cues, and unrestrained thespianism.
The script is a jumble of caricatures and cliches.
Domino is less a movie than a hyperkinetic slide show -- presented during a nuclear attack.
It's to Fanning's and Russell's credit, and the filmmakers', that the formula never gets the better of the film.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's all very deep, but in a tricked-up, art-directed sort of way.

Too long, and too rich, for its own good, but clearly Gaiman and McKean were bursting with ideas. Those ideas fly all over the place, sometimes landing with a thunk, but more often taking the breath away.
A gloomy, self-serious picture.
It's delicate stuff, and it's been brought to the screen with grace, humor and a mood that's wonderfully (here comes another of those film review words) bittersweet.
Where the Truth Lies might have worked if Egoyan had cast someone more credible in the central role of the reporter, but Lohman isn't believable for a minute.
A gently comedic parable that offers a unique view of a cloistered society while addressing themes of faith, family and friendship that are universal.
Compared to the CG gems from Pixar, Chicken Little is stylistically inconsistent, narratively messy, and, well, just not much fun.
Although the picture suffers a narrative letdown in the third act that leaves its central characters -- and, alas, its audience -- in the muck of anticlimax, Jarhead has moments of real glory.
If Deceived was Hitchcock Lite, Derailed is Extra Lite -- there's no caloric content whatsoever.
While Downey's rumpled insouciance jibes with the movie's jaded, narcissistic tone, it's a hard tone to take for a hundred minutes or so.
A fairly dreadful melodrama drenched in self-pity.
The real reason to see this slight but interesting documentary is to watch and listen to the radiant Aury.
A handsome Holocaust melodrama hobbled by a transparent and cartoonish script.
Everything about An Unfinished Life's screenplay is cliched and predictable, but the actors manage to elevate the proceedings above and beyond shameless soap.
It's a celebration of the good times and bad times shared by a man and woman who found each other in the middle of some historic craziness, and it rocks.
Tony Takitani, fablelike and beautiful, requires a certain amount of patience, but its small, peculiar charms work their way into your soul.
With cartoon villains and cartoon victims all the lane-changing, gear-shifting, and wrong-way-on-the-freeway driving seems like a meaningless waste of time.
The relationship between the talent-challenged Will and the punishing Green makes for one of the film's meatier dramatic threads.
The Other Side of the Street is full of the stillness, and silences, of a life that's been muted and shut down.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Street (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An exquisite exploration into the realms of seduction, obsession, deception and disillusionment.
A first film with a deft comedic touch and a trio of charming stars.
Captures the spirit and astounding agility of its krump constituents with appreciative zeal.
Neither Marion, with her melancholy stares, nor Gilles, with his detachment and his cigarettes, appears more than a character sketch.
If you want to see how members of a family that's fraught with discord and dysfunction learn about teamwork and the nature of kin -- and dispatch bad guys in the process -- rent The Incredibles.

A mischievously inventive, surreal entertainment, one that celebrates not only Whipple Scrumptious Fudgemallow Delight and Nutty Crunch Surprise but Busby Berkeley, Stanley Kubrick, the Beatles, and the outer-space acting choices of one Johnny Depp.

Although Me and You and Everyone We Know requires patience on the part of the viewer -- to get past the faux naivete of its grown-up characters, to get past its deadpan arty tone -- Miranda July's feature debut is worth the time.
movie_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Potter explores midlife ennui, (middle-)East-West tension, theology, biology and the irrational nature of romance in this ambitious, if ultimately sketchy, drama.
Hustle & Flow is a weird fusion of blaxploitation and American indie, built on a template of old-style, follow-your-dream Hollywood drama. But it works -- sometimes magnificently.
Manages to deal with its raw, awful subject matter in ways that are both challenging and illuminating.
The Island could be read as a metaphor for societal ills if it weren't so shamelessly dumb.
Duris' performance is more finely tuned and less frenetic than Keitel's enjoyably over-the-top job, and the film's emotional chords resonate in more satisfying and complicated ways.
movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arrêté (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This ambitious drama grapples with big themes -- identity, family, East-West conflict - but loses itself in melodrama, caricature and narrative missteps.
A weird, moonshine-and- marijuana-fueled yee-haw fest based on the '80s TV show.
Saraband, flat and static both visually and thematically, doesn't begin to approximate the austere beauty of the director's art-house classics.
The film offers a rich gumbo of menace, mystery and magic - and then lets it go cold and mushy in a rainstorm of Hollywood haunted-house huggermugger.
This smart, unhurried drama plays out like a retro version of Saving Private Ryan.
Ambiguous in a satisfying, puzzling sort of way.
Craven, an old hand at menace, shifts gears smoothly from the slasher parodies of Scream, offering a more subdued brand of suspense.
Kings and Queen, full of passion and humor, madness and grief, is close to a masterpiece.
Mad passion and marital ennui collide with calamitous results in Asylum.
Cronicas is the kind of tense, terrific suspenser that screams for a Hollywood remake. Only the remake won't be anywhere near as good, so check out the original.
If The Brothers Grimm flies apart like a badly designed airplane (and it does), it still has more going for it than most of the movie fare this summer.
The filmmaker's assurance and vision in reimagining the novel are downright inspiring.
It's all terribly atmospheric, and if you're in the mood for atmosphere, 2046 delivers.
Gets bogged down in midlife-crisis cliches.
Leaves no gender, race, class or religion untouched in its scabrous effort to show how cruel humans can be. But it also leaves viewers with no one at all to like, or believe.
An enjoyably cheesy teen melodrama with a touch of indie edge.
Easily the best computer-animated feature to come from Hollywood in a long while, Monster House is also one of the weirdest.
[A]s an antidote to the sugary confections of the season, its hung-over cynicism works wonders.
If you can stand the profanity, the crudeness, and the merciless strafing of all things noble and sacrosanct, then you'll find yourself huddled over in a painful ball of nonstop guffaws.
Sharply observed and deftly acted, Friends With Money offers a funny, sad, trenchant view of women of a certain age and social milieu (moneyed Los Angeles), struggling with, well, life.
A throw-it-at-the-wall-and-see-if-it-sticks onslaught of potty jokes, puns, celebrity cameos, J-horror, and j-high sophistication and wit. You get laughs, but not nearly as many as you'd hoped.
Rife with meaningless hugger-mugger, the movie is no In the Line of Fire.
The filmmaker's ability to at once mock himself and consider his dilemma with compassion transforms an otherwise smarmy tale into something honest and insightful.

There's no way to watch United 93, Paul Greengrass' heartbreaking, pulse-pounding drama about the lone hijacked commercial airliner that failed to reach its target on Sept. 11, 2001, and not anticipate the dreadful outcome.
... icky, incoherent thriller ...
Simply in terms of its visual poetry, the exhilarating effects of image upon image of dazzling impossibility, The Promise is not to be missed.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Alas, Brick, from writer-director Rian Johnson, isn't as clever as its conceit.
Watt's characters ... laugh at themselves and their dark obsessions, and there's something optimistic in the filmmaker's clear-eyed, straightforward storytelling style.

There's nothing hip or ironic about Poseidon, which makes Russell and Lucas the perfect leading men: jut-jawed, macho, and able to keep a straight face while being pinned by fake beams, and held hostage by page upon page of sappy dialogue.
... The Da Vinci Code may be controversial and even heretical -- but worse, still, it's plodding, tedious, deathly dull.
Over the Hedge isn't by any stretch bad. It's just banal.
Without editorializing, Mermin raises fascinating questions about the cultural impact of globalization, the allure of the West, and the troubled history of an ancient land.
Breathtakingly beautiful, breathtakingly brutal and simply breathtaking.
Illuminating and unsettling.
Hell can't possibly get any more beautiful, or strange, than the way it's rendered in Lady Vengeance.
Pixar finally rolled out a clunker.
The stuff of pulp, seriously at odds with what the writer-director has always done best. That is, show the inner workings of people, their needs, their fears, their small dreams.
Shines a light on a forgotten corner of the antiwar movement: the men (and a few women) who returned from their tours of duty filled with doubt and disillusionment over what they saw, and did, there.
The dramas going on here, on and off the court, more than make up for any lack of flash.
The beautifully shot Nacho Libre presents its improbable hero -- doughy, boyish and speaking in a dubious accent -- as someone utterly confident of his abilities, and his place in the world.
From the perfect family home movies that open the film, to its unconvincing 'urban' settings, Death Sentence is one-dimensional, cliched.
Director Kyung-Taek Kwak orchestrates all this with flair, but leading man Lee doesn't have much to offer beyond a steely stoicism, and Jang's histrionic villainy borders on the parodic.

What really sinks Waist Deep is the fact that the action scenes and car chases are poorly handled, and that the climactic confrontation takes place far too early, leaving the characters to lumber around for 20 minutes in a dull daze.
This rickety Sandler vehicle finds the comedy star steering through a charmless fantasy of self-discovery.
Chilling and compelling.
This Superman is good. Very good.
It helps -- immensely -- that Cheung is pitch-perfect. Her performance is heartbreaking.
The Curse of the Black Pearl, this second installment in the promised trilogy (Parts 2 & 3 were shot concurrently) lacks the swash and buckle of the original. And then some.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As arresting as the images are, Shepard's clunky, soap-opera banter brings most everything, and everyone, crashing down to earth.
Flimsily scripted.
This rollicking day in the life of a band of skateboarding Latino punk-rockers doesn't exude the voyeuristic smarm of previous Clark forays.
This Down Under horse opera is violent, grim and stunningly good.
That's not to say this Wardrobe isn't worth climbing into. Only that along with the dollops of delight, a bit of disappointment awaits on the other side.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Touch the Sound is remarkable not only because of Glennie's story -- a clinically deaf Grammy-winning musician who has played with the world's great orchestras -- but for the way Riedelsheimer uses sound.
Everything is beautiful -- even the squalor of poverty, the suffering of war. And nothing, ever, is revealed.
The four actors fit into their respective roles nicely, though in the case of Jarrat's bushman Mick, nice isn't quite the right word.
Munich ricochets all over the place, but it hits its target dead-on.
One would expect Casanova, a movie about the storied loverboy of 18th-century Venice, to be wicked, ribald fun. One would be wrong.
The jokes are in its tackiness, and gauchery, and raspberry-inducing send-up of Broadway traditions. On that level, the movie works fine -- and is a whole lot cheaper for the ticket buyer.
A story of lust, love and the lure of money, Match Point is so thoroughly compelling, and so deftly acted by all parties concerned, that it turns and churns deep in the gut.
Hoodwinked may be a poor cousin to the Shrek franchise, but this made-on-the-cheap computer-animated feature still has more style and snarky gags than Disney's recent CG hit, Chicken Little.
'Deadpan' is a hard concept to translate -- even when everybody's speaking the same language.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This is a movie -- albeit one with a great, gripping story -- shot through with meaningful glances, middling performances and melodramatic music cues. Pity.
It's a farce with heart, a meditation on identity, family and gender politics that has real faith in its characters -- even when the characters themselves lack it.
Wily, sad, funny, and full of life.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's not long before the timely issue of identity theft takes a backseat to old-fashioned Hollywood villainy, unnecessary (and nonsensical) red herrings, and stuff that doesn't make sense.
Eight Below is dazzling to look at, and nicely intercuts the human relationships with the pooches' awesome struggles to stay alive in the white, wintry wild.

A sly, delirious homage to the writers, producers, techies and thespians who assemble with the common mission of telling a tale, and then, many months and meltdowns later, move on to the next project -- and paycheck.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Although it doesn't have Kate Beckinsale, her guns ablazin', vamped out in the latest vampire-slaying couture, Night Watch is vastly more fun than the similar-themed Underworld pics.
It's impossible to imagine anyone, right-leaning or left, coming away from this hugely important documentary unshaken by its representation of the United States and its military establishment.
[Marshall] Curry's picture is must-see fare for any and every observer of the curious world of American politics.
It is Depp, as the debauched and decaying Restoration rake, who holds the camera. It's a strong, sturdy performance, but one that asks more of the audience than it might be possible to give.
Apart from its name (easily the front-runner for worst of the year), Failure to Launch represents a failure in every way: of ideas, of inspiration, of casting.
The movie is a lot of dark, Orwellian fun.
For all its ripped-from- the-headlines verisimilitude, Find Me Guilty sometimes feels like it should have been called Find Me My Cousin Vinny.
[Jason] Reitman makes an amazingly confident feature debut. Thank You for Smoking is funny stuff.
Intercutting post-robbery interrogation scenes with the action at hand, makes Inside Man a substantial and satisfying affair.
A quiet, loopy gem, Duck Season is a goofball celebration of old friends, new beginnings, adolescent freedom, and baked goods laced with a little something extra.
Like Tremors, only ickier, Slither is a tongue-in-cheek horror flick that skewers the genre while delivering seat-squirming scares.
Stone's purring, snarling, bedroom kink is embarrassing.
Captures the elegance, wit, spiritual longing and deep hum-ability of Cohen's work.
This pleasant but predictable affair does one thing very well: showcasing the versatility of Chiwetel Ejiofor.
David and Layla isn't going to solve any problems -- it's got way too many of its own.
The Farrellys manage to have their cake and scarf it down, disgustingly, too.
Remarkable.
Although its low-key realism is admirable, Eden doesn't really work.

A tale of horror, heroism, unimaginable physical challenges, and, yes, cannibalism, Stranded offers the kind of real-life drama that can't help but bring up notions of God, fate, and nature's imposing will.
movie_title: Stranded: I Have Come from a Plane That Crashed on the Mountains (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A must-see for political junkies, history buffs, and folks still fascinated by the paranoia-fueled follies of the twitchy, sweaty, decidedly uncharismatic 37th president.
Despereaux is a little too desperate to be loved.

For all its high-caliber performances, its cutting dissection of the roles of men and women within the Catholic hierarchy, and its timely resonance in the wake of the church's sexual abuse scandals, there's something pat and tidy about Doubt.
Sloppy, choppy, and saved by an affably low-key and typically sophomoric Sandler performance.

Maybe if there was something going with the dialogue -- snappy Chandlerisms, say, or even just sentences that made sense -- the fussy digital artifice of The Spirit wouldn't seem so, well, dispiriting.
The film isn't half bad. It's certainly not the unwitting laugh riot that many (me included) expected.
The Curious Case of Benjamin Button puts a Hollywood sheen on a decidedly eccentric yarn.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If this ragged but near-brilliant movie is about a guy trying to resurrect his career, so too is the performance at its heart.
If Slumdog Millionaire's success has Hollywood thinking American audiences are ready for the authentic Indian movie experience, Chandni Chowk to China could quickly put the kibosh on that notion.
With Benicio Del Toro delivering a fiercely indrawn and mesmerizing performance in the title role, Che is neither a hagiography nor a superficial character sketch.
Sappy, sentimental and redeemed only by the quiet radiance and fidgety intelligence of its leads, Last Chance Harvey is a fantasy about mopey middle-agers getting a second chance at love.
A close-up look at the strange alchemy that is jazz singing -- singing at its most sublime.
movie_title: Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to an extraordinary performance from Michelle Williams and an exceptionally deft hand from her director, this low-budget and loping little film is a genuine heartbreaker.

A fleet, no-nonsense rescue thriller from the crackerjack French director Pierre Morel, Taken is satisfying (1) for the Gaelic gravitas of its star, (2) its slam-bang chase scenes and bone-snapping martial arts, and (3) the scenic backdrops of Paris.
A teenager's resistance to her father's new girlfriend provides the emotional underpinnings for The Uninvited, a spooky, if narcotic, psychological thriller adapted from a 2003 K-horror suspenser.
A trippy, nonstop action fest, with the feel of a really good episode of Heroes.
Although comic mayhem follows Martin's Clouseau everywhere, none of it is particularly funny.
It's Dead Calm meets Very Bad Things, with English accents.
For its amusing premise, Fanboys is scarily flat.
The tale of two brothers from childhood to manhood, it is rife with timeless storybook themes and offers an inspiring vision of harmony between different cultures, different people.
movie_title: Azur et Asmar (Azur and Asmar: The Princes' Quest) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Where Run Lola Run was like a perpetual-motion machine, The International seems to forever be stopping in its own tracks.
Not just a great sports movie, Harvard Beats Yale 29-29 captures a pivotal moment in recent history.

The Wild Child is fascinating not only for its Tarzan-like true-life story, but also for what it says about the process of nurturing and educating children, and the tools we use -- language, discipline, affection -- to do so.
It's ugly. It's powerful. But it's hard to look away.
Despite its essential implausibility, Two Lovers lingers in your consciousness -- or loiters there, like Leonard standing on the street corner.

This movie will shake your windows and rattle your walls. At least it will for a couple of hours, before 40-odd minutes of draggy, comic-book exposition smother the wild, subversive superhero business that came before.
An enjoyably goofy hybrid of extraterrestrial sci-fi and Iron Age action.
Fans of Rickman will appreciate the actor's sneering mix of buffoonery and misanthropy, Steenburgen gives another of her playfully ironic turns, and Miller's direction allows for few, if any, lulls.
Pray the Devil Back to Hell is at once inspiring and horrific.
movie_title: Pray the Devil Back to Hell (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Long in the making -- and almost as long in the watching -- Baz Luhrmann's Australia is epic piffle.
Pomposity and foolishness abound, but the laughs are few and far between.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Flash of Genius has its corn, its conflation, its composite characters. But Kinnear does what he's done in the past: You underestimate the guy's acting chops, and suddenly, strikingly, he floors you.
Murky and grainy, and showing human beings at their grimmest -- thievery, rape, betrayal, murder -- Blindness is no barrel of laughs. But it is a barrel of pretentious metaphorical musings.
An American Carol is about as not-funny as a comedy can get.
Quote not available.
More often, all the running, the hiding, the escaping (from giant moles, from giant Murray) are decidedly less exciting, and compelling, than City of Ember wants to be.
Oddball and ingenious.
An OK sports doc that owes as much to reality TV competitions as it does to the genre of nautical cinema.
W. offers a failed mix of political satire, psycho-biography, SNL-style mimicry, and Shakespearean tragedy.
The comedy is uniformly crude and lewd, some of it works and some of it's lame.
As writer-director Stefan Ruzowitzky shows, powerfully, affectingly, in The Counterfeiters, the privileges experienced by this small team of Jews and criminals came at a price.
As for the space stuff, well, George Lucas need not lose any sleep.
What follows - walking, talking, flirting, fighting - is a charming piece of low-budget, improv-y filmmaking in the tradition of Richard Linklater's Before Sunrise.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sure, it's a skewed view through adolescent eyes, but it's one that still speaks to the aspirations, agendas, image-making and spin control behind a real, grown-up political election.
Impossibly arty and, at times, narratively incoherent, Filth and Wisdom still has its goofy charms.
Pride and Glory definitely stirs up some drama. But the script doesn't serve the drama well.
There are cutting laughs along the way, and Keener plays the hard-nosed studio chief with an insider's acumen, but, really, Entourage is better than this.
Shot by Wong's longtime cinematographer, Christopher Doyle, Ashes is dreamy and splendid and definitely deserves to be seen on the big screen.
The Boy in the Striped Pajamas has a storybook innocence about it, by design.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's pretty formulaic stuff, and earns its R rating with profanity and unapologetically gratuitous female nudity, but somehow has a winning knuckleheaded charm.

Godard frames and edits his shots, moves the camera, uses music, and deploys his actors in ways that still seem radical -- even as several generations of directors since have cribbed and stolen from him.
movie_title: My Life to Live (It's My Life) (Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux) (1962)

movie_review_blurb: Brilliantly creepy.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Kristin Scott Thomas gives a performance that is so chilling, so braced in pain that it's almost impossible to bear. Almost impossible, because, in fact, it's impossible not to behold this riveting piece of role immersion.
Quantum -- the 22d 'official' Bond picture, 24th including the rogue Bonds -- is never less than engaging.
Funny, fear-inducing, with periods of voyeuristic gore and an undercurrent of anxiety and dread, Let the Right One In is up there with the bloodsucking classics.
Amazingly, it feels real -- the actors pull it off.
It doesn't happen often, but when it does, look out: a movie that rocks and rolls, that transports, startles, delights, shocks, seduces. A movie that is, quite simply, great.

Roiling with laughter, tears, drunken confessions, revelatory soliloquies, pain, sorrow, hospital visits, and various kinds of love, A Christmas Tale is a smart, sprawling, and sublimely entertaining feast.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A clever art-imitates-life-imitates-art send-up of celebrityhood and the state of the action-hero genre, JCVD juggles humor with whomping martial-arts moves and a kind of melancholy star turn from the melancholy, muscular star.
McCarroll comes off as a likable and talented guy, amazingly calm as the Big Moment arrives and the guy making his models' shoes is nowhere to be found.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Aiming for a romantic-caper vibe, Duplicity zips from one elaborate piece of hugger-mugger to the next. But at a certain point, boredom sets in.
The footage is spectacular, the colors electric, the life aquatic trippier than anything you'll see in even the most wildly imaginative animated fare.

Full of forced jocularity and drawing-room hissy fits, with its cast parading around in vintage threads and antique cars, Easy Virtue is a close-to-insufferable souffle based on the 1925 Noel Coward play.
Not exactly a hundred million dollars' worth of classic comedy.

Phillips, with a script credited to Jon Lucas and Scott Moore (and with loads of loose-limbed interpretations from the cast), captures the amity among a group of grown men set loose without spouses, girlfriends, or sobriety to hinder them. (Or help.)

As Ryder's motives begin to reveal themselves, The Taking of Pelham 123 loses its aura of post-9/11 dread, replaced by a muddled commentary on Wall Street greed in these days of raging financial crises.
Not quite the absurdist gem that was Bent Hamer's 2004 release, Kitchen Stories, the Norwegian director's O'Horten is nonetheless a deadpan delight.
A sly and surprisingly sublime little noir romance, which marks the directing debut of Michael Keaton.
A heart-grabbing, awe-inspiring work that needs no embellishment.
It's not a pretty picture. But Food, Inc. is an essential one.
My Sister's Keeper offers a couple of twists, one of them crucial and the other cruelly unnecessary and melodramatic.
Allen and David do stuff in Whatever Works that shouldn't work but does.
A bravely earnest and gauzy bit of biography.
Ultimately, the movie's a bust.

In the end, Moon raises disturbing ethical questions about science and bioengineering, but it's the emotional questions the film poses -- about memory, about family, about identity -- that really resonate.
At best diverting, at worst an almost self-parodic compendium of French film cliches.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Like all the best war movies -- no matter what war, what era -- The Hurt Locker goes to the core of human nature.
The charmlessness of its central characters -- Rust's charisma-challenged Denis, Panettiere's Barbie-hard and vacuous Beth -- makes this putative farce all the more difficult to endure.
Half-Blood Prince is a bubbling cauldron of hormonal angst, rife with romance and heartbreak, jealousy and longing.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The character's fleeting success in the art world, her moody naivete and childlike reverence for both the natural and religious worlds, is conveyed with such tenderness and totality that it's almost heartbreaking to behold.
Havana Marking's excellent, illuminating film follows four Afghan Star finalists over the frenetic final months leading to the Moment of Truth.

Just about the only folks likely to find this humdrum hybrid of Mission: Impossible and The Wind in the Willows worthy for consideration are non-discriminating pip-squeaks happy to watch rodents rappelling walls and scampering along air ducts.
Funny People turns out to be fairly predictable, and not so rough. In a thoroughly satisfying way.
A pity-party of Hollywood narcissism.
Using the medium of Wallace and Gromit and Gumby, Israeli filmmaker Tatia Rosenthal turns her clay figures into real people in $9.99, a wise, wistful study of hope and dread.
A taut, German-made thriller, Jerichow adds a bit of European xenophobia to the pulp traditions of passion and betrayal.

To its credit, Adam doesn't go for the cheap, easy solution. In that way, the film shares something of the spirit (and realism?) of (500) Days of Summer: an acknowledgment that not every close encounter, no matter how meaningful, can last forever.
What is absolutely impressive are the visual effects: the hordes of aliens, the mother ship, the seamless blending of the real with the fantastic.
A kooky, head-spinning romantic mess.
No matter how dashing the two leads -- even as they get bloodied, blackened and battered around -- they're not dashing enough to keep Mr. & Mrs. Smith from feeling interminable.
[Has] a mess of cultural issues to reckon with, and Rudo y Cursi deals with them while offering an engaging rags-to-riches sports fantasy.
Eagle Eye wants to be Marathon Man, or Enemy of the State, only with a post-9/11 overlay and a plot device lifted straight from 2001: A Space Odyssey.
With the same twisted humor Raimi displayed in Evil Dead and Army of Darkness, his Drag Me to Hell is wickedly jolly and disturbingly frightening -- often at the same time.
Message to Hollywood: Stop with the time-travel stuff.
Malkovich, mixing the magician shtick with a dogged resiliency, a dab of pathos, and more than a bit of mystery (did he really just hypnotize 300 people?), is simply a joy to watch.
A weird and gloomy existential thriller.
A stagy, arty, and uncompelling account of the Welsh writer and his menage-y relations with his boozy Irish wife and his young Welsh girlfriend.

An amalgam of the vintage sci-fier Attack of the 50 Ft. Woman and Pixar's Monsters Inc., Monsters vs. Aliens is a goofy computer-animated romp that works just fine in the traditional moviegoing format.
An engagingly breezy tale about a guy with a broken heart and the girl who broke it.
At a certain point you find yourself thinking, why not watch the real It Came From Outer Space, instead of this mildly amusing replica?
Adventureland mixes the intimate, indie vibe of Daytrippers with the absurdist screwball streak of Superbad, to winning effect.
For a time, Surveillance is sick, smart fun. But then things get weird: yes, there's a big surprise, but its playout is predictable, and nasty.
Exceptionally fine performances elevate what could have been a pile-it-on melodrama into something deeper and more unsettling.

[Director] Fukunaga's startlingly impressive first feature is almost ruthless in its depiction of the brutality and degradation confronting the hidden hordes that cross rivers and hop trains trying to get to the United States.
As funny as it is sick (and it's plenty of both).
Tokyo! is a must-see for the Gondry segment, and a strange, diverting pleasure for the rest.
Full of passion and speechifying, 12 is unmistakably Russian in spirit and sensibility, but its themes are universal at their core.
Hunger is daunting and powerful work.
A wide-screen wildlife documentary in which the cycles of birth and death, migrations and seasons, are captured in stunning -- absolutely stunning -- ways.
Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck's film is a modest but masterful triumph.
Impossibly charming and impossibly French, Shall We Kiss? is a comic romance full of rueful musings about fidelity and true love.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quote not available.
A torn-from-the-headlines tale of institutional racism and injustice in the Lone Star State of not-so-long-ago, American Violet might not be subtle, but it's certainly powerful.
Caine moves through the less-than-surprising story line, shaking things up not with an actorly flamboyance but with a heartbreaking sense of quiet tragedy and regret.
The cast is ferociously good, bringing an edgy unpredictability to familiar scenarios of infidelity, alienation, and betrayal.
There's little of the seen-it-all, wise-guy acerbity that made his character in the X-Men trilogy stand apart from his fellow mutants. Here, he just glowers.
Deploying multiple split screens and a discreet but effective score, Tyson is hugely engrossing at the same time that it is not entirely credible.
A quietly soulful study of two very different men.

For the impatient viewer, Jarmusch's pulpy, poetic exercise will probably feel hopelessly, unintentionally parodic, prompting disdain and derision. Consider yourself warned -- not everyone's going to go for this business. But I did.
A likably oddball romantic comedy about a traveling saleswoman and a motel night manager who won't leave her alone.
Quietly and keenly observed.
A super-size rehash of the original.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Coldly voyeuristic, the film is a piece of cultural anthropology that doesn't even pretend to get into the soul of its characters.
If a couple of the plot devices seem contrived, The Lucky Ones makes up for them with sharp, heartfelt performances, and a deceptively easygoing narrative style.
Choke is too low-key for its own good, and neither Rockwell nor Macdonald seems able to find the right psychic momentum to move this thing along the way it needs to be.

A cool study of erotic longing, misguided love and class warfare in the civilized spheres of French society, Claude Chabrol's A Girl Cut in Two, despite its high melodrama and wicked humor, delivers a real emotional wallop.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A beautiful little meditation on childhood, on imagination literally taking flight.
A thumping, gabby slog.

Charlie Wilson's War tells its tale briskly, almost merrily. This is not a sober history lesson, but a political comedy laced with sex (party girls in limos, strippers in hot tubs), booze, and even good old-fashioned cocaine.
In the grief-drenched romantic comedy P.S. I Love You, things are excruciatingly amiss, start to finish.
...the film looks grand. A little too grand for the sappy proceedings.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Day-Lewis, channeling John Huston and Orson Welles (the grumbling intonations, the crazy-eyed glares) and who-knows-who-else, is nothing short of astounding.
This anemic vehicle for Ice Cube and Tracy Morgan to mug and jive through is just weak, weak stuff.
The Orphanage is never less than engaging. Here and there it's even genuinely frightening.

A light-headed, fleet-footed French caper, Jean-Jacques Beineix's ultra-stylish Diva stormed the art houses when it was released in 1982, and it's still a lot of fun now -- though its hip patina feels more quaint these days than cool.
There's not a believable character, nor line of convincing dialogue to be found.
The running and climbing, the tidal waves of debris rushing down the avenues, the screams and carnage grow tiresome.
Steep is a visually exhilarating sports documentary that is also more than a little exasperating.
First released in 1989, Let's Get Lost -- shot in the high-contrast black-and-white that's a hallmark of Weber's still photography -- is well worth revisiting on the big screen.
Set in a culture caught between East and West, between male chauvinism and female empowerment, Labaki's movie isn't about to revolutionize a genre -- its charms are modest, but many.

The absolute clarity of the storytelling, the aching authenticity of the performances make for a film that will stay with you for at least as long as the period alluded to in its title. It might stay with you forever.
Youth Without Youth is so beautiful, in fact, that it almost transcends the epic bunkum of Coppola's script. But almost doesn't count, even when it is uttered in ancient tongues.
A romantic comedy with brains as well as heart, Definitely, Maybe is that rare studio release that feels like it was written by a human being, not by committee.
In the end, In Bruges is a bit arch and artificial, but it is more than redeemed by Farrell and Gleeson's presence, and by the bushwhacking wit of the film's writer/director.
Moderately scary, moderately amusing, intermittently dull and obvious, Diary of the Dead is not groundbreaking, nor even ground-quaking.
There's lots to like.
So disturbing, on so many levels, that it's hard to know where to begin.
A celebration of the DIY aesthetic, and of the universal appeal of movies, Be Kind Rewind is a charmingly off-the-wall little tale.
Shot in a gritty, kinetic style that captures the colorful squalor of a neighborhood dubbed Dead-End Hill, City of Men is in many ways a more satisfying piece of storytelling than City of God.
Aimed at tweenage girls and mushy romantics of all age and stripe, Penelope has a quick gait and a nice comic tone.
[Director Haneke is] an adept manipulator who goes one better by calling attention to his manipulations, questioning them, and then, still, managing to freak us out in the coldest, cruelest ways.
This quiet, closed-in picture with its unsurprising twists and turns, lacks the steamy passion of its pulp roots.
Too much of Drillbit Taylor is the kind of formulaic free-for-all that does Wilson no good, nor anybody else.
It'd be nice if [Perry] took more time to think about lighting and staging a scene -- but hey, he really doesn't have to.
21 makes for some slick escapist fantasy. Even if, and because, the fantasy has its roots in something real.

Starting Out in the Evening is a 'small' movie. But in its keenly observed examination of strangers who become intimates -- and of family members who remain, in part, strangers -- it has big things to say.

The writing and the performances are such that as things go from bad (sad motel-room affairs) to worse (a 4-year-old gone missing), the film's characters get inside your skin, your soul. It's enough to make you want to cry.
The Dardennes' film offers a portrait of a fragile yet determined woman set on making a home for herself in the world, even as that world unravels before her eyes.
There are quotations from Machiavelli, brainiac chess stratagems, meditations on the ego and suicide, and some of the clunkiest gangland gab this side of a Martin Scorsese parody.
Sometimes it works brilliantly, other times (masked dancers gyrating on ocean waves -- ick!) you just want to run.
...The Hunting Party derives much of its tension from watching seemingly 'normal' people doing seriously insane stuff.
In the Shadow of the Moon is, quite simply, a revelation.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A Bronx tale full of jaw-dropping behavior and jaw-dropping hairdos.
Comes off like TV-movie sensationalism, sidetracked by distracting backstories and hard-to-swallow plot twists.
As a meditation on the vicissitudes of love, on the need for people to connect, and the struggles that come by both making and missing those connections, the movie is wading-pool deep.
A rich, beautifully detailed espionage thriller that captures the bygone days of Shanghai -- and 1940s Hollywood noirs' romantic evocations of same.

The Final Season is as corny as an Iowa farm field, but as the World Series rolls around, fans of the sport might want to check out this tried-and-true tale of overcoming adversity, beating the odds and banding together for a righteous cause.
The Power of Song shows this icon of 20th-century music to be a man of passion and principle, and a true American. An important figure, an important film.
movie_title: Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (2007)

movie_review_blurb: At times solid and suspenseful, at times dopily implausible and woefully familiar.
The central gimmick of the film remains just that -- a gimmick -- as genuine emotion gives way to shaggy-dog shtick.
Less a movie than an illustrated audiotape, Kurt Cobain: About a Son is nonetheless fascinating for what it reveals of its subject,
Casey's big brother has made a tough, taut mystery.
What are you going to do when your lead actress offers a performance that's as unlikable as the woman she's portraying?
The movie examines a life -- and a death -- without getting deep about it. The result is oddly exhilarating.
Mr. Untouchable is never dull.
Just terrible.
Lumet's film is a stunner.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a thought-provoking look at the world of abstract art, the relationship between a reporter and his/her subject, and the nature of parenting, prodigies, and "objective" storytelling.
It has enough buzzing wit and eye-popping animation to win over the kids -- and probably more than a few parents, too.
...Lions for Lambs is also stagy, and worse, dull.
An eerily quiet, bracingly bloody, and expertly laid-out adaptation of the Cormac McCarthy novel.
Zemeckis, who blazed trails mixing live-action with animation in Who Framed Roger Rabbit, blazes not even a footpath here.
Dizzyingly incoherent and subversively surreal, this sophomore effort from the man who made the great, strange Donnie Darko is certain to have its fans. I'm not going to be one of them.
DePalma's movie offers its own doctoring and processing, without delivering an ounce of real humanity -- good or bad -- in the bargain.

I'm Not There is at once experimental and mainstream: Haynes juggles the facts, plays fast and loose, but serves up images, and songs that are as much a part of the collective pop consciousness as anything the 20th century produced.
Makes a strong case that when it comes to military action, the American public has been deceived by presidents from Lyndon Johnson on down the line to the current occupant of the White House.
Quote not available.
Visually, The Golden Compass is dazzling, hopscotching from hallowed halls of academe to the Nordic tundra, from luxe manors to creepy, sci-fi-like facilities. The effects couldn't be better.
It's almost as if the filmmakers wanted to say something about isolation, and loneliness, in the urban environment. Almost.
For sheer audacity and adrenaline-fueled carnage, Shoot 'Em Up hits its target pretty much dead on.
Based on a Balzac story, Rivette's Duchess manages to be both old-fashioned in its settings and circumstances, and coolly modern in its view of thwarted passion and despair.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Despite Scorsese's efforts to pump up some drama -- the director, with his signature glasses and Groucho brows, gets huffy about not receiving a set list -- drama is sorely lacking. This is just a concert film.

The attention to detail -- always a Pixar hallmark -- is amazing, and Stanton and his crew incorporate surprising elements that mix vintage sci-fi with old musicals with a meta-cartoon rendering of the future.

Not just the story of one man's obsessive quest to find harmony on a plank of wood, Surfwise offers a cautionary tale about parenting, homeschooling (camper-schooling, actually), sibling rivalries and family sacrifice.
It can be done -- there are rich, sordid black comedies out there -- but Tolan doesn't quite pull it off.
For the uninitiated, I heartily recommend this free-associative, autobiographical gem.
Thanks to Smith, it's a story about movie stars -- and why the multiplex-going humankind needs to have them kicking around, too.

Gibney also wants to honor what it was that made Thompson a celebrity in the first place: his brilliant, blotto writing, and his ability to smell out the liars and the hypocrites and expose them for the feral beasts that they were.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A small, beautifully acted piece adapted from the British poet Blake Morrison's memoir.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: For all its eye-popping, Middle Earth-meets-Mos Eisley majesty -- its mix of Heironymus Bosch, Jules Verne and George Lucas -- Hellboy II is a letdown.
A terrific mystery, equal parts haunting love story and nimble thriller.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [A] quietly observant and quite beautiful adaptation of the Monica Ali novel.
Beauty in Trouble offers a meditation on the legacies of communism and the lure of capitalism, but also on the human need for love, connection and family.

Gloomy and serpentine, with a pointless chase sequence and a couple of big revelations about what Mulder and Scully have been up to on a personal level, The X-Files: I Want to Believe will make believers of no one who's not already a diehard X-phile.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Full of riffy, improvised moments and a couple of jaw-droppingly raunchy sight gags, the comedy follows a typical buddy-movie arc -- conflict and loathing giving way to bonding and brotherhood, or step-brotherhood in this case.
Achieves a level of unexpected power and poignancy.

Full of exclamatory one-liners ripped from a copy of Indiana Jones for Dummies, and with the breathless cast spewing putatively witty rejoinders that get drowned out by pows and bangs, Mummy 3 should have been kept under wraps.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A great story -- and a true one, more or less -- Bottle Shock nonetheless fails to deliver much in the way of entertainment.

The movie's too long -- and the violence and mayhem are unexpectedly harsh and heavy -- but Franco's inspired, looped performance is right up there in the annals of reefer filmdom with Jeff Bridges' the Dude in The Big Lebowski.
Even in the spookiest woods in the dead of night, there will be no difficulty figuring this one out.
While the territory is familiar, the terrain is new: Allen shoots his title city with an eye for its art and architecture.
Jack Black's fearless, foolish ferocity is missing.
Stealing America: Vote by Vote is sobering. The film suggests that come Nov. 4, the votes of Republicans, Democrats and independents alike might not be counted fair and square.
There's no quick fix for a culture 'addicted to debt,' as one wag puts it in the film. But watching I.O.U.S.A. is a good place to start.
A morally complex if plot-wobbly thriller set on the Trans-Siberian Express as it rockets (well, creaks and groans) through snowy forests and forgotten towns.
Quote not available.
Full of clunky humor, battle-of-the-sexes musings and spicy accordion music, Everybody Wants to Be Italian is relentless -- but not necessarily relentless fun.
A goofy screwball romp that affords a gaggle of A-listers the chance to hambone around in antic style.
The Grocer's Son offers a nicely observed portrait of a man in search of himself, finding his purpose, and finding that, in fact, it is possible to go home again.
movie_title: Le fils de l'épicier (The Grocer's Son) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: By the time the film's frantic, far-fetched climax comes along, Lakeview Terrace's pretense at exploring racial intolerance has been exposed for what it really is: a B-movie copout.
Ostensibly a comedy, but one in which the (normally) brilliantly funny Ricky Gervais is more dull than he is droll, Ghost Town takes a familiar formula and goes nowhere with it.
Wanted is an assaultive roller coaster of a movie that would be more fun if the violence weren't so nasty, and if the script made any sense.
If you have a hankering for old-style Hollywood comedy and romance, and Turner Classic Movies is on a Steve McQueen or John Wayne jag, Leatherheads offers an agreeable substitute.
The first part of what director Bodrov promises to be a trilogy tracing the life of the historic conqueror, Mongol is great cinema, great fun.
A very cool comedy based on character -- real, and really self-deluded characters -- and not on shtick.
A story that's too cute, too corny and too contrived.

In a Dream captures a family imploding. Their lives are laid bare, in broken bits, like the ceramic that Isaiah uses for his art, and they come together in In a Dream with sadness and beauty, rage and insight.

Much of the casting is dead-on, from Cedric the Entertainer as a street dealer to Jay Mohr as a slimy cop and Chris Evans as an earnest rookie who saddles up with Reeves' Ludlow for an ill-fated ride.
Reynolds is more than likable in the lead.
A dark, often funny Oedipal and erotic tale from Young Adam director David Mackenzie, Mister Foe benefits from the emotionally and physically agile performance of Bell.
Beautifully observed, and beautifully acted by the novice thespian Polanco (culled from a New York City public school), Chop Shop is at once a heartbreaker and a story of hope and the American Dream.
The Hong Kong director's efforts to transplant things to a distinctly American tableau fail. Prettily, but miserably.
A maddeningly mediocre, ineptly manipulative 'real-time' thriller. (A real-time thriller that's almost 20 minutes longer than its title suggests.)
There are two very fine performances here -- Wood's and Amurri's -- but they're not strong enough to rise above the metaphor-laden script.
Simultanously silly and sleep-inducing.

Offers a mix of nasty toilet jokes and sex gags, but the gratuitous nudity (male and female) and crazy cannabis-ness are there to serve a greater good: to mock social and political hypocrisy, a culture steeped in prejudice and pretense.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Made of Honor is the kind of formulaic fare -- there's even that turn-the-car-around-and-get-me-back-to-the-church moment -- that depends on the wit of the script and the spark of its stars. In those departments, the film is just middling.
Never Forever has the steaminess of pulp and the stateliness of art.
Speed Racer offers a crazy, turbo-charged mix of cartoon kitsch, gamer action, and a wild new way to think of -- and look at -- movies.
Redbelt's ultimate Ultimate Fight moment feels sorely lacking.

A tale of obsession and vigilantism cut with humor and a little Hegel, Henry Bean's Noise is a satisfyingly screwy New York story in which a successful businessman/family man jettisons all because he can't stand the cacophony on the street.
Before the Rains is never less than compelling, but never more than adequately realized.

The cast is uniformly attractive and earnest. But the romanticized image of the tortured artist is the stuff of stereotype unless it's leavened with humor, or limned in art. In Fugitive Pieces, neither element appears in sufficient quantity.
While the production values are top-notch, and the action artfully choreographed, in the end -- and quite well before the end -- a sense of tedium sets in.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A little piece of cinematic poetry.
No one is getting at anything in The Strangers, except the cheapest, ugliest kind of sadistic titillation.
Dazzling and delirious, The Fall is a celebration of cinema, of old-fashioned storytelling and globe-hopping spectacle.

Lacking in subtlety and nuance, Broomfield's nerve-jangling movie nonetheless succeeds in showing the war from various vantage points. And from wherever one's standing, the view is profoundly disturbing.

While its storyline might seem familiar (in fact, very familiar if you've seen the recent live-action Jackie Chan/Jet Li hit, The Forbidden Kingdom), there's enough invention and irreverence to make the film feel fresh.
A quick and nasty social satire that comes with the 'inspired by a true story' avowal, Stuck melds horror and humor as it offers a literally lacerating portrait of humankind at its worst.
The final installment of filmmaker Argento's Three Mothers series, this rollicking scarefest boasts roving bands of leggy witches, blundering priests, and voices from Beyond.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Drawing inspiration from the young-artists-in-angst tales of Godard, Truffaut and the French new wave, Joachim Trier's Reprise is both a charming homage and a vibrant work in its own right.
Alas, The Incredible Hulk is no Iron Man, and a brief appearance by a devilishly goateed Tony Stark only serves to remind us of that fact.
The Promotion uses the structure of a workplace comedy to pose gentle moral and ethical questions about treating people right (or wrong), about honor and ambition, truth-telling and back-stabbing.
In reality, The Love Guru isn't likely to offend anyone -- save, perhaps, audiences that prefer their comedy sophisticated, not sophomoric, and devoid of references to bodily functions.
The film doesn't hold together in any compelling way.
What ensues are much blood-splattering, mass drug-induced bowel evacuations, and none-too-funny commentary on the cultural distinctions between Americans and Brits.
Engagingly odd and full of sad, funny moments.
A long way from high art. Or even high schlock.
Takes a clunky TV-movie approach to detailing a chapter in the life of the celebrated Irish playwright, poet and drinker.
Simple, poignant and leavened with humor, it's a film that affirms the nourishing aspects of love and companionship.
Despite some fine, nuanced acting, Unfaithful doesn't get much deeper than a romance novel.
A quiet, disquieting triumph.
Every so often a movie comes along that confirms one's worse fears about civilization as we know it. The New Guy is one of them.
This thing will have your mind glazed over faster than a glob of dough in a Krispy Kreme plant.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Fans of the Hornby book should be pleased by the Weitzes' smart, faithful translation.
Director D. J. Caruso brings a visual flair to the proceedings, and Tony Gayton ... shows a deft appreciation of the genre, as The Salton Sea twists, turns and twists again.
A cartoon that's truly cinematic in scope, and a story that's compelling and heartfelt -- even if the heart belongs to a big, four-legged herbivore.
The film is flat.
Code Unknown gets at the ache and angst of the human condition in ways that shiver with telling detail and the machinations of real life. It's powerful.
movie_title: Code Unknown (Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Displays the disarming nutball sensibility of a Naked Gun farce and the dead-on social satire of an on-its-game Saturday Night Live sketch.
Salles ... has crafted a compelling existential tableau.
While Wang Xiaoshuai's film doesn't plumb the depths, nor resonate with the kind of profound irony of Vittoria De Sica's 1947 classic, it is nonetheless an affecting, poignant drama.
It's a wise and endearing little film.
Rohmer pulls off a wonderful feat: celebrating the elegance, and artifice, of another era at the same time he brings this tale of social upheaval boldly into the present.
Tunney, brimming with coltish, neurotic energy, holds the screen like a true star.
Hawke's actors are a talented troupe, and even when things get self-indulgent and fuzzy-headed (and boy, do they!), interesting stuff is going on.
The Bourne Identity has all the necessary components of the genre, and deploys them well.
A picture that extols the virtues of comradeship and community in a spunky, spirited fashion.

While the film, deftly imagined by screenwriters Scott Frank and Jon Cohen, doesn't entirely hold together, its dark, twisty chases and tricky puzzles have much more going for them than Spielberg's last foray onto similar turf.
A fine, inventive '70s period piece about friendship, first love, and growing up to face the hard lessons of life.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Although Huppert's intensity and focus has a raw exhilaration about it, The Piano Teacher is anything but fun.
Both a thrilling adventure about endurance and survival, and an elegiac examination of centuries-old tribal culture, fast-fading in the new millennium.
Rings true for the most part, and explores human nature -- leashed and unleashed -- in ways that resonate.
A plucky parable about mastering one's fears, and making connections.
Directed by Rob Bowman in a palette of dark, muddy colors, Reign of Fire is often incomprehensible and hardly ever entertaining -- even unintentionally.
A witty, whimsical feature debut.
Despite some jaunty performances and its pretty Cotswolds locale, the film, in the end, is hardly a pleasure at all.
The picture uses humor and a heartfelt conviction to tell a story about discovering your destination in life, but also acknowledging the places, and the people, from whence you came.
An engaging mix of musical, melodrama and goofball-fantasy.
Its somber ruminations on passion and desire, marriage and aloneness, resonate with unmistakable force.
Creepy and compelling and beautifully shot.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A psychological thriller that emphasizes the psychology over the thrills. It's a smart, heart-twisting picture.
Noteworthy solely for its thuddingly crude humor.
By the end, you just don't care whether that cold-hearted snake Petrovich (that would be Reno) gets his comeuppance. Just bring on the Battle Bots, please!
A harmless and mildly amusing family comedy.
A candid, compelling documentary.
This is an A-list cast toiling on a C-list screenplay ... and working for a director whose agenda -- and propagandist tactics -- get the better of him.
This dubious product of a college-spawned (Colgate U.) comedy ensemble known as Broken Lizard plays like a mix of Cheech and Chong and CHiPs.
As thrillers go, this one, with a peskily insistent score, weepy-timbred voice-overs, and telegraphed 'twist' ending, is mighty unthrilling.
Moretti doesn't wrap the grieving, the angst, in melodrama. The facts are given. And the suffering is palpable.
movie_title: La Stanza del Figlio (The Son's Room) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: It's no surprise that Jan Svankmajer's Little Otik is dark, strange stuff.
Pearl Harbor without the product placements, without the Hollywood bombast, and certainly without the $100-million-plus budget.
[E]ntertaining though hardly profound...
MacDowell, whose wifty Southern charm has anchored lighter affairs ... brings an absolutely riveting conviction to her role.
A likably energetic star vehicle for English sports god Vinnie Jones.
Showtime's complete lack of originality oozes off the screen like, um, rancid popcorn butter.
It's a charmer.
Compelling, kinetic, fast and furious.
It's hard not to get caught up in this improbable but true follow-your-dream tale.
Works the basics with style and intelligence.
Brims with passion: for words, for its eccentric, accident-prone characters, and for the crazy things that keep people going in this crazy life.
A mild but engaging romance, the charms of which come at you sideways.
Hey, big surprise: Ron Jeremy craves attention. That's the revelation in Porn Star: The Legend of Ron Jeremy.
movie_title: Porn Star: The Legend of Ron Jeremy (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Death to Smoochy has some of the same determinedly twisted, tumbleweed energy as [DeVito's] The War of the Roses and Throw Mama From the Train. What it lacks, though, is real wit.
More trouble than it's worth.
High Crimes fits comfortably into the conventions of the genre, but Franklin seems happy to be working with them, not against them.
A meditation on faith and madness, Frailty is blood-curdling stuff.
The ads for The Sweetest Thing promise that if you loved There's Something About Mary and My Best Friend's Wedding, then you can't miss this latest Cameron Diaz vehicle. Well, miss it.
The movie's combination of unabashedly fun carnage, cool special effects, and tongue-in-cheek dialogue keeps the ball rolling.
A chick movie? Well, yes, but it's a whole lot cooler than that one with the Ya-Ya's in the title.
Sad and wry, deftly acted, and ultimately moving.
A sharp, inventive mix of love story and film noir.
Sly, sophisticated and surprising.
Has the disjointed feel of a bunch of strung-together TV episodes.
Maybe all the pieces of a truly good film noir are here, but the filmmaker has opted simply to toss them into the air and let them fall where they may.
8 Mile should satisfy Eminem's legion of fans and, at the same time, affirms rap's power as an artform, as real beat poetry, for the uninitiated -- and even for the actively resistant.
Darker, scarier and somewhat better than Sorcerer's Stone.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The deep, dark sadness of Haynes' movie casts a beautiful, powerful spell.
What a mess.
Prefab and formulaic all the way.
Sci-fi meets sea-faring fantasy, and the mix isn't half bad.
They has a low-budget, generic feel -- but also enough sense to know that unseen menace is a lot creepier than explicit gore.
A tad more character development would have been nice.
Ultimately just one more urban gangland genre flick.
This unabashedly stupid comedy is, well, unabashedly stupid.
The Weight of Water uses water as a metaphor for subconscious desire, but this leaky script barely stays afloat.
A quiet, heart-rending masterpiece, one with an actor's turn that people will remember, and rediscover, eons into the future.
Evelyn's strong cast and surehanded direction make for a winning, heartwarming yarn.
An elaborately worked-over opus that's as tarted-up and artificial as Scorsese's '70s classic Mean Streets was gritty and real.
An amazing story, amazingly told.
Fleet-footed and fun, if a mite too long.
Deflated ending aside, there's much to recommend the film.

Manages more than a few laughs.
Stephen King without the snap, David Lynch without the kink, teen horror without the teen hormones, Darkness Falls falls apart in a crescendo of creepy-crawly hoo-ha.

Jeong-Hyang Lee's film is deceptively simple, deeply satisfying.
At turns heartbreaking and heart-stirring.

The action is so rivetingly orchestrated, the crazed chaos of it so palpable, that the movie sucks you in.

Sometimes this modest little number clicks, and sometimes it doesn't.
A romantic comedy for anyone in love with the movies, and anyone, for that matter, who's in love.
Unlike the lumbering and portentous Unbreakable, Shyamalan's Signs is a satisfyingly taut suspenser.
Cruelly and brutally unfunny.
It's got the brawn, but not the brains.
A sturdy, suspenseful throwback.
A small, smart indie pic with a twisted sensibility.

A bad French Lieutenant's Woman-like romance.
[Stockwell] captures the rush and glory, and the total tidal awesomeness of the sport.
Gedeck is simply terrific in the title role.
The Chateau belongs to Rudd, whose portrait of a therapy-dependent flakeball spouting French malapropisms ... is a nonstop hoot.
Simone, for all its flaws, offers an enjoyable look at the machinations of moviedom and fame.
A muscular, no-nonsense genre pic.
It has Williams -- memorably creepy, chillingly sad.
Muccino ... orchestrates the alternately comic and catastrophic goings-on with a maestro's touch.
The eye-popping design and sense of scale remains as fresh and vital as it was in 1927.

A stage-y but likable ensemble piece.
A prickly coming-of-age tale in which everybody -- but especially Culkin -- shines.
The film is not recommended for toddlers and easily frightened little tykes. But for everyone else, kid or grown-up, this thrilling foray into magical realms is a must.

A bracing, unblinking work that serves as a painful elegy and sobering cautionary tale.

Heaven is odd, and awkward in places, but its lyricism and power stay with you.
One of the strangest and most beguiling romantic comedies ever made.
Kinnear gives an amazing performance as the Hogan's Heroes star.
The perfect film for anyone who likes their headbutting and kickboxing dressed up in gold brocade, frilly collars, and tri-cornered caps.

A thoroughly acceptable sci-fi genre pic.
Still feels brand spanking new, and way cool.
At its best The Gift evokes some of the creepy chills of To Kill a Mockingbird. And at its heart, there's Blanchett, an actress whose instincts are unerring, and dead-on.
Never less than amusing.

A supernatural fantasy of a most pedestrian nature.

A charmer.

An amusing, compelling and technologically fascinating tale.
Wasn't one iota funnier when I regained consciousness than it was when I mercifully slipped out of it.
Just a big chunk of waste flushed from a Hollywood studio.
A spare and moving study of regret and redemption, marked with chilling truths about a life behind bars.
Emits an aura of contrived cool.

Smart, enjoyable.

movie_review_blurb: Several notches above the usual gay-themed indie.
A devastatingly funny portrait of a wildly dysfunctional clan.
In the end, you just feel good about these people, and that's a nice sensation these days.
Crowe and Connelly's work rises above the mush.
Despite its haunting artistry and its winning eccentricities, The Shipping News is a vehicle that's still very much at sea.
Borrows' Liam -- well, they found the right kid, without a doubt.
A massive compendium of youth-movie/ pedal-to-the-metal cliches.
A little European indie pic that digs down to the roots of its characters, describing people's lives and relationships in ways that resonate with clarity and heart.
Sweet-natured and goofy and funny in all the right places.
Affecting if sometimes overwrought.
Makes something like Save the Last Dance ... seem bogus and preachy by comparison.
More than an entertaining ethnographic study. It's human drama, high and mighty.
Boring, and decidedly misogynistic.
Doesn't lack for ideas, nor for images that will sweep you up in their boldness and have the resonance of dreams.
movie_title: Der Krieger und die Kaiserin (The Princess and the Warrior) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Doesn't add anything new to the stranger-in-a -strange-land action genre, but, like Li's intrepid hero, it gets the job done.
Is Final Fantasy decent sci-fi? Yes, more than decent.
A smart screwball comedy that upends the stereotype of the airhead towhead.
Nothing runs very deep, or very diverting ... in this overplayed, underwritten slice of (love-)life.
Favreau and Vaughn have chemistry to kill: comic, combative and engagingly goofball.
A mildly amusing mess.
Poignant, funny and clear-eyed about some tough topics: homophobia, racism, AIDS.
Birch and Johansson inhabit Zwigoff's film with deft assurance and subtle moves.
Inventive, original stuff.
Until it devolves into what seems like a quasi-surreal Fatal Attraction ... offers a stark, spooky portrait of family fracture and loss.
With the raunch quotient cranked up several notches, the sequel is calculated, cynical and, worse, not funny.
The film is beautiful to behold but lacking in any kind of palpable dread or suspense.
Goofy, outlandish and exhilarating.
movie_title: Time and Tide (Shun liu Ni liu) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Remains rooted in the real world, which makes its story all the more satisfying -- and chilling.
In a season dominated by effects-driven blockbusters, this old-style, lyrical love story should find its audience and then some.
With alarmingly few exceptions ... nothing that occurs can remotely be construed as humorous.
Johansson ... gets to the rebellious and thoughtful core of her character with a disarming ease.
Henstridge ... has neither the heft nor the acting chops to carry the film.
Predictable and slight.
Offers a thoughtful reading on adolescence pushed to the edge.
Summons every cliche of the rock world and then clings to the hoary scenarios with the fiercest gravity.
As filmed by Hyams (he directs! he cinematographs!), all the crazy, exhilarating ballet of the martial arts genre is lost in a murky blur of motion and the clang and thump of overdone sound effects.
Captures the volatility and chaos of a nation struggling to find its identity and purpose.
Monty Python and the Holy Grail still stands as a gloriously silly and twisted send-up.
movie_title: Monty Python and the Holy Grail (1975)

movie_review_blurb: A disturbing and provocative study of adolescence and isolation.
A wistful little thing about regret, jealousy and love.
Despite director Gary Hardwick's stock sitcom scenarios, LL Cool J, the rapper-turned-actor, does a great job as a leading man Lothario.
A weird, bubbly cocktail -- effervescent charm and troubling pathology, shaken together.
movie_title: He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkable picture, full of suspense and discovery.
Washington, Schreiber, Streep and company -- and Demme -- have managed to make all the malevolent machinations seem relevant again.
[Jamie Foxx is] the reason to see Collateral, as he walks into the frame and walks off with the picture.
Open Water is so deeply terrifying, so primal in its depiction of man at the mercy of nature, that watching it shakes you to the core.
As a modest conflation of mystery, melodrama and witty romance, Leconte's tale of intimacy and aloneness has its definite charms.
A crackling, claustrophobic chamber piece.
A fascinating, fly-on- the-wall (or fly-in-the- dining-car) glimpse of some clearly blotto rock legends talking, singing, hanging out.
A strangely flat and ploddingly formulaic mystery.
Anacondas is to its 1997 Jennifer Lopez-starring forerunner what Jaws: The Revenge was to Steven Spielberg's shark monster original.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: From beginning to end, Hero is a painting in motion, its fight scenes a ballet with blades.
A thinker and an educator, Zinn has led a life of commitment and compassion, and the film offers a loving tribute.
movie_title: Howard Zinn: You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Less a story of undying love and passion than a singularly focused lovefest. And it's a self-lovefest, really, no matter who the flower girl is.
The storytelling is slack and lackluster, the cliches rampant.
Makes the case that it is not just societal recognition that same-sex partners lack without the official decree of a marriage -- it is the legal rights that married couples share.

Cross Get Shorty with State and Main -- Hollywood hustlers, colorful crooks, crafty poseurs, and a production crew on location -- and you have the stuff of The Last Shot. One other thing: eliminate anything funny.
Catastrophically overdone.
It's got poetry to it -- the poetry of humanity.
An issues-based doc with a sense of humor. It's a bit flimsy, but you have to hand it to these guys: They're con artists with convictions.
As football movies go, it's a great one.
A corny, wading-pool- deep tale about overcoming grief and enjoying a rooftop view of downtown L.A. with a cute English guy with a hedgehog coif.
A brilliant little indie thriller.
Offers a fascinating chronicle of the birth, glory days and waning years of a motorcycle-jacketed, bowl-haircutted quartet of middle-class geeks who unwittingly spawned the punk movement.
movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Like Hitchcock, Kahn uses dry humor and keen observation of human character (and character flaws) to spin a compelling brand of menace.
A sobby road movie marked, and marred, by labored performances.
As an entryway into new ways of thinking about the self, the universe, and the vast infinite whatnot of whatever (you know what we mean, oh wise one), this little movie is big.
movie_title: What the Bleep Do We Know!? (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Estes' dark sunlit tale cuts like a knife.
It isn't frightening. Sometimes, in fact, it's laughable.
A small, unsettling thriller.
Screamingly funny.
Thanks to fine performances and a grounded script, the pieces of this intriguing little puzzle all manage to fit.
If things begin to go south for the actress careerwise, Berry can use Catwoman as an audition reel to land a part in a road company of Cats.

If the filmmakers show a bias (and they do), it doesn't negate their central argument: For better or worse, the trends of global capitalism have changed -- and continue to change -- society as we know it.
Both a spooky reverie about childhood and a slow-burning suspenser in which conspiracy and betrayal shake the foundations of a boy's life.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A thoroughly charming oddity. And, in the end, a moving one, too.
Overblown, hyperactive.
A fluid and often funny morality tale.
Laughably predictable and lamentably unfunny.
A murky thriller.
A forced and flaccid affair.
A poignant, death-tinged comedy.
These are tales from the heart -- pulsing to a high-tech beat.
It does make you wonder: about good intentions gone awry, about the mythologizing of the American Dream, about cultural chasms and the ways in which people are so similar, and so different.
A noisy, 19th-century fantasy adventure that goes nowhere.
To say that The Saddest Music in the World is not for everyone is to state the obvious. But who's to say whom it is not for? Not me.
movie_title: The Saddest Music in the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Things pick up with the latter pieces, which were shot independently of any ongoing Jarmusch production and consequently feel less like outtakes, afterthoughts.
Heartfelt and artfully shot.
Teems with illogical action, improbable coincidences.
Harry Potter and The Prisoner of Azkaban offers what neither of its predecessors, for all their wand-waving and witch-brooms, had: real magic.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A story full of gentle grace notes and keen-eyed observation, writer-director Julie Bertuccelli's first feature is at turns funny, sweet, sad, trenchant and telling.
