Powerful wartime drama.
An eye-opening, important film that examines the war in Iraq from both Arab and Western perspectives.
Bears no resemblance to the movie that spawned its namesake.
Isn't as funny, or as wicked, as it should be.
An uneven mix of comedy and pathos.
Classy but ultimately unsatisfying.
Jesse and Celine come to life again in ways that are sad and beautiful, funny and profound.
A pumped-up, plotless montage of extraordinary landscapes, colorful wildlife, and interesting people performing feats of derring-do.
This Arthur is long and somber, broken up by crowded, clanging battle scenes that lack the visceral thrills of, say, Braveheart.
Apart from the somewhat novel conceit of turning Dickens into the stuff of a Gus Van Sant picture (see My Own Private Idaho), there's nothing original, nor compelling, about Twist.
An engagingly knuckleheaded comic vehicle for former Saturday Night Live trouper Will Ferrell.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Director Williams' tale never quite finds its footing.
Birth makes its oddball supernaturalism seem completely, compellingly real.
It's a shame about Ray, because Foxx is trapped in a movie that takes the music icon's unique story and turns it into cheesy, sentimental American Dream cliches.
The movie feels creaky and anachronistic.
Tinged with nostalgia and flooded with narcissism, this isn't easy to watch. But Caouette's fractured history is imbued with heart-crushing sincerity.
The filmmakers' mix of history and conjecture doesn't add up to anything more than reenactment.
It rings true at heart.
Has the feel of a coming-of-age novel.
Simply put: There's not much trenchant pathos in the former, while the guffaws are far between in the latter.

The film's strength -- and its weakness -- is in its you-are-there view of guys who are e-mailing their loved ones back home one minute and breaking down the doors of Iraqi homes the next, on the hunt for the enemy.
Hrebejk wrings real poignancy out of the screenplay's wet rag of fateful coincidences and ill-fated relationships.
movie_title: Up and Down (Horem Pádem) (Loop the Loop) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A compelling thriller that manages to incorporate a seemingly impossible bundle of disparate elements -- Jewish-Arab animosity, homophobia, the haunting aftershocks of the Holocaust, and the repercussions of suicide.
Steamboy, ultimately, shares deep-seated themes with the futuristic Akira. Both offer cautionary tales about scientific responsibility and the evils of war. And both look pretty cool, too.
The loose, lively spirit of the performances breathes life into the cliches.
Leaves you feeling rich -- and richly satisfied.

At times, it works brilliantly, bringing the fanatic (and mostly male) world of baseball geekdom into collision with the planet where women strive for career success and true love, usually with painful disappointment in one department or the other.
This richly produced tale of the last years of the famous 19th-century conqueror has a certain captivating quality about it.
Pulses with nasty thugs, cold-blooded crime lords, drug traffickers, blond seductresses, and a thumping suspense that can lead to head-cracking violence.

Miike, whose work usually veers into more surreal, experimental terrain, uses creepy-crawly juxtaposition, grisly violence, and dark humor to create a nightmare scenario for the text-message generation.
Far Side of the Moon imbues the weightiest issues of human existence with a zero-gravity grace and charm.
A comedy about a guy kicking a drug habit and struggling to reenter society, Astronauts, from Spanish director Santi Amodeo, is also a sweet, offbeat buddy flick.
The movie's sense of menace diminishes, instead of mounts, with each new break-in, booby trap and corpse.

The best thing about In the Realms of the Unreal are the sequences in which Darger's drawings, of epic battles and pigtailed heroines, are gently animated -- the pictures brought to life with subtle, fluttering motion.
movie_title: In the Realms of the Unreal (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Lost in a time warp of its own doing (or non-doing), Hitchhiker's Guide just doesn't seem terribly original.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: While the Argentine filmmaker takes his time, his film isn't tedious.
Like that nerve-rattling collision of metal and glass, Crash will leave its audiences jarred awake, feeling bruised.
It's not an indictment, so much. It's more like a mirror.
movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A loving, dopey documentary about the bird man of a place with a view of Alcatraz.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's title, I guess, alludes to the student profilers' ability to put themselves in the mind-set of a murderer. In this witless exercise, however, Mindhunters more accurately suggests that all parties concerned have lost theirs.
Bittersweet and sophisticated.

Kicking & Screaming is yet another low-budget, high-concept vehicle for Will Ferrell to say and do dumb stuff, throw hissy-fits, get punched in the face, and find redemption (as both a dad and a son).
Lucas still can't write. His dialogue crashes and burns like an X-wing zapped out of the sky by a star destroyer.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A crowd-pleaser of immense proportions.
While teens and adults can do worse than Madagascar (anyone for Kingdom of Heaven?), this slight and amusing 'toon is mostly a trip designed for the kiddie crowd to take in.
Offers a sometimes lyrical, sometimes gut-turning portrait of war seen through the eyes of children.
The performances are uniformly strong.
It's transporting, it's magical.
Represents the mind-numbing antithesis of cool.
Visually, taking its cues (mostly) from Van Allsburg's Hopperesque art, The Polar Express is eye-popping. Storywise, however, it can be eyelid-drooping.
After the Sunset is the kind of glossy, Hollywood-forged waste of time that would depress even the most happily lackadaisical retiree.
Cute, cloying and catastrophically predictable.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Neeson, in soft, subtle ways, draws out his character's humanity -- and shows the passion that drove the man.
Twee is one of those distinctly English words. It's used to describe something flowery, fey, hopelessly lightweight. It can also be applied -- quite nicely, thank you -- to Finding Neverland.
Avoid this lump o' coal.
Portman, well, she shines. It's a performance that really does mark her entrance into movie adulthood.
Offers a cheap (relatively speaking -- ticket prices aren't what they used to be), stress-free, vicarious vacation.
A Very Long Engagement probably has too many elements -- and too many characters -- for its own good. But its heart, like its heroine's, is in the right place.
It's action opera, sword-and-sorcery song-and-dance, and it's a heart-pumping, jaw-dropping thrill.
For the most part, the film stays steady-on, celebrating one man's crusade -- and one family's heartbreak.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The Life Aquatic is full of moments of strange tranquility and screwball juxtaposition.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The film never gives you a real sense of what drove Darin on.
Has a relatively quiet pulse for a spooky, supernatural thriller.
The new picture takes its time, gives its actors room to breathe, and isn't afraid to strike a hokey note if it reveals something important. Real life, after all, is full of hokiness.
Kill Bill without irony, and without Quentin Tarantino's flair for cool dialogue and chop-socky action (and without Uma Thurman, for that matter).
Bacon's portrait chills to the bone.
A studiously cheesy remake of John Carpenter's 1976 cult fave shoot-'em-up.
Has neither the freaky electricity of Taxi Driver nor the gloomy resonance of Death of a Salesman.
The movie's main purpose seems to be to make audiences squirm uncomfortably. Yelp and shriek in armchair-clawing glee? Not likely.
The choral numbers, many with lyrics written by Barratier (a classically trained guitarist), are lovely.
Despite all its roiling melodrama, Head-On has its moments of sharply observed humor.
A creaky, cliched, feel-good family drama about learning to stop and smell the roses - and planting a vegetable garden while you're at it -- Uncle Nino is shameless, sappy fare.
Offers a diverting tale of erstwhile indie filmmaking and the power of porn to generate change -- both at the box office and in the bedroom.
A smart, funny tale of thwarted dreams and impossible humiliation.
This supernatural, super-noir thriller has been shot beautifully (by Philippe Rousselot), and directed with enjoyable, crazy-angled aplomb by Francis Lawrence.
Curdled gobs of antic shtick.
It addresses the essential human need for dignity, for freedom, for mastery over one's life.
Beautifully filmed, and devoid of the kind of patronizing beneficence that First Worlders often bring to the Third World.
It's a quietly powerful work, pulsing with gentle humor and a gripping sense of imminent calamity and dread.
Kill Bill is silly stuff -- but it's transcendental silliness.
At once hugely entertaining -- and hugely scary.
The ensemble cast, asked to improvise its roles, interacts with conviction and chemistry.
A love song to the new Europe ... and a snapshot of a polyglot gang on the cusp of kind-of- reckless youth and responsibility- burdened adulthood.
As prequels go, Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd is right up there with Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace -- long, lumbering and endlessly unfunny.
movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: [Chen] gets realistic and affecting performances from his cast.
A beautiful, grim tale.
Director de Villa captures the rhythms and colors, the sounds and flavor of the neighborhood that gives this movie its name.
A slo-mo gem of gangster cool.
A subzero saga where dysfunction and distress -- and large quantities of herring -- rule.
A movie that has no language barrier and even functions as a satisfying whodunit.
Deftly directed by Danny Boyle and scripted by novelist Alex Garland, 28 Days Later is seat-squirming, hands-over-the-eyes stuff.
Gleefully airheaded and slick.
Terminator 3 moves at not-quite-breakneck speed, and the shape-shifting, metal-melting special effects aren't exactly spectacular.
In the end the film is undone by an overload of cliches, and by a gravity that never lets up.
Rampling and Sagnier are very good in roles that demand very different things of them, and Ozon's mix of peril and playfulness make for a seductive cinematic diversion.
Despite some awesomely choreographed stunts and the two stars' pedal-to -the-metal appeal, the movie seems endless.
Owning Mahowny is an unflashy but fascinating meditation on addiction and greed.
Both Tomb Raiders suffer from rampant action-adventure cliches and the sort of lumbering dialogue that harks back to the Saturday morning serials of yore.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Spy Kids 3-D is kind of exhausting, and the many-tiered virtual reality universe numbs the mind after a while. But Rodriguez manages to work in some nicely cornball messages.
There's ... something flat and labored about the whole affair.
A torpid dud starring the cuddly celebrity twosome of the moment.
As a celebration of a figure who fashioned his own identity from pieces of pop culture and street poetry, from song and fashion and fury, it's memorable.
Manages, despite its middle-aged male-fantasy scenario, to steer clear of the predictable -- or, at the very least, give the predictable some real human dimension.
S.W.A.T. is by the numbers, by the book, and, by the way, pretty good.
Boasts a noirish script and a top-drawer cast.
As tooting-your -own-horn documentaries about innovative alt-rockers who've been around for 20 years go, Gigantic: A Tale of Two Johns goes very well indeed.
A tediously ghastly genre pic.
An awesome compendium of cowboy-movie cliches. It borders on parody, and often crosses the border, rustling up a drove of oater aphorisms.
The performances from Rehany and Semel resonate, and the depiction of a community, and a country, where conflict and comradeship collide in unexpected ways, is deeply revealing.
As cartoonish as live action gets.
As putatively quirky coming-of-age movies go, this one feels factory-tooled -- and fake.
The Italian Job zooms along with confidence, smarts, and some of the coolest car chases this side of the Indy 500.
An unsatisfying mix.
Formulaic and unnecessary.
A dour-faced but sublime comedy.
After sundry Batmans and last summer's Spider-Man, the comic-book formula of childhood loss, filial revenge, and freakish physical prowess doesn't seem all that fresh anymore.
Suspenseful but overworked death penalty thriller.
While much of the action rings true in Dark Blue, and the events leading up to the riots make for a tense, eerie framework, the movie heads in a disastrous direction ...

One hopes that some day Gilliam gets to realize his dream, but in the meantime, in Lost In La Mancha, the shards of that dream offer tantalizing -- and tear-inducing -- glimpses of what might have been.
Bier knows what she's doing, and the performances are expert and affecting.

Tears of the Sun has a title that makes no sense whatsoever. The film's message, on the other hand, makes too much sense -- it's simplistic and reactionary and designed to get hearts pumping but not minds thinking.
The Hunted isn't exactly fraught with psychological depth and nuance, but as a stalker-stalkee suspenser, the pic has some nice things going for it.
Excruciating exercise in voyeurism, provocation and pretentiousness.
This low-key affair is graced with fine performances and a decidedly grown-up view of the world.
A piddling exercise in which our heroine must decide between her literally lofty ambitions and her hunky sweetheart.
The elements don't hang together, but Kasdan delivers real scares, and real hoots, in the midst of the mayhem and madness.
The Core is unabashed Hollywood spectacle, but with a cast of up-from-indie actors that makes the cataclysmic kitsch all the more fun to behold.
Spun is slummishly stylish, occasionally funny, and pretty much devoid of meaning.
A smartly acted, achingly simple love story.
A wonderfully crafted, smartly acted study of a complex old coot.
Diesel doesn't have the chops, or the charisma, to overcome the pic's formula conceits.
A deft, delightful mix of sulky teen drama and overcoming-obstacles sports-movie triumph.
It's mindless.
Blurry, opiated, jagged with melancholy and stone cold beautiful.
Even with its deft parade of dressed-up actors, real human emotion is hard to find.
[Kennedy] has a pretty good I'm-lame -but-I-believe -in-myself shtick going there. However, it doesn't last nearly as long as Malibu's Most Wanted's running time.
With none of the smarmy voyeurism that taints Larry Clark's teen exposes, Better Luck Tomorrow manages to get at the truths and the traps of a high-strung segment of today's youth.
Filmmaker James -- whose wife is a social worker -- should be applauded for his courage and commitment.
An effectively scary, psychological variation on Agatha Christie's And Then There Were None.
Although the script, by Chick (a Sarah Lawrence alumnus), can be painfully old hat, this little indie's cast goes a long way toward making the story interesting, even compelling.
The special effects have definitely improved.
An elegant and intelligent drama.

LaBute's lacerating take on the battle of the sexes, on the betrayals and debasements littering the field like bloody corpses, isn't for everyone. But for the rubberneckers and masochists among us, The Shape of Things is hard to beat.
Goes a good way toward reinvigorating a forgotten genre, fashioning a movie world that's not quite real, but not strewn with slam-bam car chases and meaningless intrigue, either.
A beautifully deft, witty character study.
movie_title: The Man on the Train (L'homme du train) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: With lines that feel like long soliloquies -- even as they are being framed in conversation -- Max is static, stilted.
This impressively icky, witty scare pic from director Eli Roth combines the hillbilly-country horror of the first Blair Witch Project with the viral decimation and paranoia of 28 Days Later.
A woefully thin and pointless musical comedy.
A virtual ricochet-fest of eyeball action. Those looks, those glares, those gapes, those gawks!
Win a Date is easy to like, and easy to forget.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Profoundly knuckleheaded.
To Be and to Have is a movie every teacher should see, and every parent, too.
movie_title: To Be and to Have (Etre et Avoir) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: While Wilson and his partners in crime make for a pretty impressive cast, the movie doesn't hang together. In fact, it practically falls off the screen in shards.
On one level -- an important one -- Brooks' picture, erotically charged and haunting, is about the way people connect, and change each other, profoundly.
Quote not available.
Triplets of Belleville conjures up a world that's totally surprising and sublime.
It neither adores nor disapproves of its players, which leaves the moviegoer a little clueless, and unmoved.
A riotously awful biopic rife with stereotypes and boxing movie cliches.
Like the guests who party hardy on Pleasure Island -- a Caribbean resort lorded over by a brain-fried Jimmy Buffett-type -- the writers must have been too blotto to bother with, like, jokes.
A generic, high-end Hollywood whodunit with a school of red herrings swimming through a plot that has more holes than a gopher farm.
Schematic, didactic, and most of all, in the case of Keitel, woefully miscast.
Heartbreaking stuff.
A sobering examination of a land in turmoil and a people that have faced what former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations Jeanne Kirkpatrick cites as 20 years of ethnic cleansing.
movie_title: Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Magnificent moviemaking.
movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining foray into a world of spy guys, stakeouts and secret government machinations, Spartan teems with the kind of terse crypto-speak that is the playwright and filmmaker's stock-in-trade.
Bloody, bone-chilling fun.
If Taking Lives starts off with a modicum of wit and creepy-crawly scares, it winds up somewhere else altogether.
It's a trippy but tender examination of human emotions, relationships, all-consuming love.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A mesmerizing, and devastating, story.
A hackneyed tale of vengeance set in the 'hood, teeming with stock characters, slo-mo gunplay, and rampant misogyny.
Tender but never sappy, Monsieur Ibrahim brings two people of vastly different age and background together in ways that are touching, and telling.
movie_title: Monsieur Ibrahim et les fleurs du Coran (Monsieur Ibrahim) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A deft balance of wistful family drama and drollery.
Smith's story is like a nightmare amalgam of decades of single-dad sitcoms: mawkish, cloying, and essentially bogus.
Faithful to its pulp roots and lacking the cumbersome self-seriousness of many a comic-book adaptation, Hellboy is, well, hellacious good fun.
A fairly flat, predictable tale.
Where the first pic breezed along with gags and gunplay, this forced follow-up is artificial to the hilt -- fueled on a kind of trying-too-hard hilarity that makes even good actors look bad.
The strengths of Leland ... come from its performances.
Slight but occasionally riotous.

After a while, Once Upon a Time in Mexico starts having the same effect as one too many tequilas: the Hong Kong-style stunts, the goofy wisecracks, the foxy presence of Eva Mendes -- all of it becomes blurry and numbing.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Brings the horror stories of everyday life down to a recognizable level.
Challenges and provokes in unexpected ways.
If stiletto-heeled heroines outfoxing legions of dunderheaded males are what you're looking for, seek no more.
An entertaining history lesson.
As predictable as it is tedious.
A multilayered meditation on the fast-blurring lines between fantasy and reality, and the seductive troika of money, power and sex.
An engagingly screwball comic vehicle in which the actor and Tenacious D frontman goes through an inventory of heavy-metal moves and makes a mockery of them at the same time.
Mambo Italiano is likely to provoke the same urges in the movie house that poor Nino experiences after a dinner at the noisy Barberini compound -- an overwhelming desire to flee.
There are laughs here aplenty, and sexy, goofy, off-the-cuff charm.
Like the best sort of short story, The Station Agent captures lives in fleeting, but telling, moments.
The movie never adequately explains the inner conflicts that led its relentless-reporter heroine to die.
The real Radio, and the real coach deserve better.
For a movie about community and forgiveness, family and grace, Pieces of April is refreshingly unsappy.
Scary Movie 3 is a veritable time capsule of of-this-moment kitsch, schlock and bad taste. And it's funny, too.
A generally upbeat and engaging tale of friendship and understanding.
By no means a disaster, but neither is it the wholly satisfying, sexy suspenser that was Klute.
The sibling masterminds abandon all humor and most invention for a series of Mr. Wizard cosmic cliches.
Love Actually is just about impossible to dislike, even if you really, really want to.
An enjoyably goofy yuletide tale of a towering innocent with a serious sugar addiction.
A study in moviemaking that doesn't resonate beyond its subject matter.
Polley's performance is pitch-perfect, and that the world described herein -- glazed with humor as well as melancholy -- is devoid of phony sentiment.
There simply aren't enough laughs in this Christmas comedy -- it's more like a stocking stuffed with lumps of coal.
Easily the best western of 2003.
It's not just Hollywood convention that gets in the way of the story, it's the lack of depth, heft and heart at its core.
Stuck on You, despite its penchant for the crude and lewd, is gooey in ways that have nothing to do with bodily fluids.
With the likes of Nicholson, Keaton, Reeves and Peet -- and a fleeting, funny few minutes with McDormand -- Something's Gotta Give is never less than entertaining.
It's the drunk-guy- at-the-party syndrome: The only one truly entertained by the clown with the lamp shade on his head is the clown with the lamp shade on his head -- or folks similarly inebriated.
[The] trilogy is, by any measure, a crowning moment in cinema history ... So why is the final installment, less than awesome?
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Small-scale moviemaking about small-scale lives. But it's big in all the right ways.
Belongs with the likes of Impostor: a near-future tale of paranoia and suspense of disappointingly generic proportions.
Cold Mountain is the equivalent of comfort food: old-fashioned, earthy, satisfying.
Chasing Liberty boasts exceedingly high levels of improbability and an embarrassment of continuity and character shortfalls, but still has a certain bubbleheaded charm.
Tonally schizoid and rife with anachronisms (a David Bowie song on the sound track, out-of-era vernacular), Tarantino's Third Reich folly is utterly exasperating.
The Martian is stirring and powerful, boasting a commanding performance from Damon.
A clever existential comedy.
Under the Skin definitely gets under your skin.
A small, supremely satisfying film. Heck and you betcha, it is.
Swinton, her hair white and long and her eyes tired and kind, and Hiddleston, moody and resigned, are wonderful - delivering their lines with the dry sighs of a desert breeze.
Thank goodness for Leslie Mann.
Liza Johnson's nicely tuned, and turned, adaptation of the Alice Munro short story "Hateship, Friendship, Courtship, Loveship, Marriage."
A bracing salute to American gangster pics, with a jumpy European post-war uncertainty thrown in.
So why doesn't Heat, with its elaborately staged, tautly edited robberies, its killer cast, edgy score and elegant cinematography, offer more satisfaction? It's the script, stupid.

The literally in-your-face camera work can easily expose an actor's weaknesses, but, with the lens framed on Nicholson's bulldog visage, he lets loose with volcanic fury. His demagoguery and gung-ho self-righteousness are something to behold.
Garfield is mumbly and gangly as Peter, and unrecognizable as Spider-Man, suited-up head to toe with the dome-like corneas that allow neither glint nor gleam of the actor's eyes.
To call Blue Ruin a revenge thriller is to sell this barbed-wire-sharp and altogether surprising American indie short.
Decoding Annie Parker is a movie about resilience, about staring doom straight in the face - with a smile, with hope.
The mix of violence and laughs never gels, the rejoinders are snapless, the pace slack.
Released in 1,492 theaters on Friday, Christopher Columbus: The Discovery should be gone from most of them faster than you can hoist the mainsails and shiver your timbers.
If Teenage delivers a sweeping generalization or two (or three) ... Wolf's documentary makes up for it with footage that's just too good to be ignored.
Watching Byrne, Basinger and Pitt struggle to bring verisimilitude to this cockeyed business is painful. And watching the parade of ricocheting doodles is just headache-inducing.
Even if you dispute the facts, one thing is clear: As a nation, we are fat, and getting fatter.
Brings these themes to a dramatic head: romance and race, privilege and justice.
A man, a car, a hands-free mobile device. And it is extraordinary.
Something happens to François Ozon's people when they get near the water.
Edwards' expertise in the visual effects field manifests itself in the seamlessness of the computer-generated imagery, if not in its extraordinariness.
Though we don't get to know Steadman the man all that well (rough time at boarding school, and yes, he has a wife and a dog), we do get to know his art.
Jon Favreau's bouncy paean to the culinary arts wins you over in a stridently upbeat, crowd-pleasing way ...
It's hard getting past the benign "menace" of the gangs, the corny out-of-touchness of the parentals, the stodgy morality of it all.
Crowe's movie is like a great record album: the songs connect, and the people connect, too.
The Double doesn't get very deep, but it does get interesting.
Ambitious, even audacious, the movie's mix of action and for-devotees-only intrigue can overwhelm, but there are moments of sheer virtuosity, too ...
It's a little freaky to watch Phoenix go at it, a smooth-talking beguiler who suddenly turns stumblebum. But there's nothing freakish about Cotillard.
In the blood-red lipstick and midnight-black gown and cowl of her Sleeping Beauty antecedent, Jolie's Maleficent is magnificent.
The episodic flashbacks are cast in an unfunny Freudian light -- domineering mother, helpless hubby, the tragically withdrawn child. What a laugh riot!
Soon the worlds of technology and humanity collide - super-medicine, super-intelligence, super-ecosystems, super-confusing!
There's something flimsy and unformed at these characters' cores, something that no amount of jumpy close-ups, skittering sideways glances, and rainy music can make up for.
Kurt and Courtney is an entertaining swim through the muck of the rock underworld. But as journalism, it's an utterly sloppy piece of work.
Tim's Vermeer is film as forensics, bringing math and science to bear to solve an art-world mystery.
The Wind Rises has the sweep and majesty of a Technicolor Hollywood classic.
Revealing, if occasionally frustrating.

This is a movie about friendship, about foolhardy endeavors that get your adrenaline going and make you feel life buzzing in your toes. Written with wit and concision and remarkable confidence, Bottle Rocket is a joyride worth taking.
Mr. Peabody & Sherman has a cool, midcentury-modern look (dog and boy live in a populuxe Manhattan penthouse) and a voice cast that may not be A-list but fits the bill nicely.
Whatever you do, do not look inside the bag.
Stritch, in her trademark billowy white blouses and skinny black tights, or in bed, without makeup and without, sometimes, a lucid notion, reveals herself to be full of opposing emotions and desires.
You'd have to be a true carmudgeon (sorry) to want it to stop.

The Grand Budapest Hotel is by far the most headlong comedic affair in Anderson's canon. It's practically Marx Brothers-ian at moments. And Fiennes - who knew he was capable of such wicked, witty timing?!

There's a danger of overselling Anderson's sweet-hearted, loony little fantasy, but everything -- from the soundtrack of '60s Brit bands with their jangly anthems of angsty love to Robert Yeoman's slightly hyper-real photography -- fits perfectly.
With a couple of elaborate action set pieces and some trippy, dreamlike sequences when Tris' thoughts are on display, Divergent is sure-footed, suspenseful, and sequel-ready.
Nymphomaniac: Vol. I is intimate, in-your-face, and, mostly, enjoyably ridiculous.

"What do we live for?" is the question that pops up in The Lunchbox, a romance set in Mumbai. The film, a first feature from Ritesh Batra, aims to offer a meaningful answer: We live, ideally, for love.
A Lifetime Channel-like meditation on grief and moving on ...

Darren Aronofsky's Noah is the Old Testament on acid. It's the movie equivalent of Christian death metal. It's an antediluvian Lord of the Rings, fist-pumping, ferocious, apocalyptic, and wet - very wet.
A spooky enigma, more ponderous than provocative, more silly than suspenseful.
Not exactly a breezy getaway, the film visits the sites, and drops down on rougher terrain, too.
Ernest & Celestine is a genuine charmer for kids, and for the parental units tagging alongside.
The Lawnmower Man echoes Frankenstein and a zillion other noble-scientist-whose-experiment-goes-awry movies.
Check your cynicism at the door, and just revel in its enormity.

There's too much going on: the Marvel Universe stuff, the WikiLeaks-ish paranoia stuff, the video game-ish CG visual effects stuff, the epic John Woo-ish everybody-pointing-a-weapon-at-everybody-else face-off stuff.
Many films have examined from many vantages the Khmer Rouge's nightmare reign, notably Roland Joffé's 1985 Oscar winner The Killing Fields.
In the Blood is generic B-movie fare, bloody and, alas, increasingly dumb.
A long plod ...
The NFL gets a "special thanks" in the end credits. Maybe it should have been the other way around.
The kind of crime flick where the characters volley dialogue like furious ping-pong players, riffing with delight, their lines ripe with pulpy metaphor.

This world feels studied in its "authenticity": the rusted GMC pickup, the tumbledown shack, the boozy brothel, and angry Joe Ransom guttin' deer and tending to his own gunshot wounds with a grimace and a bottle of alcohol.
A dark piece of neorealism - and a searing indictment of Eastern Europe's newly moneyed classes ...
Finding Vivian Maier is a find in more ways than one.
This movie feels like it has a million jokes, and every single one arrives with a lethal thud.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's all very busy, and cute, and, um, French ...
A masterpiece.
L.A. Confidential isn't quite up there with Chinatown, but it's the closest thing to come down the Santa Monica Freeway in the last 23 years.
It's hard not to take delight in Michel Gondry and his whooshing, bendable universe.

The kind of cliched, misfit crimefighters-versus-demented villains scenario that Kevin Eastman and Peter Laird happily parodied when they came up with the original Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles comic books way back in the 1980s.

De Bont has assembled it with masterly precision. And Speed looks terrific. There are breathtaking aerial shots, mind-boggling stunts, and camera positioning that you just don't expect. It's a rocketing eyeful.
Noyce, working from an adaptation by screenwriters Michael Mitnick and Robert B. Weide, finds a compelling through-line ...
A frothy romantic comedy tinged with melancholy and yearning.
Why sit through this pimply excuse for pulp fiction? Why not read the real boys (Goodis, Cain, Thompson), or see the real films (Forget it, Jake. It's not Chinatown)?
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Are You Here lacks more than just the question mark that should go on its title. It lacks a point-of-view that makes sense, that feels central.
A delightful, oddball surprise.

Moretz has a nicely calibrated energy and intensity, and the teen romance ups-and-downs of Mia and Adam's relationship - are they really soul mates, or will he drop her when the right groupie shambles along? - feel authentically OMG-ish.
A friend, after seeing Jacob's Ladder, griped, "I wasn't afraid of dying -- until I saw this movie." Put that blurb in an ad and see who shows up at the multiplexes.

Brosnan ... slips back into his intel identity with seeming effortlessness. The watchfulness, the calm, the jujitsu moves, the walking-through-rooms-with-the gun-held-straight-out-in-front-of-you stuff.
The Trip to Italy doesn't feel entirely new, but there's comfort in familiarity, too.
A Summer's Tale is one of those movies where it looks like nothing is happening ...

If you're in the mood for some knuckleheaded comedy at the expense of -- in mad scientist Dr. Forrester's words -- "a stinky cinematic suppository called This Island Earth," then get thee to some place playing MST3K.

With his deliberate speech patterns and haunted, reptilian good looks, Dafoe is an almost nobly sad presence at the center of the film. There's something wonderfully calm about his performance, and it holds Light Sleeper together.
Never -- at least not since the first Mortal Kombat -- has tedium been so loud, so full of backward flips and flying fists to the kissers of centaurs from another realm.
In the end, this tale of lonely souls and soulless thugs - of money and morality - even feels kind of hopeful.
A film about learning, and changing, and learning to change.
Browning, staring down the camera and singing up a storm, brings buckets of soulfulness to a script that might not be terribly deep.
I don't know about you, but my eyes glaze like doughnuts when people start time-traveling, showing up in two places at once, or one place twice -- which is what happens here.
The movie toys with real emotions, with our emotions, in ways that are pat and writerly and button-pushing in the cheapest, cheesiest ways.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It has the steady pace of a police procedural, with a flawed but noble hero and the colorful lowlifes that populate any hard-boiled mystery scribe's world.
Kline's character is an alcoholic and not exactly lovable, but we come to empathize. Smith, the grande dame of British theater and film, is wickedly wry and quick.
Worth it for the talent on display, disappointing for what the talent has been given, or not given, to work with.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's bleak business, and as it hurries toward its explosive, expository conclusion, the film becomes nonsensical, too.
Benjamin captures Hendrix's nodding swagger, his effortless cool, and most important, his voice - going beyond mimicry into some other, spookier realm.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If audiences and star are so inclined, it's easy to see this premise and this character - a tough, taciturn gent burdened with regret and a very special skill set - going into Roman numerals.
It's a wonderful world, full of Rube Goldberg contraptions below and colorful Dickensian squalor and excess above.
It's a wondrous mix of the momentous and mundane, the profound and the perverse, with Cave blues-talking his way through the goofy juxtapositions, the darkness, and the light.
It's Radcliffe and Kazan, clinking their takeout coffees (well, there's no clink in cardboard, is there?) and radiating soulful desire and distress, that make What If more than just an iffy affair.
Stalingrad is long and operatic, but its message is simple enough: War is hell, but hell, it makes for good cinema.
[Gleeson] projects fierce intelligence, wit, gentleness, ruefulness, soulfulness.
The oversized terrapins are characteristically flip as they backflip through an unnecessarily muddled plot.
Ultimately, like La Femme Nikita, there may be less here than meets the eye. But what does meet the eye is pretty darn thrilling.
Woodley ... balances grace with gravity, wit with heart.
The whole thing begins to feel like a giant-screen videogame - with the gamer getting a little further, a little deeper, with each new push of the Start button.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Words and Pictures stars Clive Owen and Juliette Binoche - a matchup that makes you want to like Fred Schepisi's film, even when it becomes impossible to do so.
How can you not love this guy, this story?
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: [Moodysson] captures the crushing urgency and emotional craziness of youth. It's not blood that flows through these girls' veins, it's nitroglycerin.
Loved Local Hero? Charmed by Waking Ned Devine? Then go watch Local Hero and Waking Ned Devine.
Does the meta-acknowledgment that everyone's in it for the bucks give a purposefully dopey sequel more cred? ... You bet.
Let The Signal take you by surprise. And it will.
[A] loud, long and pointless spectacle.
Eastwood, directing his 33d film, adds some keen-eyed realism to the showbiz schmaltz.

There's a muted absurdist thread running through A Coffee in Berlin, and while Niko's quest for the titular brew devolves into a series of whimsical frustrations, the filmmaker's motives are more serious.
Third Person falls into a kind of fugue state. The lines between characters become blurred, their respective losses and heartbreaks dissolving into a melancholy vapor. Or vapidity. Take your pick.
Somebody call Austin Powers, quick!
Maybe that's the sad takeaway of Dawn of the Planet of the Apes: that peace is futile, conflict inevitable. No matter the species, we're all doomed.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Wickedly smart and wickedly playful, Roman Polanski's adaptation of David Ives' Tony-nominated Venus in Fur works on so many levels, it's almost dizzying.
Hey, it sounded good on paper.
I wish Wish I Was Here made me care more about this guy's woes, but there's a patness to the weepy scenarios. To the funny ones, too.
The folks behind Sex Tape did their homework. They just forgot the laughs.
None of this is remotely funny. It's actually kind of sad.

To spy, to lie, to seduce, to deceive, to try to do right, to destroy - that is the current that runs under everything in le Carré's fiction, and it courses through Hoffman's veins as Bachmann in A Most Wanted Man.
Is it dumb to say, "Wow?" I don't care. Wow.
Whatever the intent of the filmmakers, a story that hinges on existential despair requires at least a modicum of emotional credulity.
Happy Christmas examines, in its shambling way, the challenges facing dual-career couples as they become parents.
Very Good Girls has a breezy yet bittersweet, vaguely nostalgic vibe.
Mom and Dad Save the World, which was directed by Greg Beeman and has the straggly feel of an extended Saturday Night Live skit, boasts unusually inspired production design.
movie_title: Mom and Dad Save the World (1992)

movie_review_blurb: For all its visual delights, Magic in the Moonlight, the 44th feature written and directed by the admirably industrious Woody Allen, has to be one of his bigger duds.
A must-see for anyone concerned about the state of health care in this country. Which should be all of us.
It's pandemic time!
It would be curmudgeonly to count all the ways in which The Hundred-Foot Journey is unsurprising, unrealistic, unnecessary.
If a movie with suicide as a central theme can be deemed funny, then writer/director Craig Johnson has pulled it off, mixing heartache and humor and giving Wiig, especially, the opportunity to shine.
They have turned the Christ saga into cheese. As in cheesy.
Godfrey Reggio's Visitors is as much a Zen experience as it is a movie, although as the latter it can be quite astonishing, too - cinema that envelops and enthralls.
What it lacks is even an iota of originality.
This inspired nutball comedy is like its heroes on their mission: It just gets progressively more nuts, more blotto.
Directed with invention and insight by Zachary Heinzerling ...
A loping and lovely romance, steeped in tragedy, with a Texas twang.
It is about inspiration and beauty, of course - and Folch, as a vagabond who escaped from a Spanish refugee camp, is certainly inspiring and beautiful.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Director John Crowley trots his crew around London, working up a suitable amount of suspense. And paranoia.
Drinking Buddies walks a fine line between the mundane and the meaningful, but the actors walking it are top-notch.
This is a film about hurt and healing, isolation and fear, need and rage - and it's not just the motley, messed-up crew of 14- and 15-year-olds who are trying to cope, trying to get better.
Austenland begs a couple of questions: One is why, Keri Russell, why? The other: Where is Christopher Guest when you need him?
Wong Kar Wai is an expressionist master. A master of character - deep, rich, truthful character - especially in The Grandmaster, he is not.
[A] quietly fierce condemnation of fundamentalist Muslim society's treatment of women ...
Terraferma offers a sun-splashed meditation on compassion, tradition, tolerance, and generational change.
Thanks for Sharing is an odd film: The sex-addict business is treated with an uncommon level of detail and honesty.
The Butler is an inspiring and important summation of the black struggle.
Salinger is fascinating because Salinger was fascinating. But the film is frustrating, maddeningly so, because it is bent on trumpeting its own importance over that of its subject.
Not exactly an original idea. But Gordon-Levitt goes at it with gusto, and style. Give the guy some props.

Rush has an elemental simplicity about it. Two men in competition, driven (so to speak) to win. They are enemies. But they need each other, too, and as they roll around at 170 m.p.h., they come to understand why.
Reich is funny, poignant, passionate.
Enough Said is a romantic comedy about hurting the people you love, who you want to love - and making mistakes that may be impossible to recover from.
Feels like it could drag on forever, and drag us down into a purgatory of stupefaction with it.
A wildly suspenseful zero-g tale of survival 350 miles beyond the ozone layer, Alfonso Cuarón's space saga is emotionally jolting - and physically jolting, too.
Haute Cuisine is an epicurean dream where the dishes conjured up by the characters are as essential to the experience as the characters themselves.
Wadjda is a movie about freedom - and nothing represents freedom with the metaphoric simplicity and symmetry of a bicycle.
Parkland is history as existential despair.
Guillermo del Toro's feature debut is an arch twist on the vampire tale.
We watch these films and wonder about ourselves, about who we are, why we are here, what we would do.
It makes Baz Luhrmann's 1996 contempo update - the one with Claire Danes and Leonardo DiCaprio and the plus-sign in its title - look like some kind of masterpiece.
At once repetitive and puzzling. There is a lot of finger-pointing. Assertions are made, theories offered, but not much in the way of certainty.
Even when there's tragedy around the turn, it doesn't matter. Populaire plays like a musical - you expect anyone, at any time, to break into song.
The Spectacular Now captures the exhilaration and confusion, longing and dread of young romance with raw honesty and insight. Nothing rings false, nothing feels "cute."
It's an American success story of epic proportions, but Joshua Michael Stern's biopic of the Apple co-founder is hardly epic.
Cartoonishly violent, with blood spray, vomit spew, severed limbs, impaled torsos and more, Kick-Ass 2 has none of the punky flair of the Matthew Vaughn-directed original.
Man of Steel is just the same old same old.
[Riseborough's] work is indrawn and riveting. It's hard to read the look in her eye, but we never stop trying.
Its marshaling of the facts is one-sided, leaving many questions, and considerable scientific evidence, unexplored.
A relentless horror thriller that serves up a chilling vision of a planet in the throes of apocalypse ...
A comedy, of sorts, if what it says about our obsession with the famous and the frivolous weren't so totally depressing.
There's no fire, and where their lines should ricochet with wit, they just spill forth, affably.
Monsters University is cute, and funny, and the animation, though not exactly inspired, is certainly colorful.
Trainspotting, buoyed by a great Brit Pop soundtrack and Brian Tufano's agile cinematography, captures the stoned-out, gut-churning experience of hardcore addiction with hallucinogenic acuity.
What a mess.

A wild, wacky, wide-screen reimagining of the vintage radio serial and TV series, the film - with Armie Hammer in the hat and mask, galloping across Texas righting wrongs, and Depp as his trusty Indian sidekick, Tonto - is an epic good time.
Pacific Rim looks great. It's one of the rare 3-D features that probably delivers more in the large-screen, stereoscopic format - severed Kaiju limbs, comin' at ya!
Flat and mostly unsurprising.
Oscar Grant had friends, he had a sister and a mother and a grandmother, a girlfriend, a child. In concise measures, Fruitvale Station shows us these connections, these bonds.

Although The Wolverine eventually falls back on a comic-book formula and CG effects (the climactic face-off between Logan and a giant silver warriorlike thing is totally generic), Mangold and his team find time to explore more nuanced realms ...
Shot on the fly, while Silva, Cera & Co. were waiting to make another movie, Crystal Fairy ends up on a beach, and ends up resonating with a pesky charm.
A deadpan mock-documentary about an early-'80s gathering of programming nerds, arguing about AI and predictive algorithms and showing off questionable fashion choices and facial hair.
The Hunt offers a powerful, provocative study of mob mentality and the fabric of trust.
Thoroughly engaging, edge-of-the-seat entertainment.
The Wahlberg-Washington express hits lots of comfortably familiar notes. And more than a few viciously uncomfortable ones, too.
It is utterly chilling.
Eastwood deliberately upends the conventions of the western, subverting his own image in the process.
For all its fiery explosions, Face/Off just kind of implodes.
While it's sloppy and draggy in parts, Kevin Kline, in the title role, delivers an ingratiating comedic performance.
The cinematography and gravity-defying stunt performances are exhilarating. The story, alas, is pure routine.
Apart from looking like no other type of animated film, Chicken Run stands alone in its unwavering determination not to play down to the kiddies.
An innocuously smutty road comedy starring Jason Sudeikis and Jennifer Aniston.
Among the slew of recent futuristic hell-in-a-handbasket spectacles, Elysium takes the cake.
Blanchett is steady as she goes, delivering one of the most exhilarating performances of the year.

If Laurel and Hardy, wearing matching baggy overalls and similarly dumbstruck expressions, had starred in a screen version of Waiting for Godot, the results wouldn't be far afield from Prince Avalanche.

There is incredible tension in this ordeal, this effort to survive, to find rescue, and Redford - an icon of the American film experience for more than half a century now - makes that tension deeply palpable.
If you're going to take another stab at this tale of a taunted, traumatized teen who exacts fiery revenge on, well, everyone, then Kimberly Peirce is the director to do it.
The problem with director Bill Condon's fictionalized account of all this is that, like WikiLeaks itself, there's way too much data to sift through.
Watching Jenkins and O'Hara go at it (in more ways than one) is especially terrific fun.
A conventional biopic made anything but conventional by the magnitude of its subject's life and accomplishments, and by Idris Elba's imposing performance in the title role.

As thrilling a filmmaker as Martin Scorsese continues to be, and as wild a performance as Leonardo DiCaprio dishes up as its morally bankrupt master of the universe, The Wolf of Wall Street seems almost entirely unnecessary.

This isn't the meaningful movie it pretends to be. But as a goofy entertainment that speeds through the latter half of the 20th century, stopping here and there to snap a photo or two, Forrest Gump does just fine.
Her is a wistful, wonderful meditation on where we are and where we might be going.
It is Roberts who makes August: Osage County watchable, and more: As Barbara, the actress' wariness and weariness, her caustic humor - deployed to hide a deep sadness - all ring true.
A step-by-fateful-step study of human endurance, of desperation, of resolve, and resignation.
Too much of the action in Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit takes place on laptops, thumb drives, and video monitors.

Shot with a stillness that serves to reinforce the restlessness in its characters' souls, The Invisible Woman offers a fascinating view of a young woman whose eagerness and energy are slowly compromised ...

That's interesting stuff, but it doesn't play out with a lot of smarts. And the opportunity to end Ransom on a creepy note of unpredictability is forsaken for the usual glass-shattering, bullets-flying finale.
A thickly knotted and compelling tale, set in an unglamorous, working-class Paris, it churns with complex emotions, suspense, guilt, and regret.
It is a yarn. But it's so full of passion, poetry, and humor that it becomes, for the time, quite real.
See them all ... You won't be sorry.
Two great reasons to see The Oscar-Nominated Short Films 2014: Live Action - one dark and funny and wickedly existential, the other a nail-biter of a domestic drama, filled with dread.
movie_title: Oscar Nominated Live Action Short Films 2014 (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Gloria, spare and keenly observed, plays like a short story - there is no sweeping narrative arc, no momentous triumph or calamity.
Director Rob Meltzer, who made the kind-of-amusing meta short "I Am Stamos," directs things in shameless, let's-get-this-thing-over-with style ...
Alas, it's a throwback that's thrown its back out - limping along, trailed by battalions of stereotypes and ammo rounds of cliche.

Four Weddings and a Funeral is one of those rare films that have you smiling from the get-go, and keep you that way -- with a few well-earned poignant interludes (including, of all things, a reading of W.H. Auden) -- right to the end.
With their matching hipster goatees and deadpan cynicism, Affleck and Lee evince the easy rapport of old buds.
High Fidelity, with its knowing take on men, messed-up romance and music, is like one long, hook-filled pop song for the eyes.
Lee's Eat Drink Man Woman is tender without being mushy, sweet without being syrupy -- and surprising in ways that can only make you smile.
movie_title: Eat Drink Man Woman (Yin shi nan nu) (1994)

movie_review_blurb: In addition to Fiennes, who does a star-making job here, and the radiant Paltrow, Shakespeare in Love teems with wonderful performances.
RoboCop is a solid near-future action pic that poses moral questions about artificial intelligence and remote-control combat systems without getting too preachy or ponderous about it.
A jaw-dropping groanfest of teen romance cliches ...
If you've seen Hirokazu Koreeda's films - Nobody Knows, Still Life, I Wish - then just the announcement that a new one, Like Father, Like Son, has arrived is all you need to know.
Winter's Tale is the kind of really bad movie that may still be quite easy to like, or even love, if you abandon all senses ye who enter here.
Kids for Cash is no-nonsense, no-stone-unturned filmmaking.
Despite its able cast and handsome period costumes, In Secret is, in fact, quite awful.
Abu-Assad's tale is less a political thriller than it is a human story - although everything about its setting and circumstances is defined by oppression, surveillance, restriction, and control.
It's the modern dilemma: how to balance work with family, get the job done, and still have time to share a meal with the wife and kid.
A freewheeling, feel-good holiday movie.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Non-Stop gets increasingly far-fetched as the jet makes its way across the Atlantic.

American Hustle is a movie built on that cornerstone of the American Dream, reinvention. If you're not happy with who you are, or who people think you are, then go ahead and become somebody else. Anything to survive - and thrive.
Smart, delightful.
Butterfield brings lots of adolescent earnestness to his role, and Hailee Steinfeld is an affable sidekick.
This is a TV movie all the way, in the pre-HBO network shlock sense of the term.
Piecing the components together, and only sparingly deploying intertitle cards for clarity, Let the Fire Burn brings this 28-year-old tragedy front and center again - vividly, viscerally.

This three-hour portrait of a young French woman named Adèle (Adèle Exarchopoulos) captures the dizzying, all-consuming ardor of first love, the joyous discovery of bringing your body and mind into union with another human being.
A glorious romp of a martial-arts thwack-fest ...
How I Live Now manages to fuse a teen love story, steeped in alienation and hurt, with a near-future nightmare thriller.
Its monsters and angry armies and visual effects are interchangeable with Peter Jackson's Tolkien pics, with Clash of the Titans, with The Avengers, with Man of Steel, and on and on.
Kill Your Darlings is a tale of inspiration, then, but also a tale of jealousy, obsession, homophobia, and homicide. It's a whirlwind.
The Broken Circle Breakdown deftly juggles some heavy-duty themes: not just the crisis of cancer, parents faced with the possible loss of a child, but the eternal questions.
The Holocaust has never looked so beautiful.
Just about everything is right with Dallas Buyers Club, beginning with Matthew McConaughey's literally transformative portrayal.
There's underworld intrigue, and Bucharest gets to show itself off nicely.
James and the Giant Peach shines with weird, whimsical invention.
Bigger, better and broodier than the first film.

Essentially, The City of Lost Children is a macabre fairy tale, and while its tentacled comic-book plot and freak-show cast narrow its appeal -- this isn't a work of any allegorical depth -- Caro and Jeunet have pulled off a cinematic delight.
movie_title: The City of Lost Children (La Cité des Enfants Perdus) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: With its molelike inhabitants, its sprawling war between flesh-eaters and lentil-men, its achingly sweet love story and surrealist blend of dusty antiquities and 21st-century gizmos, Delicatessen is indescribably wild.
Delivery Man, with its democratic band of half-siblings and its feel-good view of humankind, is what it is: a reproductive remake that will make you laugh. More than once or twice.
The pain and hope and sense of loss are all there in Dern's eyes, in Woody's stolid willfulness, his shaky gait.
The Witches is a slow-to-get-going but ultimately entertaining yarn about a nasty coven conspiring to turn Britain's entire populace of single-digiters into mice.
Black Nativity offers a whopping serving of Yuletide emotion. And it's a musical - with plenty of wailing and rapping on the side.
Ryder rockets to such heights of emoting that she looks like she could black out from lack of oxygen.
A true story that takes unexpected, unusually poignant turns.
The Armstrong Lie is eye-opening and myth-shattering and more than a little depressing.
Compared to While You Were Sleeping, even the half-baked scenario of the Marisa Tomei-Robert Downey Jr. romance Only You looks witty and inventive.

Although Out of the Furnace takes place just a few years back in this new millennium, Scott Cooper's solemn, blood-soaked drama about brothers and broken dreams feels like it's of some different, ancient time.
The film offers frank, matter-of-fact commentary that is far more illuminating than the talking-head encomiums served up by the likes of Perez Hilton, Dita Von Teese, and Hugh Hefner.
Whether it's a function of sloppy editing or sloppy writing, few of these supporting players and their accompanying subplots pay off.
The Desolation of Smaug is not only eight minutes shorter than its forebear, it's at least eight minutes better - less twee, less chatty, more action, more Elvish.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Burgundy and his goofball buddies are faced with dramas and dilemmas that may seem arbitrary and contrived on paper but have an urgent puissance onscreen, as Ferrell and company act their little hearts out. OK, not really.
Inside Llewyn Davis plays like some beautiful, foreboding, darkly funny dream.
Gone Girl presents a deft mix of whodunit and who-you-gonna-believe?
Wasikowska plays this wordless wanderer just right. That is, she makes her real.
Feel-good stories feel good for a reason, and this one is practically operatic.
Richly informative and fascinating ...
In-your-face polemic, with nowhere to go once the point has been made. Repeatedly.
It looks lovely in an art-directed way, and Eddie Redmayne, who won his Oscar earlier in the year for his portrayal of Stephen Hawking in The Theory of Everything, looks lovely, too.
If Macbeth comes off at times like a Classics Illustrated comic-book adaptation (there is one, from 1955), it can also be quite moving, quite troubling, haunting, even.
The two men come alive (responses that seemed dry or diffident on paper are tinged with humor, with audacity, even), and so, too, do the images.
The Force Awakens is half reboot, half remake, and all fun.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Youth is a meditation on aging, on friendship, on love, loss, wisdom, disillusionment, pain.

An epic work of self-indulgence and smug riffing, stringing together tropes from TV and screen westerns and closed-room whodunits, The Hateful Eight announces itself with all the pomp and circumstance of a mid-century cinema spectacle.
Mara and Blanchett are each extraordinary, working in the most organic and soul-stirring ways.
Joy's entry into the world of entrepreneurship has the crazy trajectory of a rocket gone haywire, and Russell's movie is kind of haywire, too.
The Revenant is exhilarating cinema.
Ergüven's film, beautifully shot and beautifully performed, cuts its storybook tone with starker, more brutal truths.
One of those what-were-they-thinking projects in which good talent is on very bad display.
An accomplished and compelling film by writer/director Josh Mond, James White is also pretty much a bummer.
In 13 Hours, Bay is striving for something more realistic, and less Hollywood, than his World War II extravaganza. To some extent, he pulls it off.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Offers a crushing view of humanity at its most desperate, and a view of one man's fevered efforts to find grace and dignity amid the horror.
Try not to let the film's overbearingly jaunty score get in the way. The Lady in the Van is quite a feat.

Old school and new school, color pencils and touchscreen styli, a wide range of formats and techniques are represented in the Oscar Nominated Short Films 2016: Animation program, and that's a good thing.
A goofy conflation of Coenian elements: the numbskull huggermugger of The Big Lebowski, the La La Land surrealness of Barton Fink, the Old Testament overlay of A Serious Man.
Only Yesterday is a meditation on coming of age, the ways our personalities are formed, and informed.

The relationship between the young American and the old Frenchman is as rich as one of Perrier's sauces: the pupil and the teacher, the son and the father, the keen protégé and the stubborn classicist.
Most parties concerned maintain their grim countenances, their characters struggling to find the sweet spot between honor and greed, between doing the right thing and doing the absolute worst.
An impossibly enjoyable live-action cartoon that plays on our real-life anxieties about vengeful cadres of foreign radicals blowing up people - and places.
Apart from its anthropomorphic, allegorical angle, Zootopia is also a tale of female empowerment and a classic noir, too.
Guerra's remarkable film dives deep into seemingly infinite forests, and deep, too, into the soul of man.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Thumpingly exhilarating ...
Sitting in the theater, watching Knight of Cups, you hear an incredible amount of thought-balloon babble, but you don't hear anything approaching the sublime.
Rauch is so committed to her snotty, bitter, up-speaking protagonist that she finds the real humanity lurking there.
45 Years is a study in economy, in the beautiful symmetry of word and image and music.
Terrence Malick comes to mind, too, in Rohrwacher's approach to storytelling - but without the American's sense of the symphonic and supernal.
It's a period piece full of colorful characters, natty costumes, jaunty music.
A kind of mad coming-of-age yarn embellished with lightning bolts and monsters made of cadaverous flesh.
Learning to Drive is a story of companionship, loneliness, resilience. It's a small, artfully crafted thing, but it resonates in big ways.
Isn't the whole handheld "real-video" thing kind of old by now? Isn't the Shyamalanian-twist thing kind of old by now, too?
Black Mass, a down and dirty crime drama based on the exploits of Boston gangster James "Whitey" Bulger, is thrilling for a number of reasons.
There'd be a lot less strife and starvation, disease and dread, if Nancy Meyers ruled the world.
It may not get inside the head of its pole-balancing protagonist - it doesn't really even try - but Zemeckis' movie takes you skyward.
Powerful.
Succeeds in evoking the anarchic violence of the drug wars raging on both sides of the U.S.-Mexican border.
It's quite a story, and if Guggenheim goes overboard in the telling of it, that's perfectly understandable.
Using a screenplay polished and honed by the Coen Brothers, Spielberg dips into John le Carré territory ...
The country goes unnamed, the warring factions aren't always clear, but the nightmarish exploitation of children is made specific in the most vivid, visceral ways.
The acting is unarguably, uniformly strong.
Singular and stunning ...
Some projects are just too misguided for the star to mug and shrug his way out of. Consider Rock the Kasbah at the top, or the bottom, of that list.
Giving 007 a sleek bullet of a BMW instead of his trusty old Aston-Martin isn't exactly going to turn the world of Bond upside down. And, as it turns out, neither does the casting of Brosnan.
If we now take a woman's right to vote and to hold public office for granted, Suffragette reminds us that it wasn't that long ago when things were different.

Sure, your stomach will be in knots, your fingers clenched, your heart racing. But it will also fill that heart with a sense of the goodness, the courage, the enduring love that is out there to be discovered ...
Although Hou Hsiao-Hsien's The Assassin is technically a wuxia film - martial arts, swordplay, the whoosh of arrows in flight - it is much more a film of stillness, quiet, beauty.
Victoria is thrilling cinema, and just plain thrilling, too.

After weeks of media bombardment with Tomorrow Never Dies product tie-in commercials, it's clear that the studio and the film's producers have reinvented movie promotion. Now they need to focus their efforts on reinventing the Bond movies.
It's business as usual, even if that business is pulled off with brilliant precision, ingeniously choreographed action, and an itinerary boasting some of the most photogenic spots on Earth.

Jafar Panahi's Taxi looks onto a world where the social order and the spiritual order are at odds, in flux, where the conversations are sometimes cutting, sometimes comic, sometimes troubled, sometimes profound.
Barrymore and Collette bring life and charm to a screenplay that needs all the life and charm it can get.
Ghosts haunt Heart of a Dog - but so, too, does love.
Inspiring stuff, the stuff of Hollywood all the way back to Frank Capra and before: a story of scrappy underdogs, determined to get to the truth, and toppling the mighty in the process.
What Our Fathers Did is a movie about historical and filial responsibility, about repudiation, about acceptance, about the pain we inherit, and the pain that continues to be doled out.
movie_title: What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Secret in Their Eyes is notable for its top-tier cast - Julia Roberts, Nicole Kidman, and Chiwetel Ejiofor are the leads - and for its utter lack of credulity and good sense.
Brooklyn is that rare period drama that doesn't lose itself in its dogged re-creation of another time.
If Mockingjay - Part 1 was walkier and talkier than its forerunners, Part 2 is pretty much all action - and lesser for it.
Creed is corny like the old Rocky films, but riveting like the old Rocky films, too.
The worn and weathered third installment in the four-part film adaptation of Veronica Roth's postapocalyptic dystopian YA books.
Resonant and surprisingly affecting ...

There's a gravitas here that even the staleist of comic book tropes can't diminish. Snyder, who directed Man of Steel and the failed comic book adaptation Watchmen, is nothing less than respectful. The effects aren't bad, either.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Krisha may go on a little longer than you'd want, but then, its title character is the kind of houseguest who stays longer than you'd want her to - so even the postscript confrontations and apologies feel right.
The Fallen Idol finds innocence and inquisitiveness at odds with corruption, violence, desire, deceit - all the stuff that grown-ups trade in.
Much of Finding Dory is funny, and fun. But there's something kind of haunting about our heroine's memory thing.
Immersive and illuminating ...

Full of silly, swirling fantasy sequences and breezy backstage glimpses into their ``lives'' - not to mention an album's worth of new tunes - Spice World offers a fanciful view of fame and female camaraderie in the fabulous '90s.
A movie about the safe haven of imagination, about loneliness and despair and resilience, about obsession and, um, stalking.
In Spielberg's grasp - mixing live-action and green screen, CG and motion-capture effects - the 1982 children's story becomes a large-scale tableau of impossibly wonderful images ...
The Secret Life of Pets is a pet-lover's loving salute to the domesticated animals we rely on to bring us comfort, companionship, and triple-digit veterinary bills.
Girl power and ghoul power - it's a winning combination.
As solid as Cranston, Leguizamo, Kruger, Bratt, and all the rest are, the built-in constraints of the movie format don't do their real-life counterparts full justice.

There is plenty in Star Trek Beyond for diehard Trekkers to enjoy, and director Justin Lin guns the action sequences - even if that motocross machine that Kirk is ostensibly riding looks totally fake and video-game-ish.
It's a rare movie that asks such big questions - about parenting, about family, about modern-day America - and comes up with answers that are moving and meaningful, that make you laugh and cry.
"Life is a comedy written by a sadistic comedy writer," Bobby quips. Café Society, on the other hand, is a comedy written by a benumbed one.
Jason Bourne finally knows who he is. But Jason Bourne doesn't know how to process that information.

If you succumb to Koreeda's slow rhythms, the climbs up a hill to find a magnificent view, the walks along the beach, the simple peace of a shared meal, this is the kind of movie that will leave you feeling restored, maybe a little misty-eyed as well.
Mildly amusing, moderately raunchy, mostly schematic ...
Stop the presses: War makes people rich. Stop the movie: These people, who cares?
Hell or High Water is at once a tale of desperation in hard times, and a keenly observed character study - or studies.

A Tale of Love and Darkness loses itself in dreamy imagery, in its studiously crafted aesthetic. But there are times when Portman lets the toughness, the tenacity, the emotional heart of Oz's story shine through.
movie_title: A Tale of Love and Darkness (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Elevator to the Gallows, killer stuff.
movie_title: Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenseur pour l'échafaud) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: The truehearted insights in Chad Hartigan's Sundance award-winner - about adolescence, about alienation, about parenting, about race - make it a must-see.

The movie brushes up against far-fetched soap-opera scenarios. The ending isn't altogether satisfying. Yet Weisz, playful and seductive, utterly confident, disarmingly vulnerable, delivers a performance that makes you forget all that.

As in the films of the French New Wave's Eric Rohmer, nothing cloying happens here, nothing plainly engineered to elicit emotions. But emotions are elicited - moral and ethical concerns are addressed, examined, defined.
Moretti knows how to orchestrate a good laugh when it's needed, but he can plumb more soulful, sorrowful depths, too.
Pretty sure I spotted a credit at the end of the movie for a tear-bucket grip.
At once a true-life drama about heroism and people working in harmony under exceptional conditions ...
If you haven't succumbed to the joyous magic of La La Land by the end of the Fred-and-Ginger-flavored "A Lovely Night," well, then, pick up your Official Curmudgeon badge and head for the exit.
Arrival is at once majestic and melancholy. It's a grand endeavor, and Adams, at the center of it all, brings pluck and smarts and a deep-seated sorrow to her role. This is her movie, no doubt.
It is a fever dream of a movie, tracking its subject as she tries to maintain control, maintain her composure, her sanity.

Though I'm generally not one to complain about a movie being too short, this adaptation seems to have achieved its brevity by eliminating most of what was good about the books and leaving in most of what wasn't.
What it doesn't have is any kind of real magic.
Brings home the complexities and contradictions of the man.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Fictocritical and funny.
A story of survival, of assimilation - and of alienation.

How the film plays out, and what happens to the boy and the adults in his company, may prove a revelation, or a disappointment, or something in between. But getting there is thrilling and wondrously strange.
Wonderfully evocative, funny, sad, complex, and essential passages from a man's childhood and adolescence.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The feeblest kind of costume drama, where the costumes have more impact than the drama and where the period details serve only as distraction, reminding audiences that things looked different back then and not much else.
It's almost an anthropological study: a tribe in its native habitat - batting practice, bar fights, babes (or so they hope, obsessively).
Demolition plays like a failed iteration of a 1970s angry-misfit movie (think Jack Nicholson in Five Easy Pieces), not like the real thing.

Born to Be Blue doesn't pretend to have all the answers. What it does have - in addition to an immersive performance from Ethan Hawke as the cool-cat jazz man - is an emotional understanding of who Baker was, or may have been.
Miles Ahead is more a provocative character sketch than a meaty portrait, but it's a film that should be applauded for its daring, and for Cheadle's shape-shifting, soul-baring work.
Egregiously silly, generic ...
This Jungle Book, however, is more remindful of Disney's classic wildlife adventure pics than it is of a cartoon, and it is most remindful of that other jungle classic, Tarzan.
An odd, diverting footnote of a film.
Quiet existential irony, albeit diluted and distorted, still reverberates in this stranger-in-a-strange-land story.
Carney understands how music not only provides a soundtrack for a life, but can change a life, too.
Sampling Tolkien, Disney, and Grimm, The Huntsman: Winter's War lays on the pastiche in slabs, but no one is slouching here.
If, as has been reported, Graffiti Bridge is Prince's homage to the heyday of Hollywood musicals, he should have hired a director who looks at film as more than an extended music video.
Hemingway was the master of less is more. Papa: Hemingway in Cuba - more is less.

[Saulnier does] everything right: the cast, the music, the editing, the way he leads you one way and then clobbers you (and some of his ill-fated characters) when you (and they) are least expecting it.
If the beauty of Rio de Janeiro is jaw-dropping, so, too, is the slipshod manner in which the aforementioned talents go about their business there.
movie_title: Rio, I Love You (Rio, Eu Te Amo) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With every new installment of the comic book franchise, the scale gets bigger, relationships get trickier, new forces enter the fray.

With Sarandon in the title role, Scafaria has a winner: The actress tackles Marnie headlong, with heart and soul, trolling the fancy outdoor shopping mall for products to buy and for people to intercept and hang on to.
Francofonia is a brilliant meditation on art, on war - and what happens to art when nations go to war.
Even if Money Monster ultimately gets held hostage by its plot intricacies, Clooney, Roberts, O'Connell, and Foster do their jobs. It's a movie worth investing in.
High-Rise doesn't shock at all. And if its message about elitism, isolation, the decadence of capitalism, and the phony pursuits of the bourgeoisie still rings true - well, sure, what else is new?
A tale of love and jealousy, obsession and seduction, A Bigger Splash takes its time getting where it's actually going ... but that's all right.
Neighbors 2 brings back most of the principals from the first movie, and then amps up the conflict by introducing a renegade band of college sisters.
Pure Country is an Elvis movie with a thick country twang.
The Nice Guys borrows from noir traditions and pulp fiction, throwing a fresh coat of smart-alecky comedy over the whole thing.
Love & Friendship is a comedy of manners, and manors, and more. It's a comedy of empowerment and sexual politics, dressed up in the best Austen finery.
The Lobster is what would happen if Wes Anderson set about doing Franz Kafka, with a hefty dash of George Orwell thrown into the mix: surreal, comic, sad, strange, beautiful, sublime.
It's the end of the world as we know it - because we've seen it in a dozen other superhero movies by now.
Shameless in every way imaginable, Me Before You milks the pathos for all it's worth, but milks the comedy, too.
There are some terrifically strong scenes and terrific actors contributing to them.
Chloe & Theo is a mess of a message movie, simplistic, sappy, silly.
Mistress America is not a new comic-book movie, although Greta Gerwig, who stars, has a kind of stand-tall, hands-on-hips superhero vibe about her.
Stock markets, bank accounts, and NSA sites aren't the only thing being hacked in Blackhat. The whole thing reeks of hackery.
Gritty, suspenseful and almost poetic in its depiction of an unforgiving town, A Most Violent Year is just shy of being great.
The great strength of the film is that it never resorts to cheap sentimentality. The facts themselves are hard enough, crushing enough.
The Dardennes are aces at these small-scale human dramas, and Two Days, One Night is almost without flaw ...
Directed in moody, downbeat tones by Daniel Barnz, Cake doesn't know when to stop piling on the angst.
Scary and wild, forthright and furious.
Black Sea is a submarine thriller set in the murky depths of exactly where the title says.
Oh, the bathos! The loony wrongheadedness of the screenplay!
"Technically, I'm an alien," Mila Kunis voice-overs, by way of introduction to this epically kitschy space opera ...
A tiny, tasteful throwback to more innocent times, when actresses with exotic names would strip off their costumes while embracing far-fetched scenarios - and one another.
Isn't the stuff of bondage and discipline, sexual role play, silky blindfolds, and whips and floggers supposed to be, well, exciting?
A story of political and spiritual corruption, of men and women accustomed to power, and of others fighting against it.
In the future, in the past, at all points along the space-time continuum, the Theory of the Teenage Male Mind throws everything out of whack.
There are good things to say about the inspirational Disney sports film McFarland, USA, starting with its up-from-the-scrap-heap story, which happens to be true.

It's a cheerfully horrific affair, a sanguine comedy that feels more than a bit like a Christopher Guest farce or an elaborate Monty Python sketch, imprinted with the Kiwi comic sensibilities of co-directors Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's a story of global consequences and historic proportions, and of astounding athleticism and synchronicity - and filmmaker Polsky ices it.
Even if you're willing to forgive its sinkhole plotholes and farthest-fetched conceits, the film - from cowriters/co-directors Glenn Ficarra and John Requa - ultimately makes no sense.
Cool, supremely confident ...
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: [A] riveting, revelatory documentary.
Low on meaning, but full of high-velocity chases, helicopter pursuits, and weapons blasting around empty warehouses marred by graffiti and trash.

All manner of subplots weave their way through the film, which teems with "colorful" characters and saccharine cliches. But, like the first film, it's next to impossible not to find diversion in the company of such stalwarts as Dench and Nighy and Smith.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [Jordan] veers from taut thriller to devilishly sly comedy, from romance to a story of torment and redemption.
Wild Tales - Relatos salvajes in its original Spanish - is, indeed, savage. And surprising. Your jaw will drop, your head will shake, more than a few times.
The Salvation is severe and bloody stuff.
