Directed by Kenneth Branagh with a sprinkling of stardust, dashes of good humor, and a respect for the corniest kinds of romance, Cinderella is a winning re-do of Disney's 1950 animated classic.
Run All Night isn't dull. The pace is breakneck, and necks get broken. But the violence is relentless, ugly, unredeemed by any real humanity.
Obviousness prevails.

Unlike Divergent, which required pages of premise-establishing exposition, Insurgent is more purely action-centric, as the hunters hunt and the hunted flee through the trees, hopping freight trains, trying to elude capture.
Shot in intense close-ups, the better to study the emotions burning off the characters' skin, the film is all talk and gestures, but it begins to take your breath away like a chase movie would.
movie_title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If American Sniper fails at being a truly great film, it is no fault of its star.
Merchants of Doubt shouldn't be a hard sell. The fact that it is should make you very mad.
It speaks to the courage and resilience of one man, the savagery of many, and the potential, for both good and for ill, in us all.
Mr. Turner is no barrel of laughs. It's a barrel of life - an extraordinary one.
The Judge is a tale of family dysfunction, the sins of the father and all that.
Pride takes a footnote in the history of Britain's crippling yearlong industrial action and gives it a human face.
Everything about The Two Faces of January is right, even as the events it describes - a couple's idyllic Grecian holiday, a charming American's adventures abroad - go terribly wrong.
It's a wonder the actors aren't showing bruise marks from all the heavy-handed direction, the unrelenting solemnity of the thing.
It is exhilarating moviemaking, an out-of-the-blue masterwork that ranks as one of the best films of not just the year, but the decade, the century.
If St. Vincent flirts with sappiness - it does, and how - Melfi has struck gold in the pairing of Murray and Lieberher.
Fury presents an unrelentingly violent, visceral depiction of war, which is perhaps as it should be.
It's as much a horror movie as it is a keenly realized indie about jazz, about art, about what it takes to claim greatness.
Interstellar is an experience. Nolan's vision of our galaxy, and galaxies beyond, is daunting, majestic; the hardware of space travel looks right, almost familiar.
Redmayne should be getting a lot of notice for his performance; it's palpable, it's poignant. Jones, too, is terrific.
A strong, striking political drama.
If Mockingjay - Part 1 is quieter and less flashy than its predecessors, that doesn't make it less satisfying.

Even if you don't know the details of this real-life, late-20th-century tragedy, director Bennett Miller's masterfully observed psychological study is imbued with a sense of an inevitable, catastrophic meltdown.
Ostensibly a comedy, and a feeble and innocuous one at that, Post Grad is one of those what-were-they-thinking? studio productions that should have been shelved back in the script stage.
At a certain point, The Homesman will take you by surprise. By the end ... it will take your heart.
If Penn-wings of Madagascar has a certain machine-made feel about it (and it does), that doesn't mean attention hasn't been paid to the animation.
No matter how successful The Babadook turns out to be - and Jennifer Kent's horror story deserves all the success it gets - the prospects of a best-selling kid-lit tie-in don't look good.
Point and Shoot is as much about the collective movement toward Me-ism as it is about VanDyke's assiduously self-crafted journey. Either way, it makes for a great story.

An innovative take on familiar material, Top Five is an exquisitely paced, rich, idiosyncratic, satirical, yet deeply moving free-form comedy about a Hollywood star who is shadowed for one day by a New York Times reporter.
A moving (literally and figuratively) experience, a road movie where the road is a trail that sometimes disappears into the trees, or takes a turn onto a jagged precipice.
Computer-generated imaging has advanced spectacularly over the decades, but moviegoers, and gamers, have been there every step of the way. Miracles aren't as impressive as they used to be.
Long and dull, despite the sumptuous production design and light-shimmering photography (and the orgy).
If you want to see a Renaissance faire turned into an apocalyptic battlefield, this is the ticket.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Quvenzhané Wallis, the Oscar-nominated star of the trippy bayou indie Beasts of the Southern Wild, simply has to skip into a room - and into the frame - to light things up.
Like many a sequel that has exhausted its plot possibilities, Secret of the Tomb looks abroad to add color and culture.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A wondrously strange true story about art and heartbreak, intellectual property theft, and the subjugation of women.
Produced with a Masterpiece Theater eye for period detail, but also with a missionary's zeal to honor a wrongly dishonored man.
A jolly mash-up of symbol-laden, signature once-upon-a-time tales about lust, envy, greed, and misguided pursuits of happiness.
Inherent Vice is a sun-glared, neon-limned muddle of noir plotline and potheaded jokery that not only doesn't make sense, but actually seems to try hard not to.
This is what Selma dares to do so well: show us the small, private moments in King's life, the intimacies, the humanity.
Out-of-control hilarious.
The matters of sex and lost innocence work like a thematic undertow, pulling the characters down into the dark, psychological depths.
Seymour: An Introduction is just that - not too much biography, or history. And one needn't be a music aficionado, or a musician, to appreciate the modest erudition coming from this man.

Deeply personal and filled with love, Maya Forbes' Infinitely Polar Bear is nonetheless a hard movie to watch - hard to watch comfortably.

You'd think a movie about transplanting human consciousness would be smarter than this.
The film is remarkable not just for the immense talent there to see in Winehouse's performances, but the fact that there is so much to see.
This is a film that should satisfy fans of the hugely popular comic book and audiences who can't tell one uncanny X-Man from another. Mutants rule.
Trainwreck is anything but.
There's humanity here, on all sides, and a gentle wisdom beneath the raging rhetoric.
Although its origin-story machinations get the better of it, Ant-Man isn't a bust.
Mr. Holmes is about how the past defines us. It is also very much about regret and trying to put things right.
What keeps this cornball business from getting out of hand is the commitment of Gyllenhaal, whose performance is fierce and muscular, in and out of the ring.
The movie name-drops the cool stuff, the rebels of word and song, but the essence of the story and the cardboard characters who inhabit it are as mundane as can be.

Baker gets great, sly, unforced performances from his two leads, but it's not all a rollicking good time: There are moments of quietude, inquietude, moments when a sense of wariness and loneliness settles over the women.
There's a difference between velocity and momentum, and while the chases, shootouts and close-quarters combat rarely flag, our interest does.
Although it often feels like a company-bankrolled promo film, A Lego Brickumentary answers all the questions both Lego novices and Lego nerds would want to know.
I can't remember the last time four actors appeared less invested in a movie for which they've teamed up.
Demme has already made a messed-up family matrimonial get-together way better than this, with a way better screenplay than the one Juno writer Cody has tossed off.
Riley's film brings the American icon's career back into sharp focus.
There is intrigue. There is suspense. Guilt -- a man's guilt, a nation's -- hangs heavy in the air.
A lot of energy and effort has gone into this endeavor, and I can't say some of it's not fun. But more of it, alas, is just tedious.

Best of Enemies offers a bracing view of a pivotal time in our recent history, as Vietnam and race riots scarred a nation's soul, and as the Establishment and the Counter Culture exchanged epithets and blows.
We're in the company of a great character here, with a lot on his mind, a lot to say.
If you strip away all the gunplay, Hitman: Agent 47 would be about 10 minutes long.
An honest and personal and unblurred examination (even through that druggy blur) of a tricky voyage into womanhood.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Rosenwald tells the remarkable story of a remarkable man.

A taut thriller about an American family touching down in an unnamed country just as a violent coup erupts, No Escape goes about its gut-churning business by playing (and preying) on our worst xenophobic tendencies.
Conversations drift and weave, as do the people having them. Narcissistic melancholy dukes it out with beer-and-pot-stoked merriment. There is longing. There is foolhardiness.
Inside Out is the first psychological thriller that's fun for the whole family. Really psychological. And really fun.
What were Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence thinking? Seriously?

It looks and sounds as if it came out of the Disney Studios of the '40s or '50s. Which isn't necessarily a bad thing -- that's as much a compliment (in terms of the quality of animation) as it is a criticism.
If a Spy sequel isn't already in the works, they better get cracking. Nefarious terrorists and numskull guys await.

Comedy, pathos, and some schmaltzy couplets about the changing seasons follow forthwith.
If Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter takes its time, it's time worth taking.
White God offers a dark - very dark - take on the way humans exert authority, and superiority, over our fellow creatures.
Baumbach, whose films include the searingly funny, autobiographical The Squid and the Whale and the brilliantly uncomfortable Margot at the Wedding, writes wry, sharp, poignant stuff.
[An] unrelentingly grim, plodding, and close-to-incoherent adaptation of Tom Rob Smith's best-selling mystery.
Never mind the facts. True Story, slick and shaky, doesn't know where the truth lies.
Hugely affecting - and reflective and witty ...
Something deep and allegorical could be going on here, but Silent Tongue is at once so overwrought and desert-dull that you can't be bothered to investigate.
Like stage actors who live and breathe their roles over the course of months, Isaac, Gleeson, and Vikander excel, and cast a spell.
After toiling for the likes of Ridley Scott, Ron Howard, and Peter Weir all these years, Crowe takes command of his own camera crews and castmates, mounting an ambitious and sentimental period drama.
Tcheng finds Simons in moments of haughty self-confidence and tremulous self-doubt.
[A] quiet, aching film ...
The thing's a behemoth. And as the franchise thunders on, it's also becoming more and more a bore.
The line between ha-ha funny and sorrowful reverence has been crossed - more deftly than you'd think.
movie_title: The Mafia Kills Only in Summer (La Mafia Uccide solo d'Estate) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Spinney comes across as a man whose warm spirit is literally at the core of the loving, if loopy Big Bird.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Iris is an absolute kick, whether or not you care a whit about the world this character is moving through. And she is a character, with her big round glasses and her big opinions.
Miller has found his heavy metal groove (one of the legion of freaky baddies is strapped to the front of a truck, grinding out a sonic burn of electric guitar licks for the entire movie).
Dreamy and impressionistic, full of debauchery, drugs, disco, and dazzling couture, Saint Laurent is a biopic that picks its moments, leaving backstory behind.
Opens the window on a pivotal time in 1960s (and early 1970s) pop culture.
Unlikely to be remembered in decades to come - or even in months to come, once the next teenage dystopian fantasy inserts itself into movie houses.
For all the screwball patter, smart-aleck similes, and zingy one-liners that Crowe has handed his mismatched cast, a kerplunking emptiness runs through Aloha.
This peripatetic farce practically propels itself.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Quite literally the blockbuster of the year.
Fails to bring Giger to life in any kind of illuminating way.
Let sleeping bros lie.
Its daring dive into the mind of Brian Wilson feels right. God only knows (to borrow a Pet Sound song title or two), but you still believe in . . . Brian.
I'll See You in My Dreams is delicate and nuanced, with writing that rejects, or at least reshapes, the cliches of movies about people facing the glare of their sunset years.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Offers a remarkably intimate and provocative study of a marriage.

The Fighter is funny, ferocious, sad, sweet, pulpy, and violent. Sometimes, all in the same minute.
There's a fierce, self-lacerating wit on display in Lena Dunham's tiny indie Tiny Furniture: as big and bold as the production is modest and (literally) homemade.
It's a strange, thrilling tale begrimed by bad memories, by bad deeds.
Yes, some familiar Carrey tactics are on display, but the star's performance has real heart - it's easily the best thing he has done since Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.

A murderously unfunny rethink of the groundbreaking literary satire.
Quote not available.

A mournful, frightening, powerful film.

Tapping into the same vein of teen melodrama that runs through the Twilight franchise, I Am Number Four hurls a moody adolescent from outer space into the halls of a smalltown American high school.

With his soulful gaze and crooked nose, his seeming reluctance to throw a karate chop but his deft ability to do so, Neeson has an air of melancholy and menace - you feel sorry for the guy, and wary of him at the same time.
Steeped in Christian tenets of forgiveness, brotherhood, and prayer, and rife with earnest platitudes about race and family, The Grace Card is one overwrought piece of work.
About guilt and responsibility, about loss, about the terrible things human beings do, and the moments of serenity and spiritual succor to be gleaned from the natural world.

Sure, Beastly's underlying message is a worthy one, but by the time the film gets there the audience's ability to empathize will be sorely tested.
Seyfried holds the camera's attention, playing this storybook business pretty much straight, although David Leslie Johnson's script puts the actress sorely to the test.
Even the Rain strikes a deep and resonant chord.
Limitless rocks.

Think about adding To Catch a Thief or Charade to your Netflix queue instead.

movie_review_blurb: If there's a psych ward for motion pictures, It's Kind of a Funny Story should check itself in. Boden and Fleck's film suffers from bipolar disorder: manic and silly one minute, moody and muted the next.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A radically ingenious, in-your-face documentary hybrid that takes the basic street relationship between pimps and hookers and holds it up on a global scale.
movie_title: GhettoPhysics: Will the Real Pimps and Hos Please Stand Up! (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Wild and woolly, the movie is a breathtaking head trip that hails from a long tradition of backstage melodramas: 42nd Street, A Star Is Born, All About Eve, and, yes, that kitschy '90s relic, Showgirls.
Too long, too busy, too loud, and too reliant on slam-bang stunt work, Red's glib dialogue and sinister government scenarios begin to wear.
Ultimately too painful, too labored, to care much about at all.
Taylor-Wood stresses the universals rather than the specifics of John's youth. So don't go expecting a Fab Four origin story. The word Beatles is never uttered. But do go.
A Film Unfinished is a profoundly unnerving historical document.
Offers a shambling, multilingual discourse on the nature of art and the nature of marriage.
A beautiful, slow-moving meditation on life, death, and relationships that transcend time and space.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a noble enterprise, and a remarkable story, but it's not a movie that will set you free.
[It's] optimistic. Hokey, even. But it's beautiful, too.
[A] striking wide-screen costume drama.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: As anthropological study, as a short-storylike glimpse into a character better observed from afar -- or through the lens of a jumpy digital video camera -- Douchebag is undeniably fascinating.
The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest comes close to self-parody at times ... [but] the final chapter has its satisfying turns.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's a real-life spy drama. It's human drama. It's political drama. And it's engrossing, all around.

Genius Within presents an artist who was, yes, "eccentric" (the gloves, the overcoat, the hypochondria), but also visionary, curious, unpredictable, and funny.
movie_title: Genius Within: The Inner Life of Glenn Gould (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Client 9 works like a good detective novel: Colorful and seemingly disparate characters are introduced, and then the strands that tie them together are revealed in a rich, sordid, thrilling tableau.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Just remember, folks: If a NASA probe finds alien life forms in space, it's not a good idea to bring DNA samples back to Earth.
Scott shoots and edits Unstoppable with roller-coaster momentum and an eye (and ear) on that roaring tonnage of steel.

Marwencol is about Hogancamp and his miniature alter-ego, about his photographs and his creative process. But it is also, on a deeper level, about how we process our experiences...

Zwick and his cowriters (Marshall Herskovitz and Charles Randolph) are constantly letting Gyllenhaal and Hathaway down.

Hands-down the most nightmarishly awful film of the year.

movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

One of the smart, effective things about Another Earth is that it treats the discovery of a parallel planet in, excuse the pun, a down-to-earth manner.

This is one of the smarter, more honest scripts to be filmed in quite some time. And Jenna Fischer gives one of the smarter, more honest - and vulnerable, and tough - performances by an actress on the big screen in an even longer stretch.

In the oeuvre of Planet of the Apes pics - four sequels to the original, and the 2001 Tim Burton-directed remake - Rise is certainly not the most interesting, nor the most inventive. But it's not risible, either.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Point Blank is so ridiculously successful at keeping its momentum going - and keeping the audience tense with suspense - that it's likely to leave you with your heart pounding, gasping for breath.
Passione is a surprise and a delight from beginning to end.
July likes her rhythms to shuffle, her beats to go long. She is the master of sideways portent - the small act with big ramifications.
The movie claims to be only 83 minutes long, but it's the longest 83 minutes to come along in quite awhile.
Rich with inspired musings on pop culture, literature, philosophy, race, sex.

movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: To be sure, one gets a better sense of the personalities, and the passions stirring their souls, in Wolfe's book. But Magic Trip literally brings these characters to life.

movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the potential for some supernatural grandiosity, the tone here remains understated and quiet, and Gainsbourg's performance feels lived-in, and deep, and right.
What the three pairs of actors lack in semblance (or resemblance), they make up for to a great extent in their performances.
I scrawled the words completely unappealing people in my trusty notebook, sitting there in the dark in the early going of A Good Old Fashioned Orgy.

More interesting for its cultural views than for its insights into love, sex, family angst, and rebellious youth.

Hanna rocks.

movie_review_blurb: For genre geeks, this can be fun - although nothing in Scream 4 is quite as clever as the filmmakers seem to think it is.

The offbeat comedy is not entirely devoid of charm, but its derivativeness is almost embarrassing.

A beautiful, head-spinning mystery that requires keen attention - and rewards it with a tricky and poetic payoff - The Double Hour is a topflight Euro thriller right up there with Tell No One.

The cinematography, by Chris Blauvelt, captures the rugged landscapes and rainless skies with a homespun elegance.

movie_review_blurb: With its mix of vibrant CG and classical elements, the movie dazzles.

Quote not available.

movie_review_blurb: The White Ribbon doesn't resonate at all. The filmmaker's doom-laden view of humanity -- that we are all unredeemably awful creatures, easily swayed to do dastardly things -- oozes with contempt.
Porumboiu's style is steady, observational, his camera tracking Cristi along the streets in much the way Cristi tracks his subject.
The pace is languorous, the volume (with the exception of three or four jolting episodes of violence) low, the lighting dim and grim.

Morel and his crew certainly know how to stage action: the fight scenes and shootouts, the stairwell pursuits and motorway mayhem, are as good, if not better, than anything to come out of Hong Kong in a long time.
Roof-hopping, check. Banister-leaping, mais, oui.
The whole thing feels like middle-period Mamet with English accents, and not much to say.

35 Shots of Rum is visual poetry, but poetry that examines the human condition with insight and illumination.
The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo is rife with nightmarishly violent and horrific behavior. It's intense, graphic, frightening. And, yes, exhilarating.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: From landscape shots that have the serene beauty of a Han Dynasty watercolor, to its dramatic naval engagements and thundering cavalry charges, this is magnificent filmmaking, and a magnificent film.
I cannot think of another film this year that has stayed with me, its images of dread and fear -- and yes, perhaps hope -- kicking around like such a terrible dream.
A taut espionage drama that pits global corporations against a radical band of ecoterrorists.

Big Fan shares a nutty kinship with the obsessive-loner pictures of Martin Scorsese, namely Taxi Driver and The King of Comedy. And while Oswalt is no De Niro, the stand-up comic brings a schlumpy pathos to his portrait that shows depth and dimension.
All About Steve struggles mightily to find its loony essence. But Bullock's apple-cheeked larkishness is all flailing limbs and bug-eyed reaction shots -- there's no there there.
For a comedy about autoerotic asphyxiation, epic deception, and shameless exploitation, World's Greatest Dad is a surprisingly sweet and tender affair.

A mix of coolheaded cultural satire and anxiety-inducing workplace and marital shenanigans, Extract is an odd project. It's smarter than most of the comedies out there right now, but that doesn't necessarily make it funnier.

Three cheers for effort, but you won't do a back-flip over this film.
There's actually some above-average stuff in the film.
It attempts to be both prison picture and murder mystery, without really succeeding at either.
A warm, funny film that depicts a deep-dish slice of life a la Sweet Home Chicago, and we eat it up. You may even want seconds.
Notting Hill is clever, funny, romantic - and oh, yes, reminiscent of Four Weddings and a Funeral.

Bits and pieces of it are clever and entertaining, true enough. But not enough to make it a certified hit.
Just doesn't deliver!
Flounders in a no man's land of mediocrity -- pretty bad, but not deliciously bad enough to become a cult classic.
About as deep as an empty wading pool.
Boys and Girls is likely to be interesting only to, well, boys and girls.

The film is such a delight not only because it's clever, but because it so perfectly captures the era.

Cries out for a surer hand and a quicker pace.
The action scenes and performances by Voight and Van Der Beek make this a game effort.

Superstar is, surprisingly, not awful.
The movie is a string of lame, aimless skits that never really gel.

Sharp, funny, complex.

It's a sci-fi film. It's an action picture. It's a comedy. And, surprisingly, it works.

Jimmy Neutron should appeal to carbon-based life forms both young and old -- at least until the media blitz becomes unbearable.
A tasty mix of old-fashioned entertainment, seasoned with fine acting and familiar faces.
A tasty bit of drama for the adult palate.
Although it's sweet, it's nothing new.
A flawed, guilty pleasure, especially if you don't mind your movies extra sweet.
The plot is plastered with one Hollywood cliche after another, most of which involve precocious kids getting the better of obnoxious adults.
It's terribly predictable, like turkey on Thanksgiving Day. But that doesn't mean you don't love it.

Think about the last time cartoon characters could bring you to tears as well as laughter, and you'll realize that this movie is as rare as the creatures that people it.
Clockstoppers is one of those crazy, mixed-up films that doesn't know what it wants to be when it grows up.
Even with its inconsistencies, the movie offers enough suspense to get airborne.
Feels more like a series of sketches thrown together than a movie.
While there are some nifty twists, they're laced with corny dialogue, trite stereotypes and B-movie-grade effects, which eat away at the film's slick, sinister veneer.

Dragonfly is one of those films that makes you itch to punch the fast-forward button.
A B-grade Scream wannabe.
K-PAX begs more questions than it answers, though Spacey manages to make you not mind the confusion as much.
A pleasant enough diversion, but it doesn't pack the wry punch of Cusack's classic romantic comedy, 1989's Say Anything.
The movie is flabby and fails to pack a punch, lacking the high-energy numbers needed to boost the tempo and get toes tapping.
The perfect little confection for Valentine's Day.
Is it amusing? No.
There are a few giggles among the grossness, but with movie tickets going for more than $7 a pop these days, don't you want more?
Someone Like You is likable enough to make it this weekend's date movie.
The first Saturday Night Live-related comedy to produce belly laughs in a long, long time.
An unusual yet satisfying offering.
Would make a much better music video than a feature-length film.
As the movie lurches toward a warm, fuzzy, cotton-candy ending, the resulting split personality leaves us feeling cheated and dissatisfied.
Overall, there is a welcome feeling of innocence throughout this PG film, which makes it a great movie to share as a family -- if your brood is old enough to sit still for 90 minutes.
Much like its lead character -- tough to dislike and packed with personality.
Not as sophisticated as Pretty Woman, but much more interesting than Bride.
Plods dutifully through muddy explanations of battles and alliances with unrelenting boredom.

If you keep your expectations in check, the encounter doesn't disappoint.

It's all fairly enjoyable, but also predictable and occasionally corny.

Some family films strike just the right balance, engaging for viewers of any age. Shorts is not one of those movies.

movie_review_blurb: Despite all the supporting star power, it's Martin's physical comedy that makes the movie.
Seems a bit lackluster next to the original, 1980 Oscar winner.
The movie has its moments, but director Paul Weitz paces things a bit like a cheesy carnival ride.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Leap Year is a chaste little picture reminiscent of screwball comedies of the 1930s -- and a pleasant change from films that are all sex and no romance.
Unfortunately, director Tom Vaughan appears determined to deliver every minute detail of the Crowleys' story.
Garry Marshall's new movie is like a luscious-looking Valentine's treat that turns out to be disappointingly bland.
The story, like the movie, is pretty uninteresting and easily forgotten.
Hot Tub Time Machine proves that just because you have the power and money to make a movie, it doesn't mean you should.
Billingsley does a good job on selling the beauty of the island, but only a serviceable one in telling this story. Then again, there isn't all that much to tell.
It's silly stuff, riddled with the predictable bodily function humor and humiliation of adults that kids seem to love.
It's all predictable yet comfy. If you're looking for lighthearted entertainment, you'll find it here.
Co-produced by Adam Sandler, Mall Cop has an innate sweetness that's reminiscent of Sandler's 1998 romantic comedy The Wedding Singer, although the laughs don't quite reach those levels.
Horton is a wonderful family outing for parents to share with their children.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Drillbit Taylor is a guilty pleasure that's satisfying as a plate of junk food.
Forgetting Sarah Marshall is by no means great art, but it is great fun.

What Happens in Vegas is about as bubbly as flat champagne. While aiming for an intoxicating blend of high-energy comedy, the romantic comedy's predictable story, and the lack of chemistry between stars Diaz and Kutcher, don't leave it withmuch of a kick.
Someone needs to tell Adam Sandler enough is enough.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: French director Xavier Gens keeps the action riveting and spectacular.
Despite his name, [director] Softley plays it with a heavy hand, distracting viewers with lots of action, hideous makeup and garish costumes, but the effect is more perplexing than enlightening.
Although a bit uneven, The Love Guru scores more guffaws than clunkers, though parents should take the PG-13 rating seriously.
The cinematic equivalent of elevator music: bland, occasionally entertaining and, once it's over, utterly forgettable.
The dog days of summer have arrived, and I'm not talking about the weather.

A live-action movie with a boatload of cute pooches that, despite bewitching effects and a charming voice cast, buries its sentiment in a too-tangled tale.
The overall result is uneven, with the truly funny stuff undermined by the cheap laughs.
Deschanel and Carrey have surprising chemistry. She can match him shtick for shtick, while Carrey draws from his Serious Actor skills to add warmth to the romance part of the story.
Space Chimps may not be top-flight entertainment, but as kid movies travel, it's unexpectedly engaging.
When the cutest and most amusing thing in a movie is a pet pig on caffeine, you know you're in trouble.

Making Brand's character the center of this project results in a flick with a split personality: half gross-out comedy and half depressing biopic of a star besieged by drugs, drink and dysfunction. It's far more sad than funny.

movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Those who have grown up with these characters, now fixtures in pop culture, likely will find it reassuring to know that some things never change.
The eye-popping, energetic "Madagascar 3: Europe's Most Wanted" really is a three-ring circus.

Costner makes the movie, if not believable, at least entertaining.

Unlike its semi-serious inspiration, the new "Jump Street" is a rowdy mix of comedy, satire and sass.
Directors Will Finn and Dan St. Pierre create an animated musical rooted in the classic tale with wonderful, colorful and detailed settings, and a story that is gentle and sweet.
"22 Jump Street" is preposterous in the best possible way.
Ultimately, the movie begins to fall apart as clichés and contrivances start piling up faster than the bodies.
For those who enjoy tear-jerkers, "If I Stay" will provide a satisfying three-hanky experience.
Whether it's worth the price of a ticket is measured by your tolerance for treacly romance.

Might have been more aptly named "Recycled."
Knight and Day, his latest tilt in that direction, has its flaws, but at least it gives audiences a good time.
As the voice of Puss, Banderas still displays heroic charisma. And even in animated form, he and Hayek make sparks as they dance, fight, flirt and face adventure together.
It turns out that getting Smurfed isn't all it's cracked up to be.
Per usual, Ferrell unleashed is a force of nature, a guy who is not going to quit until you either walk out or break down and laugh. Me? I laughed.
The novelty of seeing Barrymore and Long onscreen together wears off quickly, and then the picture has to work on its own merits -- which, unfortunately, are few.
Fickman has a deft touch with romantic comedy, serving up deliciously combative scenes that are occasionally interspersed with bits of cheese.
The premise is the most interesting thing about it. From there, it's just bland.
Directed by Todd Phillips ("The Hangover"), this movie has the same absurdist feel and dark humor, but not the comedic snap.
Compared to some kid flicks, "Yogi Bear" is rather sweet.
A Frankenstein-like compendium of fight movies haphazardly bolted together in the hope that something will spark to life.

Fukunaga's interpretation takes great pains to accurately capture the period in its language and costumes.
Even with the 3-D effects and rap music, "Rio" has a retro feel, thanks to its bright, colorful characters and brave heroine.
The action is fast, the gags are plentiful - and many actually are funny if you check your squeamishness at the door.
It's not often a movie features a cast of characters with absolutely no redeeming qualities, but "Bad Teacher" really hits that one out of the park.
Bateman, Day and Sudeikis have a natural camaraderie on-screen, and it's fun to ride this runaway train as events careen forward.
Ron Howard has made some great films. "The Dilemma" is not one of them.

There are a few things wrong with this second go-round - not the least of which is that, in 2011, hopeless drunks are rarely seen as funny.

The sharp script by Judd Apatow and Nicholas Stoller and Dean Parisot's steady direction keep things on a higher level as the movie skewers American excess.

Hoodwinked is a delicious little basket of goodies, from its quick-witted humor to its colorful animation.
The quirky romantic comedy works largely because of good writing, and Rudd's deadpan delivery of same. That he can do so as slapstick erupts around him makes it all the funnier.

The film is at its best when it's not trying to be desperately funny, but that's rare.
It is a Disney adventure movie that does old Walt himself proud.
Ice Age: The Meltdown is a rarity, like the last of the woolly mammoths: a sequel that's as delightful as the original.

Stick It gets stuck deciding where it's going. Is it a) the story of a wayward teen who straightens up; b) a gymnastics version of Clueless; or c) just a way to blow 100 minutes? From the looks of it, the right answer may be 'c.'

Hopefully, Garfield doesn't really have nine lives, because that would mean suffering through seven more sequels.
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Tokyo Drift jump-starts the franchise with a high-octane mix of action, hot stars and smokin' cars.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: If you like watching Owen Wilson play the same character he's played for most of his Hollywood career, and like to be able to predict every comic bit in a movie, You, Me and Dupree is your cup of tea -- or, maybe, your six-pack.

Duff's desperate, self-absorbed attempts to make her scheme work include setting off the water sprinklers in a crowded New York restaurant. It's supposed to be charming and amusing, but it feels irritating and dangerous.

It sounds hokey, but the nostalgic quality of the whole Herbie experience makes Fully Loaded a charming family film.

When scares should start to pop, they barely fizzle.
It's Levy and his chemistry with Jackson that keeps The Man from being ho-hum.
Viewers are likely to feel they are enduring the film for an eternity rather than being entertained by it.
The plot, 'inspired by a true story,' is all but impossible.

movie_review_blurb: Must Love Dogs makes a good first impression -- it's smart, funny and entertaining. But as the reels unwind, it's missing the special chemistry necessary to make us fall head-over-heels for it.

It turns out Lohan isn't the one with the bad luck; the audience is.

Crossover has too much going for it. It has a wonderful message about making smart life choices, but the story shuffles among too many subjects -- sports, romance, friendship -- to let audiences hear it clearly.

Critics may accuse Ferrell of making a career out of insider sports comedies, with Blades hot on the heels of Talladega Nights, but it's still a funny, well-rounded package that lets the talents of other cast shine, too.

There is a simple sweetness about this film when it sticks to the likable Carell, God and his family, but it's overcome by the deluge of effects that pay homage to Hollywood's sole focus of worship: the box office.
A pleasant enough diversion for anyone who likes their comedies as light and fluffy as their popcorn.
For real laughs, skip Accepted and rent Animal House.

Predictable as any TV sitcom.

The Brothers Solomon isn't for all tastes, but if you like your comedy a little twisted, it's a satisfying, if imperfect, swig of silliness.

A bit like cheap champagne: It's better if you revel in its bubbly fizz and don't think about the finish.
Mimzy has action that makes it a bit too intense for small children but too tedious for grownups.

movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [Actors Henry Thomas and Louise Fletcher] are hamstrung by stilted dialogue; every sentence addressed to Liberato seems to begin with 'My dear child.'

Wild Hogs is a formulaic road picture that hits a few potholes, thanks to an uneven script and stale comedic devices.
It bears a striking resemblance to An Officer and a Gentleman, which is now nearly a quarter-century old. But the new movie's visuals and direction give it an edgier, 21st-century vibe.
A sort of blue-collar Office Space that sends up the dreary world of working at a discount store.
The pacing is a bit slow, and the references to faith at first seem a little heavy-handed, but the movie comes together as you warm up to the characters.
Flicka proves a pleasant surprise for a family film.

A frightening, tangled tapestry of youth as its worst.
Catch and Release is a puzzle missing a few critical pieces, and as a result, it never really connects.
It could have been an enjoyable light comedy, or a dark tale of obsession, but it doesn't work.

Even if there's little here for older viewers to enjoy, youngsters will love the slapstick action and catchy soundtrack.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Schmaltzy and twee to a heavenly degree, this is definitely not for the cynical, but small children will love it, especially the synchronised swimming piglets.
Bette Midler ... lends Kitty a devilish rasp that's one of the joys of the film.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If you're a 3D sceptic, this is a film you must see. The underwater world of little Sammy the turtle and his friends jumps out of the screen in a riot of colour and excitement.
It all seems rather jaded this time around, and even the pop songs (usually a saving grace in these movies) feel tired.
It's the simple charm and humour of the tale that lingers in the memory.
If the writers had produced something that was smarter than the average script, then perhaps we would have been in business.
As it is, the film is just crappy, sappy, PG-13 Valentine's Day drivel.
What can Hollywood do to save the genre? For starters, leave the city crushing to Godzilla and Michael Bay. If it can't fit in a comic book panel, it probably doesn't belong.
This Superman has the rare ability of making us look back fondly on 2006's nostalgic Superman Returns-a film that elicited a nearly universal "meh."
India has made intelligent movies for decades. Dhoom 3 is not one of them.
To be clear, it's not an altogether awful movie. The film bounces happily within the safe, sometimes stupid confines of generic Bollywood tropes.
Most of the funny lines are allotted to Shajohn who comes up with a brilliant performance while Dileep opts for a more or less serious avatar.
Manju pulls off another competent act and rises to the occasion by emoting well the various moods of the love queen of Malabar.
The Class confirms and extends Cantet's status as one of the masters of European social cinema. It's a hugely important film.

Snyder is so besotted with Moore's book that he feels he has to include almost every detail. He dawdles interminably. Slow pans, slow tilts, slo-mo: there's simply not enough kick or energy to justify the 160-minute running time.
The Damned United zips along, is often funny and will give football fans of a certain age an enjoyable memory rush.
Well over two hours long, the film outstays its welcome, but it does have some truly magical moments that outshine anything Curtis has done before.
It's a subdued, somewhat melancholic Paris to be sure, but one whose potential loneliness is softened by the intriguing support networks the characters improvise.
It's a sharper, bawdier version of Yes, Minister. And ultimately just as cosy, colluding in our cynicism about politicians rather than challenging it.
It's everything Twilight wanted to be but wasn't: beautiful to gaze at, achingly romantic, emotionally involving, unexpectedly terrifying.
What is there to say about The 400 Blows that hasn't already been said?

He never manages, though, to penetrate to his character's much-touted depths, and it's left to young non-professionals Vang and Her to infuse the action with a spry, casual liveliness that offsets the film's rickety set-up and pacing.
It's good to see an espionage thriller that avoids the clichés of the genre.
Almost every film Werner Herzog makes is savage and incisive. Encounters at the End of the World, far-out and unforgettable.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: State of Play doesn't betray its source material. It's not a huge let-down. It's a perfectly satisfactory evening's entertainment. But I wish it could have been more than that.

The screenplay by David Benioff and Skip Woods is an arhythmic mess, full of holes and elisions so that, even on the lowest-common-denominator basis of helicopter chases and acts of decapitation, the film doesn't have anything like the power it should.

This is a disappointingly reverential exercise in East End mythologising that's too busy sucking up to its rheumily sentimental interviewees to spend enough time exploring the few interesting observations they do make.
So fantastically buoyant, so soaring and so universal, that it's hard to check the urge to get down on one's knees before the cinema screen and give thanks for the joy of being a moviegoer.

Lou, helped by Zeng Jian's striking camerawork, captures very well the mood of drift and fragmentation in modern-day urban China. Compelling and messy in equal measure, it's a cine-letter to the future.
movie_title: Spring Fever (Chun feng chen zui de ye wan) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Fish Tank, a social drama at once bucolic and grimy, draws a magnificent performance from newcomer Katie Jarvis, who plays Mia, a fierce-tempered, beer-guzzling teenager.
Scrappy and overlong, it works better as a documentary than as a drama, though its ending is both unexpected and deeply moving.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Sometimes, and especially on a crummy afternoon in the middle of March, it's nice to be able to switch off and settle down to enjoying the sight of middle-class families eating well and playing together in sprawling, bucolic gardens.
Director Jane Campion has a knack for portraying female characters so intimately that she seems to get beneath their skin. She does it again in Bright Star, an exquisite piece of film-making.
Director Won Shin-yun infuses the moralisms with a pulpy energy that recalls cheery shockers such as Hostel and Saw, while also indulging in Three Stooges-style bumpkin-knockabout humour.
This is a fascinating film that, once seen, is hard to dislodge from your imagination.
Hunger is breeze-block heavy, an unforgettable portrait of battered and self-battering masculinity, a visceral and vitally important reawakening of repressed memories.
But it's a sham, a risible and almost militantly superficial piece of regional PR that exposes the snobbish and flimsy foundations on which Davies's bewilderingly inflated reputation rests.

The Baader-Meinhof Complex, directed by Uli Edel from a screenplay by Bernd Eichinger, represents a darker vision of the period that, given the ongoing war on terror and fear about home-grown militants, seems especially timely.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film marries digicam naturalism to animated fantasy to oddsome but fascinating effect, rendering magical the inner world of the shy and almost muted Jorge. It's an unusual but valuable addition to the cinema of contemporary migration.
Scott, at heart, is a pyrotechnician rather than a political philosopher. Sometimes, during the scenes when he shows graphic acts of torture, he seems like a two-penny shock merchant, too.
It's a blistering, powerful work.

Changeling fails because, despite its awful subject matter, it isn't very moving. Eastwood is too classical, too restrained a director to get inside his characters; they feel like well-costumed showroom dummies.
An utterly riveting thriller.

Cheap-looking, and peddling a humour that charitable folks will call broad and the rest of us will call unfunny, Pink Panther 2 may still appeal to audiences in non-English-speaking countries where physical comedy in the Mr Bean mould prospers.

I watched Twilight in a cinema full of young girls who, when they weren't texting friends and guzzling soft drinks, giggled, sighed and exhaled with a passion that was not only endearing, but a measure of its emotional truth.
This film does what all children's films should do: not just offer lots of entertaining things to look at, but teach children how to look at the world with curiosity, attentiveness and joy.

Slumdog Millionaire is as acerbic as it is clear-eyed about the brutal power dynamics in modern-day Mumbai. But, at the same time, what makes it so warming and what has been inspiring audiences all across the world to cheer at its rousing ending.

Not only has he hauled Rourke from his self-pitying slump, but, working from a screenplay written by Robert D Siegel, he has created an often-brutal, always-compelling portrait of a decent man trying to peel himself off Skid Row.
