Stanley Nelson's documentary tracing the rise and fall of black America's most militant movement has a little bit of everything good: mercurial personalities, passion and plenty of drama.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Rozema proves herself to be master of mood.
[Ergüven has] made a fiercely feminist statement into a work of art.
Klein is an excellent synthesizer of difficult ideas and knows how to make them accessible.
The Meddler feels a tad schematic, and nothing about the ending is very surprising. But the witty script make the piece very entertaining.
Al-Hwietat, who is in almost every frame, can express a range of feeling without saying a word. The sound is startling, and the landscapes are spectacularly shot by cinematographer Wolfgang Thaler.

How many elderly women can Maggie Smith play without repeating herself? A lot, obviously. Her characterization of the homeless Mary in Nicholas Hytner's adaptation of Alan Bennett's play is fresh and always moving.
Gorgeous to look at, the pic is heart-stoppingly kinetic.
This family drama about an aspiring F-to-M trans teen waiting for parental approval works mainly because of its excellent cast.
This pic belongs to Page and Moore, who make us care deeply about this complex couple. Bring kleenex.
It does have a predictable trajectory -- how could it not? -- but it's certainly not movie-of-the-week fare.

Shots of the masses of pilgrims are spectacular, especially those of the millions circling the Kaaba, one of five required rituals, but the emotional core of the film is what stands out: Sharma's identity crisis as a devout gay Muslim.

Amina may not be a politically courageous activist, and how that came to be discovered is fascinating. But what the story says about the degradation of journalism in the internet age is even more important.
movie_title: A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Tom Vaughan's romantic comedy trivializes so many serious issues, it should be called A Moron's Guide To The Real World.

This doc shines brightest when it tracks the logistical challenges of packing up a full orchestra for an overseas flight or when it focuses on players like double bassist Dominic Seldis and percussionist Herman Rieken.
This ludicrously melodramatic adaptation of The Wild Duck makes mincemeat out of Ibsen's play.

Director and co-writer Michael Showalter's script, especially in scenes about Doris's hoarding and the way her family relates to it, is slack, and the ending's a bit too pat. Still, it's fun to watch great actors do their thing.

At its heart is the iconic Ma himself, intellectually and creatively restless, impatient (watch him roll his eyes when he's introduced via a heap of errors and clichés) and working hard to keep meaning in his life.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director Paul Duddridge gives us just glimpses of these stories, and the narratives either resolve too easily or peter out. A peripheral piece about a pop star and his mother comes out of nowhere.
Despite an arresting first shot, this debut feature epitomizes Canadian cinema at its most frustrating: great performances in a slim script, only adequately brought to the screen.
Though it's shot beautifully, Novitiate's pacing, focusing on the sisters' daily routines, is slow.
The Reagan Show wants to demonstrate Ronald Reagan's mastery of the media but there's more than a slight suggestion that Donald Trump is taking cues from the ex-U.S. president.
It's impossible to root for Katherine. She fights back, for sure, but then she behaves more appallingly than her oppressors.

We have constant news reports and an influx of distressed Syrian refugees to tell us the truth about the conflict in Syria. But The War Show proves that there is something unique about the way movies can tell stories.
The members of the mermaid subculture are extremely committed. It's big fun watching them relish the activity of choosing their next outfits, stroking their tails lovingly.
There's something heartbreaking about seeing a cultural movement at its apex, knowing it would not have the impact so many of its proponents dreamed of.
It's interesting enough.
Tthe most moving element emerges from the film's essential respect for ancient ritual, even as it questions extreme orthodoxies. It's a tough tightrope to walk, and this film does it skilfully.

The key to this excellent documentary about writer and activist Jane Jacobs in New York City is the way it visually expresses the ideas in her groundbreaking book The Death And Life Of Great American Cities.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Though not as daring as many of his previous films, Frantz it is extremely beautiful and, typical of [Ozon's] filmography, shows uncommon empathy for its lead female character.
This doc about obituary writers for the New York Times and their challenges in making people come alive again never takes off.
This story about Katherine and Isaac, two elders who fall in love at a retirement home, could have sunk into saccharine depths, but its authentic take on aging keeps it from making your teeth ache.
Epperlein wields her microphone as if it were a weapon for revenge. And she and co-director Michael Tucker shoot in black-and-white, which lends the film a sense of authenticity and strange beauty.
Here's one of those Brit pics that, despite impeccable acting and meticulous production values, can't get enough emotional drive.
This is a movie guaranteed to generate conversation.
The Last Word may be predictable but it has MacLaine.
The filmmaking is expert. Watch how Lelio uses mirrors and windows, especially in the moments just after the aforementioned family attack.
[Writer/Director Mina] Shum mines her favourite theme - immigrant experience in Canada - in what seems at first to be a gentle slice of life but eventually develops a powerful emotional force.
This improbable story of half-sisters who reconnect works because of its strong performances and the way director Bergroth keeps ratcheting up the tension.
The key to this compelling pic is the way it keeps you on edge - Ally isn't exactly nurturing and Kate is probably big trouble so you're never sure what or who to root for.
With such a compelling premise, the film definitely keeps your interest and is at times very smart, but it just misses.
A powerful portrayal of exploitation.
On this emotional roller coaster, Katja's capable of just about anything.

Most of the fault lies with writers Liz Hannah and Josh Singer, neither of whom have major credits on their resumé. But it doesn't help that Spielberg is a true believer in America and everything he thinks it stands for.

The film pounds away at its metaphors: you get the carousel going round and round and the Wonder Wheel ride outside the family's apartment spinning endlessly. Do we need two symbols of someone being in a rut?
By the end, the filmmakers have painted a portrait of a uniquely passionate artist, beloved by audiences in both her home country and Spain, where Pedro Almodóvar figures prominently in her story.

You'd think this Tonya Harding biopic would turn out to be nothing but an extended punchline, but it's actually a savvy meditation on class, the bull inside the competitive skating world and the dynamics of family abuse.
[Sadaf] Foroughi is definitely one to watch.

As an unabashed Baldwin fan, a part of me wants to drive you to his written material - this guy was a sublimely original thinker. But this doc does well as an entree to him and his essential insights into American anti-Black racism.
This very faithful adaptation of Ian McEwan's novel - he wrote the screenplay - isn't a barnburner but, anchored by Emma Thompson's excellent performance, definitely keeps your interest.
It's well done, if not entirely convincing.
[Glenn] Close carries the pic, letting her silence speak volumes and then exploding with a righteous rage when she's had enough.

This account of the late senator Ted Kennedy's bad behaviour after his car went off the road and killed his passenger, Mary Joe Kopechne, spends way too much time trying to make us feel sorry for him.
The film is so dull. It gives no sense of the complexity of the man, in terms of both his personal and professional lives.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Joe Barton's script, especially the dialogue between the two lovers about capital punishment, is pointed and very smart, and he knows how to let information trickle out at the right pace.
The first hour, which focuses on Mary and Percy's love story starts to sag, but when Mary finds her artistic inspiration, the film takes off.
A brilliant, nuanced movie about female oppression.
movie_title: What Will People Say? (Hva vil folk si) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film has a strong emotional force. It helps that Zweig's personal guide is his friend Lucie Idlout, whose charisma and personal pain give the movie real power.
Annette Bening makes this story of Gloria Grahame's last days a must-see.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Classical music aficionados tend to love the works that are most familiar, but even the most devoted fans of the three Bs will be moved by this thrilling music.
This is a fine take on what happens when a divorcing couple can't see the impact of their acrimony on their child.
Nancy Lang and Peter Raymont paint a vivid portrait of painter Lawren Harris in this visual treat of a documentary.

Writer/director Amari adeptly captures the anxiety of the undocumented, and star Hannachi expertly conveys Samia's shifts from panicked to poised. However, the characters make choices that border on the nonsensical.
Doubtless, defenders will be legion, touting its arty pretensions and "brave" approach to essential issues. Count me out.
[A] dizzying and dazzling meditation on art, inequality and responsibility.
movie_title: The Art Star and the Sudanese Twins (2008)

movie_review_blurb: I didn't think I was absorbed in the story until I was choking back tears at the end.
To really understand Lear, go back to those superb shows.
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Innocents is a deep exploration of faith and doubt.

The real feat here is that, despite the fact that Weiner is plainly addicted to power, the doc manages, occasionally, to make him sympathetic, especially when one of his sextees tries to exploit the situation.
Law's performance is so big -- snake-like movements, a broad Southern drawl -- you'd think he was doing a solo stage show. There's no room for anyone else.
This visually stunning documentary conveys the unique relationship of the Tahltan First Nation to their remote lands in British Columbia, now seriously threatened by mining interests.
An excellent portrait of a powerful public intellectual.
movie_title: Vita Activa: The Spirit of Hannah Arendt (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rebecca Miller's dramedy about a young woman who imagines she can take control of her life -- and others' -- oozes charm thanks to the unique presence of Greta Gerwig.
In the end, Tale Of Tales works neither as a fairy-tale movie nor as a critique or investigation of those stories. It'd make a great coffee-table book, though.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: À La Vie (meaning "to life," or "l'chaim" in Hebrew) carries a strong emotional charge.
Very entertaining.
Mesmerizingly beautiful and sexy.
There's a sweetness -- not to be confused with a saccharine quality -- to this pic, made all the more appealing by its two young leads and a story that hurtles right along.
This is in many ways a conventional coming-of-age story, but charismatic Gordon's mesmerizing performance as the mysterious Natasha makes it special.
A devastating scene between Lee and his ex (Michelle Williams) is one of the best written -- and performed -- sequences I've ever seen on film.
Park goes all-out in series of gratuitous, nearly explicit, sex scenes. That's not in itself such a bad thing, but when he opts for a severely sadistic sequence near the end, he goes too far.
Set in 70s Copenhagen, this is an arresting period piece.

The doc tends to wander, focusing more on the women's everyday lives. But when they travel and are free from the strictures of their closets inside their home communities, you see how beautiful real freedom can be.
Here's a crowd-pleaser that hits all the predictable notes, but you won't mind.
It's the feel of the piece that's so unique.
Fuelled by the deep personal relationships she developed with three women over five years, first-time director Tiffany Hsiung gives these courageous survivors their voice.
Mehta is careful not to suggest that these young men should not be accountable for their crime. But it takes an uncommonly compassionate approach to its unsavoury characters.

This slender piece about a famous actor begrudgingly accepting his young caregiver as he's gradually succumbing to Parkinson's is sentimental and doesn't care much about character backstory or development. But it's entertaining as hell.
Ehe film packs an emotional charge even if it ends too abruptly. And, deeply saturated with colour -- typical of the auteur -- it's very beautiful.
Ziv's tendency to press familiar buttons subverts the pic.

Riffing off the great independent newsman I.F. Stone's famous statement "All governments lie," Peabody connects with an array of impressive indie journalists who are filling in the gaps left by a pandering mainstream media.
movie_title: All Governments Lie: Truth, Deception, and the Spirit of I.F. Stone (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Angry Inuk imparts important information about an issue we tend to think we know everything about and delivers a powerful emotional punch.
Keener is great as usual, convincingly conveying confusion and grief, and the film is visually intense, its handheld cameras relying on close-ups.
Will the documentary play to those who didn't grow up with the Beatles? My guess is that it doesn't really matter. It'll do just fine thanks just to a generation that will never let the Beatles go.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rooney's terrific.
This is first-rate filmmaking, and the cast, especially Tagar, prickly yet tender, is very good.
We don't get much backstory, and there are maybe 50 lines of dialogue in the whole thing. But that's kind of a good thing, since newcomer Linder mumbles the dialogue she's given. Krill's much better.
Fox is amazing -- steely and charismatic -- and the young cast members have great chemistry.
Aided by his fresh and engaging young actors, Morlando is turning into a master of mood. And credit Steve Cosens with making the fields and forests look spectacular.

Sounds like a good idea: convince the planet's ever-expanding population that insects are a sustainable food source, figure out ways to make them tasty and then change the world. That's what this doc's engaging subjects... set out to do.

[Bening] devours the role, nervously smoking throughout, shy in the face of her attraction to her handyman tenant and embodying steely frustration at her inability to deal with being out of control. It's the best work she's done in years.
Exhausting and waterlogged...No big splash here
"Stick It" should serve competitive gymnastics in much the same way "Bring It On" celebrated cheerleading.
Cheery yet repetitive, it's an all-too-familiar road trip filled with speed bumps.
Filled with pop culture references and zingly one-liners, it's delightfully comic and sweetly insightful.
It's a sardonic, subversive, heavy-handed black comedy, painting a nasty picture.
Sinister yet only mildly suspenseful, this overly cautious "Code" certainly isn't all it's cracked up to be.
Compassionate, intense, agonizing documentary-style reenactment, unfolding in real time.
Lindsay Lohan's a loser this time round with this forgettable, featherweight, cliche-filled contrivance.
Tough love triumphs over adversity in this inspirational, feel-good film.
Slick and stylized, it's a convoluted crime plot that's stretched to pretentious extremes.
As producer/star, Michael Douglas usually chooses projects more intelligent and provocative than this prosaic, improbable, predictable action thriller.
It's simply zany, silly, forgettable fun.
There's a reason this comedy was not screened for critics. It strikes out, except at Pizza hut which must be thrilled with its product placements.
A cheeky, vampy, naughty British comedy.
Wryly irreverent, this cynical comedy about a tobacco lobbyist is a merciless smoke screen.
There's a definite sense of deja vu about this animated adventure/fantasy that turns out to be mild, not wild.
Nicole Holofcener's intriguing take on this thorny topic is bitterly sharp and somewhat depressing, much like these privileged women's lives.
A soccer-themed soap-opera that misses the net as an insipid, if inspirational, underdog tale.
movie_title: Goal! The Dream Begins (Goal!: The Impossible Dream) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Every once in awhile, a captivating movie comes along that makes you smile and laugh and cry - and if you liked "Mad Hot Ballroom," this is a must-see.
'A lot of what gets called entertainment today is actually dumpster-diving for the mind' applies to this incomprehensible, incoherent supernatural thriller.
Haunting and outraged, it's a compelling cry against inhumanity.
While it's a mundane cautionary cult tale about the perils of drug abuse, a curious visual appeal is what distinguishes this film.
Written and directed without a hint of subtlety, it's filled with enough fast-paced carnage to justify the inevitable 'X-4.'
Sordid and ludicrous, it's a steamy stink-bomb!
Pretentious poppycock! Given the expectations of M. Night Shyamalan, it's this summer's most surprising disappointment.
It's a crass, exaggerated, intermittently intriguing gimmick concept of visual effects that wears thin very quickly.
It's fast-paced amusing fluff if you wanna, "Stay loose, stay liquid and laugh a lot."
Implausible - with every urban cliche and stereotype - a complete waste of time and money.
Devilishly extravagant, joyfully escapist, fun-filled, buccaneer thrill ride
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Brain-busting and amusing, it does for puzzlers what "Spellbound" did for spelling bees and "Mad Hot Ballroom" did for dance competitions.
It's terrific, appealing to the child in all of us. Superman soars!
Sophisticated comedies are rarely Oscar contenders but this may be the funniest chick-flick you're likely to see all summer.
Like a companion piece to An Inconvenient Truth, this timely documentary tackles what could be done about America's oil addiction.
Sappy and sentimental, it, nevertheless, has heart.
Sweetly absurd, it's silly, slapstick fun.
Quote not available.
Slick, shiny and adrenaline-propelled, it's a junker. Avoid this noisy, shallow pit stop.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Time warps this time 'round.
Think of this benign, not-so-kosher cultural comedy as "My Big Fat Jewish Bar Mitzvah."
Absolutely ingenious! The more you know about cars and car movies, the richer the experience of watching. Put the pedal to the metal and get going.
In this copycat rehash, lightweight Liev Schreiber and Julia Stiles cannot replace the gravitas of Gregory Peck and Lee Remick.
An amusing, evocative, endearing, nostalgic glimpse of down-home Americana.
Sour and unsavory, rather than a black comedy, it's a bleak comedy.
Relevant and persuasive, it's a convincing plea for activism.
A loathsome, repugnant slasher/thriller
Goofy, blood-and-guts tained comedy/horror that inevitably evokes feelings of repugnance and disgust.
Felicity Huffman astonishes with her skill, her dignity, her bravura style and her knockout performance.
Straightforward, solid bank heist thriller that's filled with stylish patter and moral ambiguity.
Woody Allen's chilling, riveting, mind-teasing psychological thriller is not only his best film in years - but also one of the best movies of 2005!
Sneaky, off-beat, satirically seedy psychodrama/thriller with Pierce Brosnan as a droll, comically demented hit-man
Raucously ribald, lushly romantic romp, aimed at the same audience who enjoyed the wicked wit of "Shakespeare In Love"
It's a classy, laugh-out-loud crowd pleaser with dual tour-de-force performances by Judi Dench and Bob Hoskins.
An original and outrageously funny social satire that blurs illusion with reality, it's helium-light fun for the holiday season.
Suspenseful, soulful and thought-provoking, it's relevant, incendiary and important. One of the best of 2005!
Staged like stale Broadway theater, something has gone awry between the stage and the screen.
Rarely have I seen such a maudlin, manipulative, mean-spirited mess masquerading as a holiday comedy.
Anthony Hopkins channels Steve McQueen as his sly, warm, quirky charm elevates this cheery curmudgeon's journey to an endearing, spiritual odyssey.
An inventive, sweetly satirical, fun-filled family diverson.
A powerful, tormented exploration of the masculine myth of the American cowboy, filled with haunting, heartfelt anguish.
Scary and sensational - simply the most spectacular creature feature ever made!
It's allegorical and imaginative, although literary subtlety is lost to the patently obvious.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A wry, raunchy, engaging, adult-aimed comedy about a delightfully dysfunctional family - a real crowd-pleaser.
Are you really willing to pay full fare just to see Charlize Theron do backflips in skintight S&M outfits?
While frantic and familiar, it's an 88-minute, family-friendly diversion that should have a longer life on video shelves than in theaters.
Humorous, bittersweet drama, proving that family can be found where you least expect it.
A powerful political thriller, striking a resonating chord with the oil-connected news that unfolds every day.
Vibrant, energetic, exuberantly powerful
Neil Jordan's gender-bending again in this picaresque tale of a small-town Irish lad who becomes a transvestite, played by Cillian Murphy, whose versatility is astonishing!
Sumptuous and exotic, this Asian Cinderella story unveils an ancient, refined tradition - albeit at a sluggish pace - and stars three exquisite actresses.
This cheerless, tiresome sequel is so tastless and flimsy that it proves big families aren't much fun after all.
Malick relishes poetic imagery the way others devour plot and characters. This is lyrical, meditative and sumptuous but sleep-inducing, like "Pocahontas" minus the songs.
This violent horror picture is gratuitously vicious, gruesome and repulsive. Don't say you weren't warned!
High-test Diesel makes the bad guy into the good guy! Go figure!
Cutsey and wholesome, filled with silly, superficial slapstick, it turns out to be far more cheesy than it should.
Volatile and vehement as a timely cautionary tale, it emerges as the first exciting, significant and, potentially, the most controversial film of 2006.
Aja confuses suspense with shock, sacrificing the former for the latter. it's a radioactive waste of time.
As date movies goe, this misanthropic misfire is briefly amusing but instantly forgettable.
Tim Allen wreaks hilarious havoc with an uncanny canine-like performance.
An amusing, sweet 'n' spunky friendship tale - if you're a 'tween. If you're older, this may be too soggy and sappy for you.
It's a taut escapist tale - and not until afterwards do you realize how absurd the concept is with its contrived, clock-ticking deadline.
As an entertainment consumer reporter, I can save you money right now. Don't by a ticket to see this movie! It's only February but it's a contender for one of 2006's Worst.
Parents should know that it's too scary for very young children and be prepared that some dogs do die in this live-action animal adventure.
Steve Martin humiliates himself in thie dreadful reincarnation of Inspector Jacques Clouseau. It's an acute embarrassment.
While Harrison Ford gives an authenticity to good guy roles that many younger actors can't come close to, this is cliche-ridden, formulaic and predictable.
Put this inane remake on your "do not call" list.
It's a formulaic, feel-good military drama,but be aware that its TV commercials tout non-existent scenes.
A dreadful debacle made wors by Lawrence's promise/threat: 'Keep a lookout. You never know when Big Momma might be back.'
Whimsical Nanny McPhee is the most magical child minder to come along since Mary Poppins.
A poignant, old-fashioned, history-heavy forbidden romance
Grappling with cliches, it's a sappy slam-dunk, formulating yet another slick underdog sports story.
It's a grotesque, repellent, macabre costume drama. If you want depravity, watch re-runs of the mini-series "Rome" on HBO.
This last sophisticated, meticulously crafted Merchant/Ivory production is polished and elegant with refined, impeccable performances.
A simple, stoic, well-structured contemporary Western that brings a humanist point of view to bigger issues.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Unabashedly poignant, it's a moody, gritty gangster saga with a stark sense of reality.
I wonder what those MPAA members who gave this a PG-13 were smoking. Filled with crude, raunchy sexual references, it should have been R-rated.
Formulaic but family-friendly revision and updating of the familiar coming-of-age drama.
Tasteless, toxic re-hash of the original
Wryly clever comedy - and it wouldn't surprise me if it augured Oscar nomination #8 for Peter O'Toole and, perhaps, a win.
Subtle and non-judgmental, "Flags of Our Fathers" and "Letters from Iwo Jima" examine history within its context and emerge as strikingly effective anti-war statements.
"The last thing to age on somebody is their heart" - says it all.
Meditative, slow-paced examination of how post-traumatic stress syndrome affects two troubled people who connect on a windswept oil rig in the Irish Sea.
What is worse: the theft of material possessions or the theft of someone's heart? That's the intellectually engaging premise.
More of a film-school exercise than a satisfactory cinematic experience, it's stylishly self-conscious, a stilted artifice, a mildly engrossing melodrama.
This beloved, quintessentially American children's tale weaves sheer magic, becoming the best family film of the year.
This optimistic, rags-to-riches, father/son relationship story becomes a heartwarming, inspirational holiday fable.
Dazzling - one of the Best Pictures of 2006. It could rival "Chicago" in the upcoming Oscar race. It's that good!
Lurid, lavish eye-candy
Admittedly, this is a chick-flick. Guys may groan but gals are gonna love it. Like 'Love, Actually,' it's the Christmas comedy you've been waiting for.
Mayan culture excelled in mathematics, astronomy, art and urban planning but Mel's only interested in its savage cruelty and sadistic barbarity.
It's exciting and adventurous. Leonardo DiCaprio's forceful maturity is a revelation.
A glossy, cinematic creche.
Flimsy and fumbling - bah, humbug!
Intense and intriguing, it's an action-packed techno-thriller that makes you think.
Perverse, pretentious and tiresome fantasy - with a narrow, hallucinogenic depth of field.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Audaciously spiritual and original - and just because you can't figure it out doesn't mean that there's not something interesting going on.
Daniel Craig embodies the cold, callous, calculating Ian Fleming spy - and it all adds up to terrific escapist entertainment.
Poignant yet fragmented - with trivial, star-studded subplots - it unabashedly idealizes RFK, presenting him in an almost saintly light.
Tedious at 89 minutes, the entire concept could be subtitled: The Joy of Vandalism. It's a terminally boring layover.
The dancing penguins flip in with fun, putting a smile on your face and a song in your heart - a Heartsong.
Prepare to be magically transported to another world by this alluring, magnificent melodrama that unfolds in pre-revolutionary China.
Silly, shamelessly derivative slapstick - but at least it's family-friendly hyperactivity.
A murky, flawed thriller that just doesn't add up.
A subtle, suspenseful espionage thriller
The most heartwarming, enchanting family film since Stand By Me, October Sky and E.T.: The Extra-Terrestrial. It's the first 'must-see' movie of 2007.
Fleeting and superficial, it's the familiar, cliche-riddled show biz rise and fall with banal notes about substance abuse and the price of fame.
An indubitably delightful date movie
The psychobabble sympathy card doesn't play well here.
Believe me when I tell you not to see this unless you're subpoenaed. It's that bad!
Sloppy, slapstick, son-of-"Pulp Fiction"...it's a sucker bet!
The predictable concept strains credulity. Throw it back!
As inspirational football movies go, this well-intentioned but disappointing effort sputters and stalls, like putting coal in a tattered Christmas stocking.
Sanctimonious and slow-paced, it's 111 ponderous minutes of retribution and, eventually, forgiveness.
Frenetic, raucous, exhilarating fable about finding your place in a group.
An abusive, shallow, sleazy gangsta film that, at best, is a cautionary morality tale.
One of the most fascinating, imaginative yet darkly disturbing political fables of our time.
Contrived yet inspirational - about transforming anger and apathy into creativity.
Bleak and baleful, recommended only if you're into sinister desolation.
Bizarre, macabre fantasy that's intoxicating but repellent.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Charming and whimsical, it offers a glimpse into the life of a literary icon.
Intense and ironic, it's a compelling story of trust and betrayal.
Full-throttle futuristic thriller - a whopper of a heart-kicker!
An inspiring documentary, proving that the American Dream is still alive and that the human spirit is, indeed, indomitable.
Timely and unappetizing, it illustrates the folly of unsavory consumption but laid-back Richard Linklater lacks the necessary caustic tone to make a lasting impact.
It's the trippy process of storytelling that counts.
Slick and sweet but superficial and only occasionally intoxicating.
This supernatural story doesn't muster much horror, much less tap into the thriller aspect.
Plot threads get tangled in a florid web of confusion, and the cast's tawdry, melodramatic antics often evoke unintentional amusement.
This tepid celebration of binge drinking goes flat fast.
Perversely sordid, some of the creepy soft-core scenes cross the lurid line of bad taste.
A reckless, relentless rush that goes nowhere in an exhausting 83 minutes.
Ben Affleck exudes sleaziness, Diane Lane is slyly manipulative and Adrien Brody scores as the scummy gumshoe...it's an enigmatic and intriguing tale.
Subversive, sophomoric comedy
This lavishly romantic tale of magic and mystery is utterly spellbinding, teasing and tantalizing you with the truth while juggling smoke and mirrors.
Yes, they're still making a few timeless, sentimental family films the way they used to - with no CGI.
No sappy sports cliche or trite inspirational slogan is ignored.
This repitilian horror thriller is the stuff of which nightmares are made.
Formulaic story, filled with flashy, toe-tapping interludes...
Somber and life-affirming, intense yet respectful, it marks the five-year anniversary of the terrorist attack.
A mindless, tense fright-fest
Silly, squealing spoof of dopey daredevils who clearly have a few lug nuts loose.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's fitting that kaleidoscopic images introduce this psychological thriller in which reality and fantasy collide and splinter into cinematic fragments.
Tepid teen revenge fantasy
A fun-filled, enormously entertaining fable about family, friendship and fair play
It's style over substance in this explosive, shoot 'em up that tries to make up with fast pace and visceral atmosphere what it lacks in characterization and coherence.

movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gravity-defying, action-packed family comedy - it's chop-socky fun.
It's a savage, tediously exaggerated "SNL" lampoon that misfires.
It's visually sumptuous and intriguing but its lack of tonal consistency makes it often incoherent and emotionally inaccessible.
To describe this as 'bleak' and 'brutal' is an understatement.
While Steve Carell is a natural as secret agent Maxwell Smart, pairing him with 20 years younger Anne Hathaway is a major miscalculation. And the humor just misses by THAT much.
A dark fantasy/horror tale, it's chaotic yet spectacular.
Steamy, sumptuous and sensual, filled with post-feminist sexual politics. Think of a 19th century "Fatal Attraction" in French.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Uplifting, finger-snapping, energetic fun - meaning "Money, Money, Money" at the box-office.
Utilizing an inane, effects-driven script, it's filled with brutal, blood-splattered vehicular mayhem.
It's the most amusing wine aficionado film since 'Sideways.'
While the Force may falter on the big-screen, 'Clone Wars' should do far better this fall as a new, half-hour weekly TV series, starting Oct. 3rd on the Cartoon Network.
Ranking far below the adaptations of "The Ring" and "The Grudge," this Asian horror film re-make is simply ludicrous.
While Nanette Burstein's naturalistic approach is admirable, the results are stereotypical, capturing a feeling of authenticity despite some obvious staging.
Ben Stiller's audacious spoof of war movies is - without doubt - the summer's funniest comedy, sending up Hollywood egos.
A compassionate, cross-cultural chronicle of humanity beseiged by hard times.
Exhilarating and engrossing
Much of the silly, half-baked humor is based on the smug idea that watching clumsy stoners being high is amusing but, unless you're joining them, it isn't.
A distractingly kaleidoscopic look at four familiar coming-of-age adventures.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A witty, cleverly crafted meditation on love - in all of its many fascinating permutations.
Despite its disturbing inconsistencies, this gently satirical, Frank Capra-esque riff on the political process is a melodramatic civics lesson.
Didn't anyone realize that 39 year-old Brendan Fraser couldn't play the father of 27 year-old Luke Ford? With this noisy, frenetic, futile installment, it's time to wrap the 'Mummy' franchise.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Intelligently adapted and impeccably directed with superb performances, it's a pensive, melancholy evocation of the far-better mini-series that's now available on DVD.
This tough, uncompromising, cautionary thriller should be a wake-up call about America's outrageously archaic laws insofar as defending the sanctity of home and family.
Don't be fooled by the family-friendly collapsing bunk-bed trailers! This is a crude, grossly vulgar, comedic rumination on contemporary parenting and sibling rivalry.
A decidedly disapppointing, if occasionally diverting, digitally animated feature.
There are no alien abductions, no space invaders, no conspiracy theories, nolthing spooky or supernatural - just a routine crime drama, like "C.S.I.: West Virginia."
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's an action-filled crime drama revolving around a dangerous, demented anarchist. Once again, the Joker's wild!
Poignant and subtle, it tackles cross-cultural conflict and racial intolerance.
Tedious time-waster that apologizes to its family-friendly audience with, 'Sorry, Earth, sometimes No. 2 happens!'
Unevenly paced yet morally complex, it dredges the depths of a legacy of responsibility and culpability.
Who would have thought that Dirty Harry would become not only one of Hollywood's most respected filmmakers but also one of its most compassionate humanists? At 78, Eastwood still commands the screen.
Mickey Rourke makes an amazing comeback, delivering an iconic, Oscar-caliber performance.
A haunting, suspenseful coming-of-age tale, giving a tender, unique twist to the bloodsucking genre that dates back to the classic 1922 'Nosferatu.'
Fitful and flighty, it's a frenetic diversion destined for a popular niche on the dvd shelf.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Pow! Blast! Annhilate! The action-packed, bullet-riddled popcorn pictures have officially arrived.
Blending elements of 'Talk Radio' with '28 Days,' it's not your usual zombie picture.
Evocative and intriguing, spiced by lush, radiant movie clips illustrating the Sherman brothers' glorious legacy of music.
movie_title: The Boys: The Sherman Brothers' Story (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Here's the problem: Mark Ruffalo and Adrien Brody are not Paul Newman and Robert Redford. They'd like to be and the plot has undertones of 'The Sting.' But they aren't - and it isn't.
Admittedly implausible and a bit confusing, it is, nevertheless, enthralling - with enough unexpected twists to keep you on the edge-of-your-seat.
Stage-struck and sentimental, it shows what these earnest, passionate performers still do for love.
Uneven, incoherent and flimsy - and obviously influenced by the success of by "Knocked Up" - it explores the silly, sweet side of stalking.
J.J. Abrams has done the impossible: not only resurrected the 'Star Trek' franchise, a concept built on space-age idealism, but also re-imagined it for cynical 21st century moviegoers.
Why would anyone want to see such utterly dismal, terminally dreary drivel with characters no one cares about?
Despite its noble anti-war, enviornmental message, it's cliched and formulaic. Unless the kids are clamoring, wait for the dvd.
Inconsistent and surly, filled with superfluous sound 'n' fury but signifying very little.
While this farcical dramedy is bemusing and beguiling, it's two-time Oscar-winner Michael Caine's graceful, subtly nuanced performance that lingers in the memory.
Ephemeral, ridiculously amusing 'date movie' that will evaporate before summer.
A ludicrous psychodrama that offers vicarious thrills, particularly the highly-publicized, climactic catfight.
Adrenaline-propelled and outrageously offensive, it's a cinematic video game that's neither coherent nor credible.
If your family enjoys this kind of entertainment, do yourself a favor and rent the BBC's "Planet Earth" from which most of the spectacular footage was lifted.
A film of enormous integrity, it's exquisitely acted, beautifully written, sensitively filmed and filled with memorable moments.
Sinister but somewhat incoherent, lacking in credibility.
This timelessly universal wish-fulfillment tale unfolds with endearing tenderness and a light touch.
Timely and terrifying, this investigative, sobering documentary reveals how our corrupt medical system, influenced by insurance companies, has failed patients in need.
Whether you view it in 3-D or 2-D, you and your family are in for a terrific, fun-filled ride. Without doubt, 'Up' is the best movie so far this year.
Schlocky and spooky, it's a disturbing terror thriller with an unusually loud soundtrack.
Crude, offensive and amateurish, it exhibits all the wrong moves since the nimble bits are in the trailer.
Something went terribly awry with this wannabe teen comedy from Chris Columbus.
Stomach-churning yet persuasively necessary - but don't plan to go out to dinner after viewing this graphic documentary.
If you're looking for ferocious, visceral suspense, Kathryn Bigelow delivers with this graphic, subversive portrait of courage under fire, as adrenaline junkies get high on danger.
Compellingly haunting human tale of survival that just happens to be set in outer space.
Frigidly sluggish yet familiarly diverting
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's all about the wicked game of seduction, but there's a distinct unease about Pfeiffer's performance that permeates and dilutes this sophisticated yet poignant concept.
Whether it's outrageously offensive or offensively outrageous, it's laugh-out-loud funny.
Awesome, action-packed and enthralling...
What an agonizing, misguided, maudlin mess!
Thou shalt avoid it like the plague - at least until the dvd is released.
'The difference between men and boys is the size of their toys'...and the epic length and cacophany of their thrill rides.
Never underestimate the pleasure of a sparkly screwball comedy - and a fluffy puppy.
Slow-moving, shallow and satirical, it's primarily populated by caricatures, not characters.
Larry David makes a terrific alter-ego for Woody Allen in this familiar farce, advocating a non-judgmental attitude about the diverse choices people make to find happiness.
It's disappointing that it's only mildly amusing.
Jessica Biel has such a contemporary sensibility that she's more than a fish-out-of-water in Noel Coward's 1920s comedy of manners and moral - she's a feminist-out-of-century.
Updated for 2009, this enthralling subway heist thriller grabs you and never lets go. It's all about greed and money.
Intellectually fascinating but fails to engage on a deeper level. Best suited for TV's educational channels and media libraries.
Unfortunately, Nia Vardalos's cleverly titled comedic vehicle is too filled with cheesy feta and, therefore, falters.
Tiresome, repetitive and time-warped, the title says it all.
Raunchy and ruthlessly naughty, it's all buzz, no headache.
An authentic, timely "immigrant experience" tale about trying to score.
Strange, stylized and sordid, it deals with lurid, repugnant relationships.
Imagine! It's an amusing, high-spirited romantic picture about senior citizens. What will they think of next?
Sweet-natured, amiable and appealing.
Long on style, short on substance and logic, it's baffling and frenetic, defeated by its own chaotic cleverness.
Bright 'n' breezy, conveying a pop-psychology message about hope, picking up the pieces, starting over and moving on.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Scary and sinister, aimed at children age eight or over...and be sure to view it in 3-D because that's where the creepy magic is hidden.
Frank Langella and Elliot Gould lend gravitas to this enigmatic cat-and-mouse game which unfolds far too slowly with not enough of a dramatic payoff.
Predictably formulaic romantic comedy that's as bleak as the Minnesota-in-winter landscape
This exploitive jaunt to the City of Lights is brutal, intense - and soon forgotten.
This folklore-filled children's story about the love of literature is disappointing because of its poor execution.
It's a trivial pursuit, slathered with peanut butter.
The funniest Bridezilla moments are in the trailer; if you've seen that, you've seen the movie.
Gritty and intense, it reveals the ugly, soft underbelly of the Mafia-type organization that rules Naples and its environs.
Inexplicable, eclectic and esoteric, it's a sardonic turn-off to a mainstream audience.
Deceptively simple and poetic, yet surreal and complex, it's a portrait of a man in conflict with himself.
It's earnest and intense but it's a shame they didn't tell - as Paul Harvey would say - the rest of the story.
Visionary Frank Miller falls flat here, sacrificing a potential franchise. Give up on this hyper cartoon-like ghost!
An imaginative idea that's never fully developed.
Thoughtful and incendiary, stressing the ever-increasing threats to civil liberties in the name of national security.
Hoplessly bleak and disturbingly detached, this dissection of a doomed marriage is saved by Kate Winslet's formidable performance.
Tantalizing, touching and timeless - an epic fable revolving around mortality.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A dour, barely adequate adaptation of Kate DiCamillo's Newberry Medal-winning book. Unless you're desperate to get the kids out of the house, wait for the dvd.
It's banal and inane; Jim Carrey needs better projects.
Charming and sentimental, delightful celebrating the hope for midlife love.
Angry, grisly, gory - and totally predictable in the creepy slaughter genre.
Frenetic and far-fetched, it's an intense, often incoherent indictment of insidious capitalism.
Silly yet crowd-pleasing and forgiveness-themed.
Edgy and exploitive, this vigilante story earns its R-rating for pushing the acceptable boundaries of crude, dark comedy - but it's not for mainstream audiences.
There's an intriguing twist to this puzzling escape-from-prison drama, as Brian Cox's convincing performance propels the flasbback/flashforward suspense.
Inspired by the Amazing Kreskin, it's a poignant, gently satiric portrait of the utter desperation of a fading celebrity.
You don't need a road map to conclude this franchise has run out of gas and is going nowhere.
Gently ghoulish and bittersweet
Even though it's a local curiosity here in Connecticut, it's predictably hokey and formulaic.
Visually awesome and eye-popping, particularly if you catch it in IMAX 3_D.
A gross-out comedy aimed at dudes who dig crude slapstick along with sporadic, if superficial shock value.
Apocalyptic sci-fi thrillers are supposed to be thought-provoking and supernaturally suspenseful, but this is just paranormally dopey.
Despite its obvious contrivances, it's cornball sci-fi fun.
Slick, sneaky, snarky fun - a devilish double-cross
How curious and somehow sad that Joaquin Phoenix has decided to retire from acting just when he delivers yet another impressive performance.
Filled with psychobabble, it comes across as a muddled melodrama about entitled elitists.
It's haunting and troubling, therapeutically transforming home movies into visual art.
Whimsically entertaining but all too familiar and formulaic.
Intense, ultra-violent, eerie and awesome, it's aimed primarily at a young male audience familiar with the blood-stained smiley face.
In this contrived illegal-immigration drama, the stereotypical characters and structured story lines keep crossing and bumping into each other.
The biggest mystery is how this high-tech whodunit-gone-awry got a theatrical release and didn't go directly to dvd.
For its intended 'tween audience, it's high-decible and shreik-inducing, but it's not recommended for anyone over the age of 30.
It's an adolescent boy's callow pom-pom fantasy.
Earns top marks for creating its own truth.
If you're old enough to drive yourself to the theater, this is not for you. But if you have a 'tween girl living in your household, for her, it's a must-see.
The most unforgettable, electrifying German film in more than a decade.
While expoliting our fear of random house invasion, there's no excuse for careless continuity and illogical behavior. Sloppy cinematic details diminish the scare factor.
Not a high point in stoner comedies, the snickering filmmakers miss their chance to take on racial profiling in the war on terror. Bongs away!
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Cleverly conceived and subversive, it's certainly the best Simpsons Movie - so far.
Uplifting, redemptive, crowd-pleasing sports drama
Slyly sensual and succulent, it's a deliciously delectable froth in which food is the metaphor for love and life.
Astonishing and adventurous, notably for its spectacular photography.
Anytime you emerge from the theater praising the scenery more than the scenes, there's a serious problem with the picture.
Raunchy, testosterone-driven Adam Sandler comedy with a relevant message about tolerance and acceptance.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Bouncy and campy, a cotton-candy entertainment feast.
Stunning, gripping and adventurous, giving new meaning to The Big Bang.
Subtle and sinister - it's evil, yes, but not very scary.
Trashy and incompetent - it's one of the worst movies of the year.
Intensely visceral and violent, it's not for the faint-hearted.
For sci-fi excitement and escapist, fast-paced action, you can't beat this. It's spectacularly loud, fun-filled and wicked cool.
A droll, amusing cautionary tale about the chances of living "happily ever after" - and wait for the zany outtakes during the final credits.
Despite the intriguing casting, this stultified generational drama fades into a luminous meditation on mortality.
A solid popcorn picture - primarily because the stunts are spectacular.
Captivating, inventive and souffle-light...family audiences will eat it up!
It's not a perfect movie but it will make you think - and the conversations you'll have afterwards are worth far more than the price of admission.
This only mildly amusing sequel is stultifying, self-righteous, sanctimonious - desperately needing divine intervention.
Timely and morally complicated, it captures the desperation and intensity of the tragic five-week manhunt for Daniel Pearl.
The dialogue is dumb drivel, the acting is atrocious and the bodaciously buff title character looks like a shiny hood ornament.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's kind of like "Star Wars: Episode I," perhaps the weakest chain in the link but necessary as a transition to the next two installments.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Smarmy, lasciviously trashy, butt-kicking bikini-jiggle fest
One of those savvy, low-budget crowd-pleasers that arrive in local theaters only via film festivals like San Sebastian and Sundance.
It's a bland, stilted, stuffy costume drama masquerading as a chick flick.
Academy Award season is offically underway with the release of Paul Haggis' hard-hitting drama, exploring the emotional wreckage of the war in Iraq.
"The naked bathhouse fight is perhaps the most eagerly anticipated scene in this brutal Cronenberg thriller - but there's more to it than that."
When a film runs 2 hrs. 40 min., it's often because the writer is directing - so there's no one to tell him to trim 40 min. - or else!
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Ron Zombie's "re-imagining" of John Carpenter's slasher classic has made mincemeat of far better films at the box-office, so it's impossible to ignore.
Phantasmagorical! It's a unique - if incoherent - counterculture voyage to nowhere. All you need is love, man.
Compelling, politically provocative, action-packed entertainment with a timely plot plucked from current events. There is a bit of a problem, though.
The only redeeming aspect is that it skewers those sweat-suited sadists we all remember from gym class, but is that satisfaction really worth the price of admission?
A cynical political thriller about reckless TV journalists-turned-bounty hunters, highlighting the absurdity of war.
Almost tortuously high-tension and exciting, it switches gender with Charles Bronson's "Death Wish."
Perhaps the strongest in the escapist espionage series.
Offering frenetic, absurdist, over-the-top violence, it's a silly, smarmy, shell-shocked live-action cartoon.
Exploitive and overwrought with extreme violence - one of the worst movies so far this year.
Banal and disappointing, this screen adaptation of the satirical chick-lit novel misses so many chances to be funny and makes 'perfection' look pretty bleak.
Galloping and gritty, it's an authentic Western with cynical, contemporary touches.
This once-amusing East-West globe-trotting franchise has become formulaic but that probably won't discourage loyal fans from lining up at the box-office.
It's an enchanting sword 'n' sorcery fairy tale - this summer's playful 'date movie,' culminating in a glowing "happily ever after."
Its humor derives from the campers' toilet and digestive tract malfunctions - truly tedious, except, perhaps, for matinee moppets with indulgent parents.
A silly, sputtering, goofball comedy gone gooey.
"Awesomely" tacky live-action feature based on the popular fashion floozies.
Silly, screwball comedy - for those who enjoy droll British humor.
It's like a 'Saturday Night Live' skit stretched out to a cheesy, mind-numbing 90 minutes.
Quaint and campy, seet yet clueless, it's an odd combination.
Laid-back and meandering.
Move over, Spidey, Shrek and Sparrow...Danny Ocean's back in Vegas! This romp is one of this summer's guiltiest pleasures.
Convoluted moral ambiguity can be very unsatisfying in this techno-thriller.
Dull and forgettable, relentlessly extending this family comedy franchise.
Scruffy, spirited, family-friendly comedy with too many flatulence jokes and pooch-related puns.
When a thriller starring two-time Oscar-winner Hilary Swank sits on the shelf for a year, it's usually because it's cinematic rubbish.
Hyper-sleazy and deliberately cliche-filled, it's an affectionate homage to the deliberately tawdry exploitation movies of the 1960s and '70s.
Chronicle of a 1970's deception yet relevant because it cleverly parallels contemporary media scams and governmental cover-ups.
This silly, satirical comedy glides in, skating on thin ice.
Frenetic and fanciful - with a confusing "moving forward" plot that encompasses abandonment, adoption, embarrassment and vengeance.
An edgy, darkly engaging crime caper that's also a taut psychological thriller.
Intense, intriguing, challenging and provocative - it's hard to stop thinking about.
If you're a fan of Stanley Kubrick or just a die-hard film buff, you may find this weird, semi-documentary an absolute hoot. I did.
A bizarre, mind-bending psychological thriller, filled with red herrings.
With its spiritual and metaphysical message, this fun-filled family entertainment goes far beyond whimsy.
A crass mid-life crisis comedy that becomes an improbable, uneven rumination about love on the rocks.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a pointless race against time.
Wholesome and inspirational, it preaches a simplistic "prosperity gospel."
How do you condense an eight-hour BBC-TV series into a 43-minute large-format movie? With great difficulty. Too much information in too little time.
Quote not available.
Instead of "Prepare for Glory!" it should be "Prepare for Gory!" It's a vividly stylized, spectacular, uber-violent video game.
Undoubtedly more fun to make than to watch, these wheezy city slickers are un-easy riders.
Resonant but angst-ridden, it's a subtle, strangely spiritual human drama that unfolds slowly, very slowly.
Bloody and brutal, evoking obvious, relevant comparisons between Ireland's internal conflicts and the ongoing civil war in Iraq.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Tense and terrifying, the mystery morphs into a violent psycho-slasher-thriller.
Whatever significance the legend had gets lost amid the repellent butchery.
Violent and implausible, it's Costner's dark field of screams.
Bleak vagabond melodrama made extraordinary by Marion Cotillard's mesmerizing performance. She doesn't play Piaf, she embodies her, lip-sync'ing to recordings.
Reprehensible, repugnant, pretentious poppycock!
It's an engaging sampler of different perspectives that never quite connect, but it does make you want to contact your travel agent as soon as possible.
Exciting and entertaining...and be patient through the long end credits for a revealing epilogue as the salty seafarers sail on.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Lady Luck fails to shine on this floundering, cliche-filled cautionary tale.
[A] melancholy, lightweight, less-than-thrilling stalker tale.
Truly scrumptious!
Indelible and uncompromising, this powerful drama about the grace and the cruelty of aging is a sensitive testament to emotional endurance.
You expect it to be crude, rude, profane and hilariously vulgar - and it doesn't disappoint.
Whimsical, quirky, strangely endearing road movie - and certainly unique!
Gruesome and suspenseful, it could be interpreted as timely commentary on U.S. overconfidence in Iraq.
A semi-satirical, sentimental comedy - for dog lovers, it could be a best-in-show.
Convoluted, contrived and cliche'-ridden, evoking Robert Frost's "Home is the place where, when you have to go there, they have to take you in."
Sigourney Weaver's piercing portrayal propels this distinctive, often comedic picture about a high-functioning autistic.
Implausible and predictable - it's a silly seer-tale. Consider this your two-minute warning.
So dreary and forgettable...watch it disappear soon.
The webslinger's nimble, the action is intense but it's not the best of the franchise.
Edgy and insightful - with the subtle shadings of a watercolor.
Short, scary and suspense-filled, it's a taut cat-and-mouse game set in a rundown motel.
Vulgar and erotic, it's a gripping drama about the Dutch underground in German-occupied Holland in the fall of 1944.
Meticulously stylized and nimbly filmed on a retrofitted Indian train, it's a spicy, lyrical cinematic feast.
Sadomasochistic and suspenseful, this erotic Chinese historical drama rightfully earns its NC-17 rating for 'explicit sexuality.'
A historical costume drama - with far more emphasis on the 'costume' than the 'drama.' And there's no excuse for such a deafening score!
More than a travelogue, this chronicles a "real life story of strength, performance and passion," offering audiences alpine thrills without the element of danger.
An outrageously raunchy romp, another audience-pleaser from Judd Apatow, who stretches farcial, vulgar silliness into outright hilarity.
Using conventional slapstick gags and inventive crosscutting, David Schwimmer scores as a creditable, if not memorable, director...but the innocuous script is totally predictable.
Neil Marshall shamelessly rips off elements from so many other action-packed, post-apocalyptic fantasies that you feel you've seen all this mayhem before - and you have!
Family-friendly doesn't have to mean dumbed-down.
Wacky and wondrous - it's bountiful fun for children of all ages.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: What makes this movie worthwhile is its depiction of a struggle of conscience. What would you do in such a situation? Would you sacrifice another life to extend your own?
While admittedly formulaic and banal, it's also a guilty pleasure for those who enjoy watching stampeding herds of woolly mammoths.
Evoking memories of 'Cinema Paradiso,' it's a gem - one of those rare films that truly touch your heart.
Clumsy and clunky, totally lacking in passion and cohesion, this dull mediocrity is an insult to Philippa Gregory's historical concept of the two rival sisters.
The goofy "My Bodyguard" premise is appealing but the execution is flimsy, formulaic and disjointed - neither the characters nor their actions are plausible. The laughs are lame.
Suspenseful, yes - but it's all too far-fetched to matter much.
Tart, smart and fun.
A plucky, whimsical romance as the ugly-duckling fantasy morphs into a satiric take on celebrity culture.
Offbeat and off-putting, unless you're really heavily into "guilt and sins and hell and all that."
Soulful and sweet-natured, this enjoyably romantic whodunit proves that living "happily ever after" isn't quite so easy.
Silly, campy and tepid - no hearts 'n' flowers here.
Geeky, gruesome and repugnant.
Clearly a vanity project, it's graphic and blood-drenched. Stay out of the jungle!
Witlessly crude and vulgar - it's my first Worst Movies of 2008 contender.
A fluffy, frivolous - if formulaic - indulgence for those of us who still enjoy the occasional, old-fashioned wedding fantasy.
It's wonderfulness on a rampage.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Problem is: 'Stop-Loss' isn't really about that legal loophole. Instead, it's about soldiers' post-traumatic stress, a subject covered far more effectively before.
Tyler Perry continues his exploration of the sense and sensbility of the African-American community with this fun-loving celebration of the possibility of second chances.
Here's the deal: this is sheer escapist entertainment - and, as such, it's a good gamble.
It's subversively eccentric and poignant but lacks the punch that fully fleshed-out characters and a more cohesive story could deliver.
Indy's back in an awesome, thrill-filled roller-coaster ride that you don't ever want to stop. It's far-fetched, fast-paced fun.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sophisticated, timely and compelling, it's a quintessential post-9/11 drama.
The coincidental plot twists are implausible, as are some of the performances. Sometimes being enigmatic just insn't as interesting as it should be.
Imaginative and visually enchanting but, remember, as Aslan says, "Things never happen the same way twice."
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Taking up where "The Da Vinci Code" left off, this enthralling documentary inflames the imagination and pushes the envelope of controversy.
As tepid romantic comedies go, they forgot to pack the fun. This one should have stayed in Vegas.
If you're into high-octane car racing, trippy Japanese anime and awesome visuals, this is spectacular, adrenaline-pumping family fare.
It's the rarest of all things: an intelligent, sophisticated romance with real meat on its bones.
It's Robert Downey Jr., having triumphed over his substance abuse battle, who puts the pedal to the metal and scores the freshest new franchise going.
It's a delightful, audience-pleasing, fun-filled fairytale of laughter and love.
So when does enigmatic become incoherent? In the hands of an inept, inxperienced director.
Stylish yet deeply sensitive, lifting your spirit. No one will come away without a smile.
It's wry and satirical but just not as hip as I was hoping. Perhaps I expected too much from two of SNL's funniest comediennes.
It's simply tedious, butt-kicking, cliche-ridden, chop-schlocky action.
It's tepid fare with a vacuous cast, particularly when compared with the previous version featuring Jamie Lee Curtis as the scream queen.
There ought to be a testosterone warning posted at the box-office because overdosing is a distinct possibility, and to call Reeves'a acting wooden is an insult to Pinnochio.
A consummate concert film but not on a calibre with Scorsese's "The Last Waltz" (1978).
Some 'smart people' can be thick as planks...and this is a fragmented, derivative, predictablly underwhelming family drama.
Over-written and awkwardly directed, it's nevertheless family-friendly, complete with flying lizards and a flatulent sea lion.
Admirably stylized but, as sports comedies go, it fumbles.
Crudely naturalistic yet innocative and effective.
What was slyly titillating in half-hour segments becomes silly, superficial and overwhemingly materialistic when stretched to nearly 2 1/2 hours. Bigger doesn't always mean better.
Cautionary environmental documentary that asserts there's more to sharks than "Jaws."
What's most remarkable in this grim, harrowing drama is the ensemble. The actors explore their characters softly, yet with chilling authenticity.
A kaleidoscopic, non-linear meditation with little coherence, it's bizarre, discordant and surreal - recommended only for Dylan devotees, definitely not a mainstream movie.
Insightful - exploring the kind of impact a former President can have after leaving the Oval Office.
Brutal and intense, it's an enigmatic, metaphysical mindgame.
What distinguishes this from other recent war movies is that it's about far more than a tragic skirmish...it's provocative entertainment that makes you think.

movie_review_blurb: Subversively satisfying, if senselessly silly sequel.
Slyly stylish sci-fi - and strangely surreal.
Abysmal! Unless you're really into techie toys, it's excruciating to watch - a tortuous endurance test.
Frenetic, fitfully fun sword-and-sandals epic, a popcorn picture that becomes a tongue-in-cheek tussle.
Weird yet strangely intriguing, posing fascinating philosophical questions, like: Does time truly exist? Why are we here? And is our essence immortal?
Engaging, yet forgettable....it's aimed at a senior-citizen audience and should enjoy a long life as a DVD.
Richard Linklater's naturalistic, bittersweet, coming-of-age alternative to studio productions.
Whimsical, entrancing and ephemeral, it should airily appeal to those who loved 'Midnight in Paris' (2011).
When audience members cheer for the ferocious killers-on-the-rampage, it really makes you wonder about our cultural values today - and society in general.
Another anthropomorphized comedic adventure - this time, aimed at boys from four-to-eight years old.
Trying to combine flaccid, family-friendly fun with a shallow sexcapade results in a total turn-off.
Unflinching and engrossing, it's an inspirational tribute to America's most influential film critic.
Puzzling and implausibly fractious, it requires interminable patience and forgiveness.
Tension-filled and visually dazzling, it stars Andy Serkis, who redefines acting in the digital age.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Tedious, dim-witted action thriller - a total waste of time.
Foul thriller, filled with depravity.
A charming comical confection and an enticing Islandic travelogue...
Charming comedy, filled with breezy Irish blarney.
"Once" again - buy the soundtrack.
Tiresome and tedious, Melissa McCarthy takes an unfortunate pratfall.
Exciting, edge-of-your-seat action thriller - a wild ride that's one of the best of the year, so far.
Sweet, if shameless update of Steven Spielberg's 'E.T.,' filled with wonder and adventure.
A frothy, only mildly amusing aperitif...
Spectacular underwater photography!
Energetic and engagingly stupid, exemplifing outrageous, intergenerational warfare.
Tepid and pretentious, it sinks in slow-paced self-indulgence....

Whimsical and poignant, serving as a showcase for Maggie Smith as the filthy, self-centered vagrant to whom "feelings of gratitude, humility and forgiveness were either foreign to her nature or had become so over the years."
Somber, somewhat insipid, yet slavishly faithful conclusion, as the Girl on Fire becomes a glowing ember.
Fueled by testosterone, it's a wannabe action-comedy caper that turns out to be neither.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Ostensibly celebrating female friendship, it's only fitfully funny.
Clumsily patched together by three writers, six editors and director Michael Bay, it's an explosion-filled, mind-numbing, $250-million Hasbro Toy promotion.
It's always a shame when superb performances get mired down in deeply flawed melodrama. Like serving a tantalizing appetizer with an indigestible meal, it's ultimately frustrating.
Sentiment reigns as the anthropomorphic vehicles take more laps around the cinematic track.
Despite superb performances, it's confounding - a misguided mess!
This underwatater thriller is suspenseful and scary - until a third act twist turns out to be ridiculous.
Simplistic and sincere - with an exquisite performance by Sally Hawkins - it's an improbable success story.
Simplistic yet compelling, giving the impression of eavesdropping on a historic conversation.
Audacious, socially-conscious allegorical fable...
Gritty, fast-paced action thriller, best suited for video viewing...
Without any sense of mystery, danger or fun, this superficial concept plays like an elaborate, expensive prologue for future films in the 'Dark Universe' franchise.
Subtly satisfying, celebrating our soldiers' canine comrades.
Brian Cox delivers an outstanding performance in this talky, repetitive docudrama, relating a questionable historical footnote.
Eleanor Coppola's slight yet savory spree serves up sumptuously seductive cuisine.
A self-sabotaging, strangely superficial portrait of a philandering couple, weighing the pros and cons of trading spouses.
Entertaining and empowering, it's the best in DC's Extended Universe. Physically perfect, Gal Gadot is strong & sexy, statuesque & stunning.
Spirited and surreal, this existential romantic comedy concludes with cosmic ambiguity.
Facile and foolish, it completely loses plausibility in the third act...
This soggy sequel sails off-course. It's a surreal shipwreck. Argh!
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Stylish and seductive, Rachel Weisz embodies the duality of du Maurier's inscrutable, yet irresistible Rachel, leaving us to wonder: Did she? Didn't she?

Awesome and elegiac, as humanity is reflected back through the apes. A 'must see' for lovers of this franchise.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Steven Soderbergh's amusing, escapist, 'Oceans 7-Eleven' heist is a blast!
On the Granger Gauge, the squirrels scurry in with a frenzied 4 out of 10 - in this back-to-school time-waster.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Spooky, scary origin story...
Penn's pompous indulgence is gruesome and gravely disappointing.
Slickly sanitized, Destin Daniel Cretton's screen adaptation of Jeanette Walls' candid memoir succumbs to sentimentality.
Sensitive and sympathetic character study, offering gentle insight into a self-segregated community.
Sordid and sadistic, it's filled with so much excessive violence that it induces revulsion, emerging as exploitative, racial torture pornography.
Fast-paced, incomprehensibly futuristic, epic indulgence...
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A frenetic, high-octane chase thriller.
A subtly savory, estrogenic potboiler that empowers the feminist perspective...
Mind-numbing cinematic malware - a total time-waster!
This forgettable sci-fi fantasy is a sullen, superficial slog.
Christopher Nolan has created the most intense, immersive war story since 'Saving Private Ryan.'
This twisted supernatural thriller is a simplistic adaptation of W.W. Jacobs' 1902 story "The Monkey's Paw."
Effective and impassioned, it urges environmentally-conscious citizens and their governments to cope with consequential challenges.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Endearing, surprisingly witty romantic comedy...perfect 'date movie.'

Atrociously tedious - What a terrible waste of time and talent!
Scrappy sequel, evoking fond memories of the adolescent angst in John Hughes' 'Ferris Bueller's Day Off."
Compassionate, character-driven story, drenched with melancholy, as Sam Elliott delivers an understated, yet Oscar-caliber performance.
Smashing, adrenaline-propelled spy thriller that's steely and stylish.
Slyly satirical, it's the first big-budget, day-and-date theatrical release that you can stay home and see.
Ridley Scott continues his splattering sci-fi franchise with another slithery creature-feature.
A revelatory, celebratory glimpse into a compelling religio-political dilemma.
A tantalizing, intense thriller...
Decline with regrets...
This psychologically provocative horror/thriller is relentlessly chaotic, filled with violent carnage.
Elegant and enchanting, it has sumptuous special effects and enhanced character backstories...
An astute, insidiously scathing, cinematic commentary on racial tension in America.
A spectacular, fun-filled creature-feature, concluding with a post-credit franchise promotion...
Awkwardly schmaltzy YA melodrama, delivering a sympathetic 'savor every moment' message about redemption and hope.
Elegiac conclusion to Wolverine's solo trilogy...
A CURE FOR WELLNESS is so grotesque; it's Gothic horror gone awry...
Sumptuous, survivalist fable. Because of its leisurely, dreamlike pace, I suspect its appeal will be more to adults than children.
Compassionate, if shallow, it's an inspiring geopolitical biopic.
A silly, subversive spin-off, energetically played for laughs.
This epic, $150 million action/adventure/fantasy is a sumptuous visual spectacle...
Subtly stoic, it's a melancholy meditation.
Trashy and tawdry, tarnishing the luster of Valentine's Day...
Unpredictable and exuberant, it's wildly rebellious and absurdly redemptive.
Tiresome and tepid. My advice? Don't watch it.
Too bad this sweet, teenage sci-fi adventure/romance only achieves a lukewarm launch.
Suspenseful and subversive, revealing the seedy underbelly of "La La Land."
Savage yet spiritual, a dour depiction of an agonized, seemingly endless pilgrimage.
In Farsi with English subtitles, it's an engrossing, empathetic commentary on contemporary Iranian society.

How many ways can I say 'un-funny' and 'stupid'?
Slick, yet silly reboot - scheming for franchise possibilities.
Ominously undercooked and unbalanced, this epicurean feast culminates in an infuriatingly enigmatic conclusion.
There's little fractious, familiar chemistry between Hawn and Schumer, so I'd advise cancelling this flashy, flimsy trip...
Fractured and fumbling, it unfolds like a frantic video game...

movie_review_blurb: A schmoozing, cautionary tale about ambition gone awry.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Although the fast-paced plot is convoluted, there are intergalactic battle sequences galore and lots of zany humor.
Sleekly sinister satire, evolving into a cautionary tale...
Sly, bittersweet romantic comedy - with a tasteful feminist twist.
Suspenseful yet sedately spiritual, it's yet another addition to Disneynature's circle of life.
Flimsy, frustrating - and quite forgettable...
James Gray's sprawling, yet superficial adventure saga about an explorer obsessed with Amazon River exploration a century ago.

Slow-paced, yet sporting biopic about Scottish pioneers of the modern game of golf.

Perceptively subtle and satisfying, it packs an emotional punch.

Helmed by Werner Herzog with that heavyweight cast, it should have been so much better.
Powerful, visually spectacular, action-packed murder mystery.

Bill Pullman's performance propels this satisfying, old-fashioned oater...

movie_review_blurb: Starry-eyed and showy, it's splashy and synthetic
Subtly stirring and sensitive drama - about a sensuous summer that could change the course of a boy's life.

Suspenseful thriller/character study, featuring a smoldering, persuasive performance by Christopher Plummer.

Familiar and formulaic, including the outtakes during the final credits.
Tedious - it's a total waster of time and talent...
Sugary & syrupy - with a rockin' soundtrack...
Enlightening, inspiring, sci-fi allegory for our times - one of the year's best!
Spectacularly surreal, it's an awesome introduction to a fascinating Marvel character...
Intense and viscerally stunning, idealized and idiosyncratic, it illuminates the first conscientious objector awarded the Medal of Honor.
Florid and flawed, compressing Philip Roth's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel into tawdry melodrama.
Elegant and erotic, an elusive, yet exquisite example of sybaritic Asian cinema.
Savvy & wryly sardonic, depicting the fragility of adolescent angst without being self-conscious...
Although Ron Howard and Tom Hanks have collaborated successfully before, this adaptation of Dan Brown's thriller is frenzied and inane, fumbling the franchise.
Frightful comedy, filled with vulgar slapstick and a mockery of child abuse disguised as 'a good whuppin.'
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Spooky supernatural story - for those who enjoy being scared.
This wannabe satirical action/spy caper goes nowhere at a tedious pace - don't bother...
Gritty and suspenseful - filled with intense action.
These veteran actresses deserve better material than this predictable, cliche-riddled script.
So fragmented and contrived that it doesn't add up....
Subtly scrappy, a rambling, often repetitive road picture, depicting a slice of Americana.
Flimsy, fragmented - and quite frustrating.
Somber and suitably shaming, yet it lacks a satisfying showdown moment...
Meditative and soulful, occasionally stunning in its bleak silence.
Engaging and enchanting, a fun-filled return to the wizarding world....
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Enlightened and empowering, introducing a new Disney heroine.
Usually insightful Ang Lee fumbles on this one - with shallow dialogue, inconsistent satire and stilted pacing.
This time-tripping, sci-fi fantasy rarely rises above incoherence.
Sober, by-the-numbers docudrama, simplistically concluding that tragedy can bring out the best in everyone.
Slick and slyly sleazy, revealing the Faustian bargain that created one of the world's largest food corporations.
Formidable drama, depicting the essential African-American experience, featuring authentic, award-worthy performances from Viola Davis and Denzel Washington.
It's the intimate, uplifting drama you've been yearning for...
Sensitive yet snarky, observing, "Wondering if you're happy is just a shortcut to being depressed."
With likeable/bankable Chris Pratt and Jennifer Lawrence, it's a terrific sci-fi premise that, sadly, squanders its compelling castaway concept.
Blatantly crass, crude and raunchy, it's only occasionally amusing, prompting the question: Why bother?
A shivery, insightful melodrama, it's truly heartbreaking.
The stars are gone, much of the spirit has been lost, leaving only a lot more wars. So this is a space-faring, big-screen computer game with hoards of Stormtroopers.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Uplifting true story, delivering an inspiring message of hope...
Slow, sensitive and subdued - timely primarily because it paved the way for the more recent controversy over same-sex marriage.
Stylish, nostalgic farce, yet stilted - with a story that inevitably culminates in disillusionment...
Solemn and mesmerizing, propelling Natalie Portman into serious Oscar contention...
Such a disappointing sequel - proving that politically incorrect vulgarity isn't always funny.
This dense political melodrama falls flat, despite its formidable leading lady.
Sluggish, stylized and superficial...
Unabashedly twinkly and entrancing, affectionately recalling the Golden Era of Hollywood musicals.
Sleek and sophisticated, focusing on surreal passions and suspenseful revenge...
An unflinching, emotionally devastating tear-jerker.
Sweaty and scrappy with sports stereotypes and showboating sentiment...
Inspirational journey - with compassionate performances - concluding that being a winner can be a mixed blessing.
Bleak and formidable, this brutal, depressing, cautionary tale may be an actor's dream but it's an audience's nightmare: a muddled mess of a movie.
Tim Burton's adaptation of this macabre fantasy is strangely spooky, yet stylish, stumbling where it should soar.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Pierce Brosnan propels this trivial, formulaic techno-thriller. It's best to disconnect.
Sacrificing emotionally engaging character development in favor of visual, kinetic action, this familiar franchise could benefit from some lower-octane fuel...
Wistfully vintage Woody Allen - with a jazzy soundtrack worth savoring....
