Rude and crude, it's nevertheless surprisingly satiric. Its intrinsic feminism is a lot funnier than either 'Absolutely Fabulous' or 'Ghostbusters.'
Tragi-comic and sentimental - with superb performances - it's a poignant celebration of indulged eccentricity and pursuing your dreams.
Playing on the ubiquitous prevalence of the Pokemon Go phenomenon, along with the popularity of horror films, this should appeal to media-obsessed Millennials...
Colorful but tepid, making one wish for a cataclysmic disaster to melt all of them....
Swedish director David F. Sandberg makes an auspicious horror debut with this shady, sinister, supernatural story.
The farcical BBC cult sitcom was fabulous but, as a full-length feature film, it's frothy but only fair...
Slight, serene and sweet, it's a subtly calming interlude...

How many superhero comic-book movies does it take to make you yawn with boredom? If you haven't reached your saturation point, this could push you over the edge as super-heroes are replaced by super-villains...
In this exciting, explosive shoot 'em up, unfortunately, character complexity has become secondary to continual conflict - too much hardware, too little heart.
A suspenseful, stylishly slick espionage thriller - a new twist on a familiar story, distinguished by authentic performances by Bryan Cranston and John Leguizamo.
A mediocre remake that turns into slime-time for female friendship.

Admittedly, Pixar's 'Toy Story' came up with the fantasy first, but this is another sweetly spirited animated adventure that should provide a 90-minute diversion for youngsters who have already seen 'Finding Dory.'
Fascistic and subversive, appealing to the homicidal maniac lurking inside everyone who has ever experienced something as simple as road rage.
This tedious sci-fi sequel fizzles like a soggy firecracker...
Subtly stodgy, it's an engaging but ultimately forgettable espionage thriller.
Wryly amusing and enjoyable, revealing a different kind of superhero...
A strange, fart-filled, absurdist fantasy that's as bizarrely provocative as 'The Lobster,' yet not as engrossing....
Escapist and highly entertaining, this action-adventure is the best live-action Tarzan in decades...
Starkly desolate, yet compassionate story - with timely relevance for women today.
Perceptively scrappy, but the corporate intrigue lacks a satisfying payoff...
Flimsy, futuristic repression isn't much fun....
Enchantingly earnest, perhaps the best live-action, family film of the summer....
Edgy, effective drama about racism, faith and injustice - yet tainted by the filmmakers' shadow of shame.
Antoine Fuqua's action-filled, shoot-em-up remake, supplying a spectacular barrage of bullets.
Funny and frantically-paced, a perceptive commentary on the changing aspects of family, wryly emphasizing the comedic aspects of parenting, stressing nurturing and compassion.
Suspenseful 'disaster' story - with edge-of-your-seat suspense.
Bridget delivers the sparky screwball comedy that's worth waiting for...
Slick and sycophantic, glossing over the U.S. government's deplorable actions and the unintended consequences of Snowden's disclosures.
Stunning, soaring heroic adventure....
Persuasively recalling a Spanish scandal as - even today - the debate between religion and science continues...
This derivative, dismal wannabe thriller has little to offer...
Synthetic sci-fi - 'Ex Machina" did it so much better...
Tense and exciting - as Clint Eastwood, once again, proves he's a superb storyteller...
If you're in the mood for an old-fashioned, historical melodrama, this is a schmaltzy, sorrowful, heart-wrenching "weeper."
It's fumbling, fragmented and formulaic, despite the fancy footwork
If you like the horror genre, this is for you. It's scary, so inhale deeply, exhale slowly - and expect a sequel.
Subtly sweet, a heartfelt date movie - aimed specifically at an audience that relishes fictionalized famous romances, like Jacqueline Bouvier/John Kennedy & Prince Charles/Diana Spencer.
Visually stunning - delivering delightful family-friendly entertainment...
Flaccid and only fitfully funny....
Shamelessly pun-filled, sexually explicit, socio-political animation - for an adult audience.
Inspirational return to the novel's religious roots, aimed at a Christian faith-based audience.
Flat and somewhat frustrating for its failure to engage emotionally...
Admirable - but tedious - serving as a tragic reminder of the consequences of America's once-prevalent, puritanical moral conformity...
Totally trashy, several steps beyond creepy.
Sinister and surreal, it's an eerie, experimental curiousity.
With a weak, cobbled-together script, credited to a quartet of writers, it's just another a flimsy buddy-cop comedy.
An updated gory, gruesome blood bath that's far too evocative of today's grisly, real-life violence.
Engrossing and insightful, revealing the behind-the-scenes story of Mart Crowley's controversial 'Boys in the Band.'
Devilishly sleazy.
A blatant promotional and marketing tool, it's a curiously sanitized, if sycophantic documentary, examining the Bieber phenomenon from a bland, 'authorized' viewpoint.
Trivial and trite, its days are numbered.
Secretive and suspensful, this action/thriller scores as a late-winter diversion.
Fierce yet fragmented, slogging through the story of colliding cultures and one centurion's quest to regain family honor.
Soaking, slippery, subterranean mid-winter diversion, distinguished primarily by its memorably stunning visuals.
Dark, despairing and soulful, it's elevated primarily by Javier Bardem's searing performance.
A psychological thriller filled with pretentious, gruesome, cliche-riddled Satanic drivel.
Extentialist questions about predestination and free will permeate this plodding sci-fi thriller about celestial messengers intervening on mortals' search for soul mates.
A minimalist, melancholy homage to Jacques Tati - a sweetly sad tone poem that's filled with bittersweet nostalgia and exquisite imagery.
Mike Leigh's bittersweet, compassionate, slice-of-life drama shows how having a partner to share the vicissitudes of life makes the difference between loneliness and happiness.
With its role-reversing twist, it's sexy, sappy and shallow.
Revisits similar stories ('Sybil,' 'Three Faces of Eve') that have packed far more of an emotional punch.
Awe-inspiring, travelogue-like trek through hostile, challenging landscapes, it's a spectacular slog.
Irreverent and politically incorrect, it's a poignant, melancholy morality tale - with a savvy, smart, self-aware performance by Paul Giamatti.
This boorishly irreverent superhero sendup is a fiasco, sustained only by its FX.
It's the kind of emotionally challenging movie that actors relish but most audience members may find themselves anxiously looking for the EXIT sign, waiting for the excruciating two hours to go by.
Corny and cliched
A cursed abomination...as a priest observes, 'We're going to need more holy water!'
Mindless brutal mayhem, signifying very little
Smirking and awkwardly insincere, it revolves around the shocking scams of a bizarre sociopath.
Existential, inventive and irreverent
It's by-the-numbers, big-screen video gaming. Hooh-ra!
Action-packed, this is a humorless pursuit thriller with an enticing impact.
Fractured fairytale? Half-baked is more accurate.
Floundering and unfunny, somewhere between the moon and New York City, it lost its charm.
Cute-and-cuddly, filled with frantic, family-friendly bunny banter, it's nevertheless derivative of 'The Santa Clause' and 'The Tooth Fairy' - and decidedly mediocre.
Incredible and inspiring, educational and endearing
Admirable attempt - but this modernist, non-linear interpretation totally lacks a formidable leading man.
Quote not available.

Relying on familiar devices like startling sounds, ominously opening doors and incomprehensible mumbo-jumbo about astral-projection and demonic possession, it's a deja-'boo,' a waste of time and money.
Surreal and suspenseful, geared to appeal to sci-fi fans
Sensitive if sentimental, delivering a trippy, heartfelt message that echoes across the generations and decades.
An amusingly absurd Close Encounters wish-fulfillment fantasy for sci-fi fans.
A cheesy, hard-boiled police procedural, tracing its antecedents back to Raymond Chandler.
Unreeling like the discarded spawn of 'The Royal Tenenbaums,' it strikes a sour note in the increasingly overcrowded dynfunctional 'black comedy' genre.
Wry, whimsical and compassionate, it's worth a trip to the multiplex.
A clueless, pointless inanity that's destined for the DVD discard bin, while Disney's 1991 'Beauty and the Beast' remains on the top shelf.
An elegant, erudite, existential romantic fable about middle-aged second chances.
Chilling, compelling and compassionate - this cautionary tale is so realistic and provocative that it should be 'must' viewing for families with teenagers.
Even in 3D, the screen is no substitute for experiencing the energetic excitement of Michael Flatley.
Forget about the IMAX and 3-D, wait for the dvd.
Tepid, twisted re-imagining of Charles Perrault's medieval fable - but the melodramatic script never makes much sense and chemistry is entirely lacking between the heroine and her suitors.
Part fantasy fulfillment, part paranoid thriller, this is a subversive Faustian tale.
Jonathan Swift's scathing satire has been updated into a silly, slapstick, contemporary parody aimed at tiny tots.
Lewd, vulgar and tiresome...to quote from Twitter: 'I bet the Robert DeNiro of 'Taxi Driver' would shoot the Robert DeNiro of 'Little Fockers.'
'Somewhere' goes nowhere. It's an atmospheric, low-key, melancholy rumination on adult responsibility.
A mildly amusing screwball comedy, evoking a surprising amount of laughter.
It's too little, too late - sanctimonious when it could have been a far more effective expose of political malfeasance and corruption.
Divertingly splashy and mildly amusing but not very memorable.
Rowdy, raunchy road trip that probably delivers the laughs you expect until 'Hangover 2' debuts next year.
Intense, nerve-wracking and terrifying, building to an emotional climax. It's agony - sheer agony - and viscerally compelling.
Dull, disappointing, vengeance-filled conclusion to Stieg Larsson's intriguing Swedish crime trilogy.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Superbly crafted, smartly acted, suspense-filled noir thriller about compromised ethics.
Shamelessly manipulative, as the humorless, heavy-handed script only superficially skims the dramatic surface of this true story of devotion and sacrific.
It's a disgusting, repellent, sadomasochistic extension of the kind of slapstick that made 'The 3 Stooges' so popular and filled with gross, gruesome pranks that men seem to find hilarious.
An action-packed, 99-minute thrill ride that's filled with sparking metal.
Everyone interested in the welfare of children and the future of our country should see it.
Superficially supernatural, the wish-fulfillment comedy of manners and morals is not one of Woody Allen's best but an amusing diversion.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Subtle, solemn and strangely ponderous, it's exquisitely mounted but filled with chilling despair.
Shallow yet sweetly sentimental, it's a mildly amusing date movie...not exactly fresh yet not completely rotten.
This is an amusing crowd-pleaser, pitting wisdom and experience against youthful arrogance and gullibility.
Poignant and perceptive, it delves into the pop psychology behind Lennon's lyrics, 'Mother, you had me, but I never had you.'
As satisfying as it is stimulating, 'Secretariat' will make you stand up and cheer.
Somber, supernatural spooky - it's an admirable adaptation of the Swedish vampire thriller.
Now that 'The Social Network' has explored the origins of Facebook, this 'reality' documentary of online intrigue examines one of its more bizarre encounters.
A sensitive, slice-of-life, subtle drama depicting lonely people yearning to make an emotional connection.
A curiously tantalizing, melancholy meditation on mortality and the afterlife.
While intriguing and action-packed, it's far more perilous, intense and realistic than previous installments.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: No damsel in distress, this savvy, strong, spunky new Disney 3-D princess is adventurous - and awesome!
Impressively incisive and infuriating - one of the best documentaries of the year.
Powerful, provocative and poignant, it shrewdly reflects the emotional savagery of the worldwide economic meltdown of the past three years.
The Coen brothers shoot straight with a slick, surreal remake of this classic Western.
Sensitive, superbly acted, subtly disturbing chronicle of suffering and despair for those seeking a vicarious kind of catharsis.
While the characters are interesting, their emotional connections are frayed and fragmented, leaving them floundering in this complicated dramedy.
Irreverent and satirical with cocksure brilliant Kevin Spacey adroitly handling the constantly shifting, darkly absurdist allegiances.
Exuberant and inspirational, it's stikingly good.
Suspenseful and tantalzing, it's a dazzling, harrowing tale.
Technically spectacular, visually and aurally - best viewed in IMAX 3-D.
Saved by superb performances, it's really a depressing, drug-drenched melodrama disguised as a boxing movie.
Spectacularly scenic but don't expect much more than a frothy diversion, courtesy of cinematographer John Seale.
As the first installment in 3-D, it's swashbuckling - if a bit shallow.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Ambiguous, ineptly fictionalized psychological thriller that doesn't ring true, leaving the audience emotionally detached and disappointed.
An overwrought, highly-stylized, visually surreal, cliche-filled, wild and wacky kung-fu fantasy.
One of the most wretched, misguided extravaganzas ever mounted on the big screen...a stale schnitzel.
Densely-layered Australian coming-of-age thriller about the newest addition to a malevolent Melbourne crime clan.
Morally simplistic yet suspenseful, visually evocative thriller.
Saucy, scattershot, screwball farce.
Colin Firth is extraordinary and Geoffrey Rush is electrifying in this engrossing, fact-based historical drama - one of the 10 Best of 2010.
Shimmying, shaking and preposterous, it emerges as another splashy, sleazy showbiz tale, signifying very little.
Not quite focused, it's positioned as a raunchy date movie that delivers only a tiny peek into the ethics, excesses, bribery and corruption within the medical establishment.
Ambiguous, heavy-handed morality tale with a pretentious plot that's implausible.
Exhaustively researched, well acted and splendidly photographed, it's neverthless convoluted and courtroom-centric.
A hackneyed, fluffy, formulaic chick flick with fangs.
Silly and stale with far too many extraneous characters. Its multiple false endings becoming monotonous far too soon.
This compressed, stilted screen adaptation disapponts but it's not a total loss.
Tension-filled political thriller - in the same genre as 'Erin Brockovich,' 'Silkwood' and 'Norma Rae.'
Silly, savage action-adventure, filled with visceral blood-and-guts carnage.
Depressing, dreadfully disappointing dirge, culminating in maudlin melodrama.
Silly, scary re-imagining of the humor/horror vampire thriller.
Pathetically stupid - forget it!
Intriguing and inspirational, it's a beguiling film in every way.
This mindless mayhem preys on contemporary angst and uncertainty.
Original and idiosyncratic, it's a quirky glimpse of imaginative innocence.
Fake and emotionally manipulative, it's aimed specifically at fanatic Gleeks.
Suspenseful and scary, this remake is filled with spooky, supernatural terror.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This brainy sci-fi has a stimulating, haunting premise that provokes philosophical discussion afterwards.
Provocative and powerful, it's a multi-racial, multi-generational 'must see.'
The last of this summer's 'origin' stories may be one of the best...it's action-packed yet compassionate, highly recommended as escapist entertainment.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's nostalgic and kid-friendly, despite an outrageous abundance of Sony product placements to catch the attention of accompanying adults.
A poignant, impressionistically sweet coming-of-age drama
movie_title: The Myth Of The American Sleepover (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Sincere and searing, it unlocks another guilt-ridden Holocaust tale.
A tear-jerking soap opera chick flick about love and loyalty
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Affecting and amusing, reminding audiences never to give up on finding romance.
Authentic & entertaining, it pushes the envelope of frontier folklore.
Inconsistent yet reverential, it's a truly trivial pursuit.
Crass, crude and vulgar - it's a raunchy repeat of what's been done - far better - before.
Solid, stylish superhero saga that's more fun than 'Thor,' 'Green Hornet' and 'Green Lantern.'
Oozing female empowerment, acrobatic Zoe Saldana is the new action star to watch.
It's a tedious faux documentary, filled with schlocky sound-effects and jarring cuts, utilizing TV actors masquerading as astronauts.
Family-friendly, inspirational action drama with a recycled Wii-redemption.
This remake rocks with toe-tapping adolescent angst.
This intelligently written, beautifully photographed, intensely emotional family drama is among the best of 2011 and should earn George Clooney an Oscar nomination.
Cynical and sophisticated, it slides down the slippery slope of contemporary corruption.
This raunchy, smutty female comedy adds up to very little.
Tiresome and tedious, it's destined to foreclosure.
Emotionally cathartic serio-comedy, ending on a convincingly upbeat note.
Fantatical horror/thriller, focused on Christian fundamentalists with a sinister agenda.
Far more than a baseball movie, it's already generating terrific Oscar buzz.
Combines the suspense of a political thriller with international espionage and a smattering of social commentary about the fallibility of our veneration of heroes.
Subtly sweet and compassionate, appealing to art-house filmgoers of a certain age.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This mucho macho testosterone-propelled action thriller is undermined by its formulaic execution.
Inspiring, feel-good, family-friendly adventure with a special appeal to youngsters who love animals.
Educational and stimulating, hopefully encouraging environmental support for the world's endangered reefs.
An artsy, self-conscious, existentialist stillness reigns - or, more accurately, tedium. Hyper-stylish, it idles in, then stalls out.
SJP's superficial balancing act predictably collapses.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Intense, ambiguous and exciting, Rod Lurie's remake of Peckinpah's psychological thriller keeps you transfixed with terror.
Writer/director/actor Marcus Dean Fuller would have been better served having some collaborators on this metaphysical fable.
An all-too-terrifying bio-thriller that realistically taps into our most primal fears and survival instincts.
Amusingly subversive, it's filled with nasty, impudent Irish humor.
Sweaty yet sentimental slug-fest, delivering a knockout punch
Lovable and sweet - it's delightful to spend time again with that silly old bear.
A dark, deeply deranged comedy.
The fast-paced, spectacular conclusion ties the final knot in the narrative thread of this spellbinding series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Explosive and adventurous origin story, a prequel that takes the superhero outsiders back to their roots.
Imaginative and illuminating, demonstrating that children often have no idea about what went on in their parents' lives during the formative years before they were born.
Spectacular and absorbing,coinciding with the publication of Jean Auel's "The Land of Painted Caves."
This emotionally resonant, character-driven, action-packed sequel is awesome!
Not rotten - just not fresh - following its own raunchy, shenanigan-filled formula.
This low-key dramedy paints a cinematic portrait of self-destruction with, perhaps, a hopeful glimmer of redemption.
Creepy, pulpy and shamelessly derivative sci-fi.
Illuminating and insightful, it's a stunning, surreal, extraordinary epic that will dazzle yet perhaps dumbfound art-house audiences.
Adventurous and action-packed, it splashes with spectacular fun for the entire family.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Amusing, whimsical, time-traveling cinematic celebration of the iconic City of Lights
There are many scenes in which absurdist fiction intersects with fact that it's depressing and disturbing, yet Gibson's anguished performance is not only believablebut insightful and compelling.
A tedious, two-hour crisis of conscience, presenting a myriad of choices - the best of which is to wait and see this on dvd, if at all.
Sparring culture clash, crammed full of familiar stereotypes
Formulaic action-packed martial-arts fantasy, chronicling a ferocious family feud.
Fun, adventurous, engrossing
A soul-searching chick flick that really clicks.
A screeching, testosterone-propelled fifth installment for this durable, high-octane franchise.
The interweaving of the two storylines is fumbling, fragmented and contrived - unless you're a devout Catholic and well-versed in Spanish history. Watching it was like doing penance.
A lame, time-wasting absolutely unnecessary sequel.
Swaggering and splashy, even though its predictably stereotypical banality prevents it from ever achieving full flight.
Kristin Wiig is sharp-yet-sweet in this shockingly scatological comedy, filled with bawdy, uninhibited babes.
Exhausting and ambiguous, it's for moviegoers who relish a quiet, arduous chronicle of bleak hardship, seemingly portrayed in real time.
It's an inspiring, uplifting - if sentimental - docudrama, pulling the heartstrings with the best of intentions.
Writer/director J.J. Anrams' nifty, nostalgic homage to the innocence and wonder epitomized by his mentor/producer Steven Spielberg.
Idyllic, inspirational, uplifting film
Rabble-rousing agitprop, asserting the consumer's right to have access to healthful food, whether it comes from the farm stand or the supermarket.
Truly stupid - except for very young kids. Wait for the dvd.
Extraordinarily evolved documentary, proving it's ethically and emotionally devastating to monkey with nature.
Outrageously crude, silly farce that works because of the cast's comedic timing.
Simplistic, contrived, neo-noir psychological thriller
Frothy, corny, adolescent wish-fulfillment fantasy
Inventive and enriching, affirming that a disarmingly personal, empathetic remembrance has universal appeal.
Pairing Tom Hanks with Julia Roberts gives rise to great expectations - which are dashed in this schmaltzy, mediocre romantic comedy.
Deafening and exhausting, yet in this kind of shock-and-awe senory spectacle, the toys always emerge triumphant.
A poignant, insightful documentary, illuminating a specific segment of our cultural heritage.
movie_title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Timely & compassionate father/son drama, it illuminates the contemporary immigrant experience, as Demien Bichir delivers a powerhouse performance.
Foul - and not even funny.

A sensory-overloaded sequel that revs to a confusing, high-octane frenzy, never forging any emotional connection with the audience. BUT the accompanying short, 'Toy Story Hawaiian Vacation' is delightful. Keep the short - can the feature.
Alarming and insightful, offering a rare glimpse into insects in crisis.
movie_title: Queen Of The Sun: What are the Bees Telling Us? (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Leisurely, yet competitive, culinary tour de farce
Blandly flimsy, formulaic, forgettable comedy.
As a superhero origin story, it's a major disappointment, including the surprising revelation during the final credits.
A nostalgic glimpse into tangled destinies.
Tediously slapstick, trying even to the most juvenile audiences - wait for the DVD
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Illustrating the dangers of anthropomorphizing wild animals, it shows the perils of adopting, separating and letting go - for both parent and pet.
Skimming the surface and romanticizing the reckless derring-do, it's infuriatingly ambiguous, just missing the mark.
This fascinating, astute 'Rashomon'-like tale is tantalizing, provocative and enthralling, never quite delineating the truth.
The essential ingredient in movies is timing, so the return of Gordon Gekko in this compelling, if cynical sequel couldn't be more welcome.
Savage and scary with excessive violence, it's nevertheless got awesome animation and the 3-D adds more than just another dimension, immersing the audience in the fantasy world.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Spicy and heart-warming, sprinkled with Creole zing and dashes of Dixieland, gospel and zydeco.
No other picture captures contemporary angst like this timely, turbulent tale. Without doubt, it's one of the best pictures of the year.
Poignant, if occasionally schmaltzy - it's a very touching family story, full of humor, heart and wisdom.
Spectacular is the most appropriate word to describe this epic historical adventure - it's visually impeccable and impressive.
An excessively gory, gruesome chopsocky thriller. A bloody bore.
Like rancid leftovers, this bland, contrived comedy is a toxic turkey, a buddy/family film gone wrong.
Haunting, ominous and evocative, it's a cautionary, cryptic allegory about the indominable hope for survival, even in the face of unfathomable horror.
It may be low-key and shallow, but middle-aged angst has never looked lovelier.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A spirited coming-of-age story, highlighted by Christian McKay's astounding physical resemblance to Welles and his perceptive, spellbinding impersonation.
With the unwavering assurance of a seasoned veteran at the top of his form, visionary director Clint Eastwood scores again with this brilliant, powerful, compelling underdog story.
So trivial and unimaginative that, unless you're desperate for sci-fi diversion for the kids, you should wait for the dvd.
Insightful, inspiring and football-themed - what could be timelier for Thanksgiving?
Poignant and insightful.
Sly and smartly paced adaptation, perhaps appealing even more to an older audience than a younger one.
Formulaic and frenzied, it's a spectacular but ultimately silly blast, drawing on every cataclysmic disaster movie you've ever seen for its Noah's Ark flood concept.
Fanciful and free-sprited, it cleverly captures the essence of the Age of Aquarius.
Street-smart and shocking, it's memorable primaily for the brazen, devastating performances.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Never has Richard Matheson's visionary work been so badly served! This is foolish, maudlin, confusing, pretentious poppycock.
Utilizing performance-capture technology, it's intricate and ingenious, offering a 3-D fantasy/adventure thrill ride, soaring into the holiday season.
Surreal and absurdly satirical, claiming, 'More of this is true than you'd care to believe.'
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Shallow, vapid and cheesy, proving that melancholy eternity themes can sometimes be drenched in tedium - except for ferocious Twi-hards.
Stylish, satirical and intriguing, surreptitiously exploring themes of ambition, jealousy and betrayal - and Penelope Cruz dazzles.

Not since Dorothy's Kansas farmhouse landed in Oz - 70 years ago - and the screen transformed from black-and-white to color - has there been such a magical, revelatory moment as the emergence of the planet Pandora in IMAX 3-D.
A striking, surreal, melancholy meditation, based on Alice Seabold's best-seller.

Be very wary of a movie poster that features a winsome blonde biting her pinkie. That's the primary lesson learned from this wretched rom-com in which cutsey nail-nibbling is supposed to be seductive.
After a solid, sensitive first-half, it disintegrates into standard-order, often senseless and inconsistent action, centering on maniacal Mad Mel.
Flimsy and forced, so keep flossing and wait for the dvd.
Formulaic TV-disease-of-the-week fare except in its revelations about how medical research is conducted and financed.
Tedious and tiresome, it's not surprising that the gag reel over the concluding credits is funnier than the 90 minutes that preceded it.
Drab and solemn, it's yet another post-apocalyptic drama, delivering bloodshed that's punctuated by poetic psalms.
While it captures the Southern Gothic atmosphere, it's sketchy and studied, best geared to Tennessee Williams aficionados.
movie_title: The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Surrounded by cannibalistic gore, Ethan Hawke and Willem Dafoe line up to drink some valuable box-office blood...call it 'From Here to Vampurity'.
Self-conscious and flawed, it's a bleak, pedestrian melodrama insearch of a dramatic fulcrum.
If you're in the mood for a delightful, middle-aged romantic comedy, this is your ticket. It's a glossy holiday confection that's chock full of laughter.
Giving one of the best performances of his career, veteran actor Hal Holbrook gracefully epitomizes the cantankerous curmudgeon in this richly complex human drama.
Fractious, family-friendly and funky, it's nevertheless cutsey charmless. Expect an inevitable Threequel.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This 21st century re-imagining of Scotland Yard's supersleuth is less Arthur Conan Doyle and more Guy Ritchie. It's elementary that some "game's afoot."
Bland, charmless and witless - trust me, you don't want to hear about the Morgans.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Dazzling and sumptuous, chronicling a haunting race to redemption.
Self-reflective and surreal, it's dazzling yet uneven, as the sumptuous whole adds up to less than a sum of its parts.
Coping with the consequences of celebrity is the premise of this intriguing art-house melodrama that brings Russian history to life.
Jeff Bridges' performance elevates this morality-tale concept to a level that makes him a viable, but not surprising, Oscar contender.
Although it's somewhat lacking in tumultuous, bodice-ripping intrigue, it's an elegant, entertaining, genteel biopic.
Sleek, sensitive and soulful, saved from Ford's overtly stylistic, sophisticated elegance by Firth's sly, subtly engaging portrayal.
Intense and enigmatic, it raises provocative issues abut rigid discipline and the abuse of power.
Bleak and tedious, it's an ambivalent memoir about Biblical adversity, filled with edgy, alienating angst.
A touching tribute, an extraordinary pop culture phenomenon and a unique artistic memorial that gives devoted fans one final glimps of the "King of Pop."
Shallow and superficial, it's far better suited to the Biography channel than the big-screen.
Sinister, scary, imaginative and original - despite a thin, one-dimensional storyline.
Irritating and inexcusable, it's a total waste of time and talent.
The novelty for this supernatural screamfest is the 3-D, making the concept of impalement, for example, seem to thrust directly into the audience.
Considering the waste of time, comedic talent and film-financing, it flunks.
Much of our enjoyment of a movie is based on expectations - and this title is misleading. It's actually a low-key, lightweight, occasionally amusing yet shallow story.
Amusingly bittersweet, screwball comedy, evoking the sexist ambiance of TV's "Mad Men."
Sensitively exploring a bittersweet relationship that's unusual and uncertain, demanding compromises and courage
Exciting, if uneven, exhilarating in the theme of Jewish empowerment and righteous revenge.
Robert Rodriguez's best family film since 'Spy Kids,' it's aimed at a small-fry audience.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Because this is an "authorized" (a.k.a. flattering) behind-the-scenes glimpse of "Vogue," it's glossy eye-candy but we never truly know what makes Anna Wintour tick.
Some books translate well to the screen. Others don't. This creepy, convoluted, frustrating chick-flick falls into the latter category.
Edgy, provocative sci-fi thriller that serves as a pop allegory for the racial tension of apartheid.
An epicurean delight!
An earnest, banal, not-quite-satire of New Age wisdom that evolves into a psychobabbling romantic drama.
Iyt's a cheesy kids-to-the-rescue adventure that should soar in popularity when it's released on DVD.
After a promising premise, it soon disintegrates into a preposterous predator/prey tale filled with brutality, bloodshed and butchery.
Intermittently engaging yet problematic, undoubtedly confounding the expectations of the usual Apatow/Sandler audience.
While the cynical concept is amusing, the actors' accents are often so undecipherable that much of the dialogue emerges as unintelligible unless you're attuned to Brit-speak - and profanity reigns.
Schlocky but scary with a weird plot twist that may leave you stunned.
Flashy - with a high-octane frenetic - aimed at a small-fry audience.
Visually stunning, it's a fantastical, enchanting charmer that's bound to delight children and adults alike.
Ice-schlocky - an idiotic wipeout.
It's a raunchy social commentary that will undoubtedly do even better when it's released on video, thereby repeating the pattern of 'Office Space.'
Erotic and haunting, filled with fateful concepts and indelible imagery.
There are some movies that should not be re-made. This is one of them, as proven by this updated, cliche-filled version which fails to build up the necessary tension and truncates the mystery.
It's criminally contrived.
Subtly scary, supernatural fright flick
Floundering, only intermittently funny. Wait for the dvd.
An endearing, engaging, escapist story for all ages, earning a place of honor among family-friendly films.
Too sadistic, violent, and grossly offensive, there are some movies that never should have been made, even for art-house audiences.
I suspect this boorish, crude, often vulgar British comedy lost a great deal of its jolly credence whilst crossing the Atlantic.
Clever and engaging, the title serves as a double entendre about a transformative 'university of life' experience.
It's a very, very funny premise - for about 20 minutes.
It's pointless to expect too much from a smarmy, silly, slapstick/teen romance horror satire and, if that's your attitude, you won't be disappointed.
It's an effervescent, rough-and-tumble rivalry on wheels, celebrating friendship and camaraderie while artfully delineating the struggle within families to understand one another.
Elegant and incadescent, it revels in its innate intelligence.
Why do we go to the movies? To be entertained and informed. And Michael Moore shows an uncanny ability to be 'way ahead of the curve of public awareness.
An enthusiastic yet familiarly recycled reinvention, which is kind of a shame.
While this sci-fi thriller has an intriguing premise, it's synthetic and superficial in its execution.
Inspiring, enlightening and affirmative journey into the mysteries of shamanism and autism.
Despite a rich and complex, powerhouse performance by Michael Sheen, it's hard to sell a biopic when many movie-goers have little awareness of either the subject of British soccer history.
An amusing kidflick that entertains while serving up enlightening food-for-thought.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Does art imitate life or does life imitate art? When you use that title, you're asking for trouble.
Hide-and-sneaky absurdist comedy
A skewed psychological thriller revolving around the many forms of betrayal.
Bullet-riddled and forgettable, it's filled with bloody violence and an astonishingly high corpse count.
Sudsy and syrupy, too often crossing the thin, star-crossed line between sentimentality and schmaltzy.
Snarling and savage, yet ultimately silly. Where are those silver bullets when you need them?
More geared to celebrity-spotting than cinematic storytelling, it's fluffy and flimsy.
Tense, timely and enigmatic, it features Hollywood's most alluring female fighting machine.
Gingerly gentle and generic, it plays like a sweet sitcom, better suited to the small screen than the large.
This loud, disjointed concept is one of the summer's major disappointments.
Mind-bending and time-twisting, it's the most exciting thrill-ride of the summer.
Smoldering and suspenseful, it whets the appetite for the final installment of the 'Millenium' trilogy, set for release in October.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: After the opening scene, there's not a shred of originality in this frantic sci-fi sequel.
A film is only as good as its villain - which is why this succeeds so well - and be sure to stay for the amusing end credits.
There are long expository speeches, which the young, inexperienced actors recite by rote, and the entire concept is filled with incoherent inconsistency.
The volatile love triangle is amped-up and edgier. Expect a lot more bite!
It's a supernatural, spiritual, sentimental sob-story that doesn't quite work.
Reflective, insightful and exhilarating, the filmmakers reveal Rivers' inherent vulnerability and dependence on the approval of others.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A glibly intelligent yet unconventional feel-good film, it grapples with commitment issues inherent in long-term relationships.
Exotic, edgy espionage escapade, delivering an exhilarating if exhausting thrill ride.
Awful and intolerably tedious, everyone connected with this abomination should hang their heads in shame.
A loving, nostalgic, heartfelt treat for the kid in all of us, 'Toy Story' may be the most treasured animated trilogy of all time.
Serious, sensitive and stirring, it reveals a gritty, cruelly uncompromising world within the confines of our own country.
Mindless, testosterone-fueled mayhem, wasting no time on credibility, coherence or character development.
Engaging and emotionally edgy, families don't come more dysfunctional than this one.
While far too long, it's, nevertheless, wise, poignant and satisfying, delivering a timeless message across the generations and decades.
Insipid and lumbering - with a title character perpetually emitting noxious gas fumes.
Time marches on, along with these rowdy, raunchy celebrations of mediocrity.
This remake of a far-nastier French farce is a silly, screwball concept with a definitive 'Odd Couple' emphasis.
Fur flies in this frothy, innocuous, critter-filled romp - but it's certainly not worth the 3-D price bump.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Exaggerated yet elegant, opulent and sensual, it's a leisurely-paced European art-house melodrama that's made its way into the cineplex.
Because of the lacklustre rom-com script and flaccid direction - not to mention the terror on kids' faces with the snarling wolves slaughtering stampeding caribou - wait to howl with the DVD.
Sassy and sharp, it's a cleverly edgy twist on Nathaniel Hawthorne's classic morality fable.
No one knows Boston better than Ben Affleck, and there's lots of robbin' in the hood in this solid, suspense-filled thriller.
Flimsy melodrama, filled with clumsy, hand-held camerawork and turgid, pretentious literary prattle, signifying very little.
Gory, pointless, pretentious and tedious, ending in a splattering cliffhanger, so you can expect this survival horror series to continue if it resonates at the box-office.

Campy, slice-and-dice, testosterone-fueled homage to violent '70s exploitation pictures - and I don't have to be a betting woman to suggest that men will like this R-rated guilty pleasure much more than women.
Enthalling and action-packed, it's understandably Norway's most successful film so far.
It's a spare, somber, visually captivating study in stillness but not emotionally involving.
Self-conscious and filled with coarse vulgarity, as a romantic comedy, it's a disappointment.
Jimmy Buffett wrote a song called "Overkill" and that's the word which best describes this high-powered yet formulaic heist caper.
Not for the squeamish or faint-hearted, it's sicko scary, spewing gallons-upon-gallons of R-rated graphic bloody gore. Not surprisingly, a succulent sequel is in the works.
A slyly intriguing, powerful, upredictable fable, a uniquely American folktale.
Think "Billy Elliot" combined with "The Last Emperor" and a touch of "Rocky." Great movies transport the audience - and this left me enriched and exhilarated.
Quirky and implausible, it's a formulaic and utterly predictable romance.
Rarely do sequels equal or exceed expectations, but this comedy does. Irreverent yet sweetly sentimental, it's a delightful late summer diversion.
This subtle, performance-propelled romance is geared to adult art-house audiences.
Too bad this blast-from-the-past mucho macho male reunion movie is so absurdly incoherent.
Exotic, escapist and superficially spiritual, it's shallow, indulgent female wish-fulfillment, sailing off into the sunset.
Splashy and stylish, it's specifically geared for youthful, hyperactive viewers who are familiar with contemporary video game/comic book culture.
Funny, fresh and totally engaging, it's a nostalgic gem.
This is NOT the first 3-D movie musical, as advertised, and the blandness of Malambri and Vinson can't compare with the charisma of Fred & Ginger or Gene Kelly with a broomstick.
What's so disturbing about this contemporary Frankenstein story is that it might happen - if it hasn't already.
Intense yet atrocious wannabe thriller with ludicrous, laughable dialogue
This enigmatic dramedy is an actor's showcase, if there ever was one, representing a beacon of quality in a summer filled with popcorn pictures.
Charming, fanciful, lyrical, bittersweet, redemptive tale that lightens your heart with a delectable bit of Irish blarney.
Elegant, enthralling journey into self-discovery - with James Ivory continuing the richly refined, tantalizing, exotic Merchant/Ivory storytelling tradition.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Stale, insipid and silly...if you stay for the end-credit blooper outtakes, it becomes obvious from their banter that Fey and Carrell could have been far funnier if they'd improvised.
The downfall of 3-D is going to be quicky, crummy CGI conversions like this clunker.
Intense and indelibly gripping thriller
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Tediously slow and sordid, it's the seedy story of a woman scorned.
Shaggy, subversive, surreal time-travel adventure, evoking nostalgia in baby-boomers and grossed out, politically-incorrect, R-rated guffaws from others.
Fanciful family fun - with lots of heart.
Time-frittering, money-wasting trifle. Bail on this obnoxious odd couple.
Engrossing, amoral prison thriller and socio-political commentary.
Controversial and suspenseful, it evolves like a crime thriller as a collector's legally documented wishes are corrupted by the vulgarity of commerce.
A dumbed-down political thriller that interweaves fact with fiction, tempting cynical wags to dub it "Bourne in Iraq."
Romantic, angst-ridden melodrama, aimed specifically at Pattinson's young female fans.
Melding history and mythology with faith, it's an Irish treat.
Bleak, brutal, pretentious, over-agitated and only somwhat suspenseful.
Sleek and sophisticated, evoking memories of Hitchcock. It's an elegant remainder of what a great director Roman Polanski was - and is.
Visually fascinating yet perturbing and scary, it's not a very young children's movie, despite the PG rating.
Well, at least you can't accuse them of deceptive advertising: this grossed-out action comedy is, indeed, a cop out - in every sense of the word.
A spooky, suspenseful, scary gorefest - but you expect that, don't you?
Disturbingly, deliberately deceptive, it's layered with labyrinthine medical, legal, historical and political issues.
An imaginative, if simplistic, visit to classical Greek mythology, an archetypal quest by a lad with paternal issues.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Sweetly amiable yet hackneyed, filled with contrived coincidence and cliche-laden bickering.
Slick, savvy, ultra-violent send-up, offering a brazen, aptly-named counter-culture diversion.
The hollow humor is coarsely sexual, crudely scatological slapstick. Do yourself a favor: rent the droll original directed by Frank Oz.
Visually stunning, intriguing and inspirational.
This wild, unrestrained roller coaster ride of vulgar, demented debauchery is - so far, as of early June - the funniest movie of the year.
Contrived soap-opera, delineating yet another dysfunctional family - and woefully underutilizing its interesting locale.
An innocuous, if frenetic, old-fashioned B-movie that seems destined for a satisfying afterlife on dvd.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An intriguing, captivating glimpse into the creative process.
movie_title: Picasso and Braque Go to the Movies (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Overly long, superficial and shallow. Their closets have been updated but not their sensitivity.
Stretching a one-minute SNL spoof into 90 minutes is bad enough but gearing this raunchy, R-rated mockery to 14 year-olds won't pay off until it hits homevideo.
A lush, lavish Bollywood-meets-Hollywood fantasy, available for viewing in both a shorter and longer version, courtesy of Brett Ratner.
Fanciful and, hopefully, franchise-concluding, it should have a long and prosperous life on dvd.
Humorously spritual journey which should lead to an interesting discussion after the closing credits.
A caustic, surreal character study about what it means to be a parent, folded into a low-budget, naturalistic, urban documentary with jittery camera-work.
Queen Latifah's talents are wasted in this bland Cinderella story set against a professional sports backdrop.

Why do I love thee, Juliet? Let me count the ways: there are no decapitations, no car crashes, no gun fights, no pratfalls, no talking animals and no aliens - just one beautiful love story, two captivating romances and lots of picturesque Italian scenery.
A joyless, character-driven, medieval history lesson with an inordinate amount of realistic, graphic violence.
British writer/director Marc Forby drains the inherent drama out of this true story, rendering it a one-dimensional period piece, suitable for the History Channel.
This observant, if simplistic, documentary makes pop human anthropology delightfully unpredictable, engaging and photogenic.
It's a good - but not great - action-packed popcorn picture.
Never has the lure of the recognizable been more obvious than in this familiar yet forgettable reboot of Wes Craven's 1980s horror franchise.
Engrossing and often surprising but I'm still bewildered why it triumphed over better foreign films at the Academy Awards.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's fortunate that Jennifer Lopez has her own back-up plan as a pop singer because her taste in romantic comedies reeks of formulaic and stale.
It's a brilliant premise but wretchedly executed, as product placement becomes more important than the sly inherent satire of consumer conformity.
Aptly named, flamboyant and frustrating, it's silly, hollow, mindless mayhem adhering to the proposition that anything worth doing is worth over-doing, including setting up for a sequel.
Occasionally, a production company is so acutely aware that it's stuck with a dud that they refuse to schedule press screenings, hoping the public will blindly buy tickets. This is just such a loser.
Fine-feathered, somewhat funny - yet it's a quirky, outdoorsy expedition that fails to take comedic flight.
Sweet 'n' salty, it's a happy hookup, despite the all-too-familiar plot.
A speculative premise that revives the American folk hero.
Sleek and stylish yet silly and far-fetched, it dissolves into a cinematic depressant.
Serviceable sci-fi - stopping momentarily at local theaters en route to its destiny on DVD as generic, escapist diversion for youngsters, teaching teamwork and preaching family loyalty and love.
Sudsy and spooky, aimed at lusty adolescents searching for the next romantic fantasy now that the 'Twilight' saga has concluded.
A good day - it isn't. To quote John McClane: "Something stinks."
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This simulated, caricatured curiosity is another Lincoln log that's recommended primarily for history-buffs.
Sappy and tear-stained, it's filled with the sentimental schmaltz that characterizes the appeal of this kind of chick-flick.
Vulgar and tawdry, it turns a cyber-crime into cinematic chaos.
A sensitive coming-of-age story, notable primarily because of Elle Fanning's incandescent performance.
Wobbly and contrived: given that cast, it could have and should have been so much better.
Serious and suspenseful, as Dwayne Johnson uses brains, not brawn to protect his son.
Derivative and only occasionally funny, it's already on the fast-track to the DVD shelf.
Underdeveloped, uneven, low-budget B-movie, a muddled crime-thriller that's not worth the price of admission.
Dismal and witless, the worst picture I've seen in many, many years. Even if you wait for the DVD - and get it free - it's a waste of time.
Preposterous and blood-splattering - not even with the price of admission, let alone the added 3-D surcharge.
A mundane melodrama, filled with caricatures instead of characters.
Endearing and astutely engaging, this deliciously tart comedy is, essentially, a British film that revives the old Mickey Rooney/Judy Garland 'let's put on a show' formula with great panache.
Arnold's back in a shoot'-em-up that celebrates America's second Constitutional Ammendment's right to bear arms.
Spooky, supernatural and grotesquely stylish - with a silly, contrived conclusion.
Continuing Michael Apted's insightful commentary on how life can be full of surprises.
Subtly intriguing and ambiguous, it's filled with suspicion and subterfuge.
This strangely sentimental twist on the classic 'Romeo and Juliet' tale becomes a charming, paranormal romantic comedy about fantastical, forbidden love.
Garish and bullet-riddled, it's a completely forgettable flick.
Neil Barsky's contentious documentary turns into a celebratory eulogy for the outspoken, opportunistic octogenarian.
Filled with tortured, manipulative shock scares, it teasingly provides a setup for yet another supernatural sequel en route to the DVD roster.
Trippy, intriguing, and enigmatic - it's a surreal, clever, ambiguous brain-teaser that will keep you thinking long after the lights go up.
Somber and suspenseful, if self-indulgent, identity story about fathers and sins.
An inspiring reminder that we need real-world heroes to expand the limits of our own aspirations.
Engaging, endearing adventure, tracing its heart-warming antecedents to Mark Twain's "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
It's bewildering how sci-fi aficionado Andrew Niccol ("Gattaca," "The Truman Show") could mastermind such a parasitic mess.
Astutely cast and directed conspiratorial crisis-of-conscience tale about facing the consequences of one's actions.
Fight-filled and blasting but forgettable - totally lacking the essential element of cartoonish fun.
Energetic slapstick, aimed at indiscriminating youngsters who will want to buy lots of Crood toys.
This lame comedy lacks anything resembling amusement and magic - until the final credits which involve a sight gag.
Family-friendly, yet derivative and too scary for young children.
Think of this solidly tense and suspenseful action-thriller as 'Die Hard in the White House.'
Singin', swingin' and sparkly, it's a sentimental, feel-good crowd-pleaser.
Voyeuristic, visually exploitive, hyper-sexualized cinematic commentary about the superficial emptiness of our youth-driven pop culture.
Intense yet shallow - with a final, vengeful twist that utterly disconnects.
Inexcusably tedious, resulting in yawning boredom
A prequel and homage to the tone and feel of the 1939 original film, it's a spirited, new, family-friendly adventure that's filled with wonder - despite miscast James Franco.
Stunning, admirable and indelible - truthfully chronicling the triumph of the human spirit - in a class with Michael Haneke's 'The White Ribbon.'
Unprecedented and deeply unsettling, it offers little hope for a lasting peace in that war-torn region.
This 'junior' version of the bacchanal in 'The Hangover' is a raunchy, misogynistic re-tred that's tawdry yet tame.
Dire and unsettling, it's ultimately disappointing.
Tina Fey and Paul Rudd rise above the inconsistent, elitist, borderline obnoxious material, as does irrepressible Lily Tomlin.
Cynical and savvy, it's a small film with a big message about the ends justifying the means.
While providing a fantastically visual diversion for aspiring skateboarders, this documentary lacks any personal insight into or commentary about legendary Danny Way.
Tiresome and relentlessly feverish, it never captures the spontaneous exuberance or rhapsodic wanderlust of the Beat Generation.
Epic and intriguing, it's a cautionary tale that emerges as one of the best foreign films of the year.
Compelling and emotional, exploring many facets of self-identity.
Inventively wired, it's a video-game adventure that explores visually dazzling, distinctively retro worlds.
Highly stylized kung-fu spoof, filled with blood-spurting and limb-hacking
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Intense and serious, it redefines 'flying high.'
Incomprehensible, ridiculously humorless horror fantasy.
Bland and uninspiring, it narrowly avoids a wipeout.
Thrilling and terrific, one of the best Bonds ever!
Gorgeous and glorious, this unconventional, epic fantasy is a visceral and visual feast.
An adult film that approaches the serious subject of sex with refreshingly explicit honesty.
A standard, heavy-weight drama about the self-destructive effects of alcohol abuse, reminiscent but never as good as 'The Days of Wine and Roses.'
Stale and derivative...
Tacky and tawdry, it's scummy, sexploitation sleaze.
Saucy, snarky and spirited...
It's an ominous beginning to a fright-filled fortnight.
Earnest and eclectic, the innate compassion of Stephen Chbosky's young adult novel elevates it above other coming-of-age dramas.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Undeniably strange yet sassy, it spreads subversive, thinly-sliced Americana.
Politically-charged suspense that's strategically laced with humor, it's compelling, intense, exceptionally intelligent entertainment.
Generic and mind-numbing, it leaves the door open for another, perhaps inevitable installment.
Intellectual, overwrought and highly stylized, it's a superficial spectacle, providing a feast for the eyes but starvation for the soul.
Floundering attempt by Tyler Perry to fill Morgan Freeman's trench coat
Syrupy, suspensful and surreal, proclaiming this final segment as the best of the 'Twilight' saga is damning with faint praise.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Superlative and spellbinding, this surprisingly relevant observation on the essence of leadership is, undoubtedly, one of the best pictures of the year.
Astounding and awesome, it's not only one of the best of the year but also must be seen in 3-D on as big a screen as possible.
Unsatisfying psychological study of a neglectful mother, failing in its quest for spiritual redemption.
Frigid and frightful, it becomes increasingly inconsistent, incoherent and, therefore, unbelievable.
Surreal and inscrutable, it's visually compelling avante-garde cinema that may leave you wondering, 'What was that about?'
Indulgent and excessive, it's Tarantino at his bloody best.
Billy Crystal delivers nostalgic, heartwarming fun for young children, parents and grandparents.
Intimate, admirable and elegant, it's, nevertheless, demanding, deliberate and depressing - about facing our own mortality.
Exciting, escapist entertainment
Mildly funny - with the biggest laughs coming from improvisational banter in the 'outtakes' during the final credits.
Foul-mouthed and forced, it seems that Lifestyles of the Rich, Ribald and Rowdy has morphed into Lifestyles of the Selfish, Spoiled and Stressed.
Sensitive and sympathetic, appealing primarily to environmental activists.
Anguished, unrestrained, relentlessly amplified, it's a uniquely overwhelming, even exhausting extravaganza.
Viscerally vigorous, it's a grim, gritty, graphic chronicle of disaster.
Grandiose and visually spectacular, although the visual effects overwhelm the narrative.
The dysfunctional silbling-squabbling delivers diluted holiday cheer.
More than the Thanksgiving goose gets cooked in this less-than-thrilling crime caper.
These mature actors never strike a dissonant note.
More bullets-and-bloodshed that's stylish, cynical - and unappealing.
Family-friendly fare that's so frenetic that it gets exhausting.
Wobbly and foundering or, as one young commando observes, 'We're living 'Call of Duty' - and it sucks!'
Expect well-deserved Oscar nominations for both Anthony Hopkins and Helen Mirren.
Unlikely and engaging, this quirky, off-beat romantic dramedy is a cheerfully enjoyable crowd-pleaser.
The filmmakers border on sophomoric desperation, achieving a measurable shred of humor only in the outtakes during the closing credits.
Fun-filled and spooky - a weirdly wonderful animated comedy.
Sick, stomach-churning, satirical sci-fi - and the many distastefully visceral syringe scenes are not for the squeamish.
Sweet-natured and high-spirited, it's a fanciful fable with a wee dash of magical realism.
Tiresome wannabe thriller, incoherently spinning its wheels for 97 minutes with sheer stupidity.
Subdued yet suspenseful, a timely conspiracy thriller.
Choppy and chilling, it's destined for a quick burial in the icy tundra.
A glossy, promotional concept that's overly enhanced by unnecessary amplification.
A mediocre, late-summer slasher, filled with pointless carnage.
Compelling - it's an insider's poignant view of the harrowing tragedy.
movie_title: Out of the Clear Blue Sky (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Strikes a bittersweet note of unaffected authenticity...
Somber, stylized and visually stunning
Degenerate, depraved psycho-sexual drama revolving around a pathetic thrill-seeker who travels with intent to visit places of tragedy or disaster.
Amiable, yet flimsy - too bad it's not a saucier, snarkier satire.
Flimsy - weighted down with an air of familiarity
So dumbed-down that it's totally lacking in suspense and common sense.
Flimsy and floundering, one of the stupidest sequels ever.
For Edgar Wright/Simon Pegg/Nick Frost fans, I suppose this silly, stylized, slapstick British romp is a ridiculously amusing, apocalyptic riff.
Acclaimed at film festivals - this is a sensitive, poignant and distressing drama about troubled adolescents.
Profoundly disturbing depiction of the grim realities and the oppression women endure under the Taliban regime - yet enthralling because of Golshifteh Farahani's performance.
Ambitious and affecting, it's a challenging, haunting, historical epic, hoping to follow the success of the similar, late-summer 2011 release 'The Help.'
Distasteful & mediocre, concluding with obligatory outtakes that are funnier than the film itself.
Without urgency or peril, it's flimsy, fantastical fun aimed at pre-teens familiar with pop-culture Greek mythology.
Unsettling and insightful, it's Woody Allen's 48th film - and one of his best.
Superficial and unsatisfying...
Bang! Bang! Boring.
Viscerally ferocious, delivering brawny, low-octane Diesel.
Savvy, screwball, feminist comedy gem.
Creaking and chugging with testosterone-laden, tough-guy violence, they're lumbering lunkheads.
Trivial and tedious...enough already!
Savage, uncompromising and gruesomely cringe-inducing, this true tale will shock you and anger you, but it may also touch you very deeply.
Robert Redford will get a Best Actor Oscar nomination for this awesome, extraordinary adventure on an unforgiving sea.
Chaotic and speculative, it haphazardly reveals the state of 21st century internet journalism which, seemingly, lacks any semblance of accountability.
A tense, relentless, edge-of-your seat action thriller, anchored by Tom Hanks' authentic, subtly nuanced Everyman performance.
Pretentious and unproductive, it's a stylized postscript revealing no new insights or relevant information, nothing that historians and conspiracy theorists have not already rehashed.
This dicey melodrama stacks the deck, meaning that buying a ticket is a gamble that doesn't pay off. Rent 'Rounders' instead.
This strangely dark comedy is a wistful, joyless, forgettable interlude.
Facetious and amusingly amoral, it lacks cohesion and consistency - and the carnage is far from comedic.
Not since Stanley Kubrick's '2001: A Space Odyssey' has there been a sci-fi fantasy as thrilling and intensely gripping as this. Wonderfully innovative, it's an awesome spectacle not to be missed.
Silly, imaginative and noisy - it's a tasty second helping that's filled with family-friendly fun.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: From 'Pillow Talk' to pornography in three generations! Sleazy yet seductive, Joseph Gordon-Levitt cleverly distinguishes the different between lust and love.
Filled with fancy, if frenetic footwork but weighed down by all-too-familiar plot/characters/dialogue.
Predictably unsatisfying and so banal that it's a total turnoff.
Fatuous and infuriating, it's a shallow, superficial examination of a multi-layered, enigmatic author.
Dull and formulaic, it's yet another wannabe post-apocalyptic thriller.
Tedious and repetitive, it concludes with yet another creepy cliffhanger.
Unflinching and intense, it's an intricate thriller evoking complex emotional conflict, moral ambiguity and sustained psychological suspense.
Exciting, exhilarating and enthralling, even for those who are not into automobile racing.
An insightful, wryly amusing social commentary about compatibility and contemporary suburban anxiety.
Energetic, if sociologically simplistic - another violent, post-apocalyptic, sci-fi spectacle.
Elevated above the ordinary comic-book adaptation by the charismatic ferocity of buffed-up Hugh Jackman.
Sly and savvy, it's a classy, globe-trotting action comedy for baby-boomers.
Nepotism has always been part of the Hollywood firmament, but it's sunk to a new low with Will Smith's vanity vehicle for his 14 year-old son Jaden.
An intriguing escapade, revolving around a magician's deliberate misdirection, as in 'The more you look, the less you see.'
Sweet, eye-popping, eco-friendly adventure, suitable for children of all ages.
It's not a caper, not a comedy...instead, it's a tepid rehash of gross, stale material that's no longer amusing.
Improbable yet engaging, this arrested development serio-comedy should be particularly endearing to those who can't quite get their lives together.
Astonishing adventure - filmed simultaneously in Norwegian and in English.
High-octane, outrageous and action-packed, introducing a long, low-slung ramp car designed to get underneath other vehicles and flip them over, causing massive vehicular carnage.
Sordid story glorifying an intensely ferocious, unrepentant, despicable man.
Adrenaline-fueled and highly entertaining, filled with feverish, fast-paced excitement and suspense. Live long and prosper!
Creepy, perverted, disgusting fright flick filled with horrific imagery.
Formulaically funny, utterly familiar, fish-out-of-water story with a few absurdly engaging comedic touches.
Straitlaced and sermonizing, this is a sluggish cautionary tale about deviating from righteous church teachings.
Stressed, struggling farmers explore the moral and social consequences of corruption and the high-stakes economic pressures in the contemporary business world.
Sumptuous, exquisitely gaudy spectacle, emphasizing style over substance and filled with extrvagant parties to which we wish we'd been invited.
Seriously rich in suspenseful, subversive complexities about the roots of extremism - that should appeal to international audiences.
Sensual, sophisticated and visually sumptuous, particularly appealing to an older audience of art lovers.
Exciting and hugely entertaining, it's an eye-popping spectacle with suprisingly clever, whimsical dialogue and wisecracking one-liners.
In this quirky, chaotic, dunderhead comedy caper, too much pain is inflicted for very little gain.
What was once an amusing French farce has become a crass, crude, mean-spirited, smarmy mess.
Only charismatic Tom Cruise could elevate this derivative, exposition-heavy sci-fi into a compelling adventure.
Stunning fashion documentary, joining the ranks of 'Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has to Travel,' 'Valentino: The Last Emperor,' 'The Tents,' 'The September Issue,' etc.
Interesting, if improbable idea: execrable execution
The line between a legitimate feature film and a product placement-filled infomercial grows thinner than ever with this underdog comedy.
Refreshingly touching and genuinely funny coming-of-age story, cleverly capturing a poignant, formative interlude.
A horror thriller that's silly yet scary enough to give you second thoughts if anyone suggests playing Hide 'n' Clap.
It's a sweet, endearing 'Fast and Furious' animated comedy, a fun-filled adventure for adrenaline junkies of all ages.
Facile, fast-paced film-turned-video game...with a weak story and rather uninteresting heroes.
Compelling and exasperating...
It's 'Pirates of the Caribbean' in the Old West. Any resemblance between the old-time radio/TV Western and this theme-park-ride-ready-to-happen is exactly what Disney had in mind.
It's a bittersweet, heartwarming delight!
This sweet 'n' sticky sequel is stolen by the mischievous Minions.
There's humor and heart in this implausible but action-packed, escapist adventure.
Snarky and scruffy, it's filled with cliche'd, odd couple bantering and punctuated with raunchy, profane dialogue.
Stirring and sophisticated, it's filled with insightful, engaging observations, like "The shot is the bartender's handshake."
Uplifting and intriguing, appealing to fans of R & B and classic rock 'n' roll.
Neil Jordan's curiously revisionist addition to the cult of the undead category.
Stunning, if simplistic sequel - an amusing comedy that emphasizes teamwork and the value of friendship.
If it weren't propelled by Brad Pitt's star power, this would be just another apocalyptic, sci-fi zombie thriller with some massive, starkly memorable special effects.
Awesome, authentic examination of a constantly evolving romantic relationship, it's a definite 'must see' for adult audiences.
Combining fantasy with reality, making familiar things new and new things familiar - it's the most exhilarating comic book movie of the summer.
Subversive, self-deprecating and sexist, it's a horror zonk-fest designed to blow a guy's mind.
Slasher films have gotten more grisly, grimy and gruesome - but few earn the three R's: repulsive, repugnant and rank. Elijah Wood has left Frodo far behind.
Enjoyably amusing adaptation of William Shakespeare's screwball comedy, but Britain's Royal Shakespeare Company doesn't have to worry.
Shallow yet scary, superficially documenting a banal youth culture of self-surveillance.
Shrewd and suspenseful, this is a low-tech, cerebral thriller that raises your social consciousness while oozing a pervasive sense of conspiracy and danger.
Enlightening documentary that, hopefully, propels people to take action.

Brushing aside the calculations of the story with sheer believability and the unwavering force of his sardonic humanity, Bill Murray delivers one of the most astonishing, rewarding performances of the year.
A wistful, bittersweet remembrance of the emerging '60s counterculture.
Fitfully funny, it's a stale, sloppy fright-fest that's destined to take a quick detour to the DVD shelf, where it will inevitably stake its claim.
Slick sci-fi, appealing to its adolescent audience with the question: 'What would you do if you had super powers?'
Sinister and somewhat spooky, bearing the stylish Hammer Films imprint.
Family-friendly, fee-good, inspirational story - and watch the closing credits for a glimpse of young Sarah Palin as an Anchorage sportscaster.
Visually stunning, it's an epic saga of survival and redemption.
Inspiring, if insipid, skimming the surface as a trail-blazing tale about the courageous Tuskegee airmen.
Ambiguous and enigmatic, it revolves around the termination of a marriage in contemporary Tehran.
Contrived, cliche-riddled and far-fetched, twisting the fugitive-on-the-run forumula.
An intense, survivalist gore-fest.
Fierce and ferocious, filled with relentless, kinetic, if senseless, violent mayhem.
Exciting if elusive - appealing to dance enthusiasts
Adoring, feel-good, sweet documentary about Kevin Clash, best known as Elmo's hand, voice and soul.
Like its warrior anti-hero, it's sharp and stubborn and should appeal to admiring art-house audiences.
Familiar hallelujah gospels glued together by caricaturist Southernfried performances and an overwrought, formulaic story.
A grim, grisly, graphic, cross-cultural love story from a humanitarian activist.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This sleazy L.A. noir crime thriller is distinguished primarily by Woody Harrelson's 'rotten from the inside out' rogue character study.
It's a supernatural, satanic stunt - and, judging by its astonishing grosses, it won't be the last of its kind.
This incoherent, redundant, sci-fi thriller is a depraved, repugnant dirge with a disappointing conclusion.
Street-wise and sincere, it's destined to reassure troubled teens searching for their identity - and their parents.
Hopelessly bleak tragedy, as trumatic guilt gnaws on everyone's sensibilities.
Preachy yet persuasive, appealing to desperate, often outraged parents who are deeply concerned about the obvious failure of the American public school system.
Contrived, predictable and formulaic, the most compelling scenes are nautical, incolving freighter ships with claustrophobic interiors, dock workers and maritime law.
Ponderously sinister and savage, it's difficult to endure and primarily notable for Tilda Swinton's agonized performance.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Smashing, crashing and nonsensical, it reveals CIA corruption at its very core.
Harrowing and intense, it's Schindler in the sewers.
Uneven, subversively flamboyant, tediously tweaking the 'Once Upon a Time' concept
Absurdist chronicle of a cosmic incident in the drab life of a slacker/stoner
Emotionally restrained yet compassionate, coming-of-age morality tale
This tension-filled action-adventure delivers a pulse-pounding, pop culture message of female empowerment.
Racist, repetitive and ridiculous - unless you're a devoted fan of Spanish telenovas.
This lame, wannabe comedy is an unmitigated disaster.
Silly slapstick, spoofing the series by playing it for laughs.
Edgy and amusing, distinguished primarily for its timely, perceptive observations about the nature of friendship and the definition of family in the 21st century.
Elegant biopic about Aung San Suu Kyi, Burma's iconic freedom fighter, known as South Asia's 'steel orchid.'
Eerie, sinister and floundering, it careens to a brutally bizarre, preposterous conclusion that's definitely not for the squeamish.
Frightfully forced, since the cinematography gimmick dilutes, rather than enhances the premise.
Crude, repetitive and offensive, propelling the R-rated teen sex comedy cycle.
Commercially viable but not up to Dr. Seuss' standards, resulting in a Lorax-approved laundry detergent appearing in a grocery store near you.
Memorable mainly for its cheesy CGI fakery.
Seriously authentic yet fragmented, it's never clear whether it's recruitment propaganda or a ponderous, vaguely comprehensible documentary.
Silly fare with the bizarre humor evoking more giggles than guffaws.
Gently enchanting, an extraordinary adventure
With only occasionally awesome CGI, it's destined to thrive when it comes out on DVD.
Sweetly syrupy, filled with slick, heart-tugging, tear-jerking sentiment.
Celebrating the worldwide poker renaissance, it's intriguing in the way it delineates another way to chase the American Dream.
Surprisingly humorless, unevenly jumbled fantasy - Blame it on solar flares!
Flimsy if fashionable - a folly for Anglophiles.
Dim-witted apocalyptic disaster
Extraordinary and life-affirming, it packs a wrenching emotional wallop.
Fresh, funny and family-friendly,it's a cheerful crowd-pleaser.
Ultimately forgettable gods of gore
It's a downhill drag!
Slick, smart, timely and topical revenge riff - succeeding because it's more caper than comedy.
While the essence of J. Edgar remains ambivalent and inscrutable, Leonardo DiCaprio emerges as a definite Oscar contender.
You don't need a horoscope to know it's a bad sign when the quirky, jumbled, plodding plot is incredibly implausible.
Boozy and incoherent, appealing primarily to cultish devotees of Hunter S. Thompson - of whom there are obviously far fewer than anticipated.
Cheeky and underwhelming, quickly to be filed under 'forgettable films.'
Generic, formulaic fumble, misjudging its revelations and overestimating their impact.
A shocking, stunning, hyper-stylized interlude - designed to make you shudder.
A slickly stylized premise, adroitly rigging the economic currency, but the essential chemistry is lacking.
An opulent 16th century costume drama that serves as a far-fetched, alternative-history curiousity, continuing the mystery.
So hammy and campy that Alexander Dumas would scarcely recognize this latest incarnation of his swashbuckling tale.
Imaginative, inventive and visually eloquent, it's definitely one of the best films of 2011.
Uplifting and sensitive without being sentimental, the mystic destination is worth the arduous trip.
A staggering, monumental, meticulous achievement.
Spooky and scary - more unnerving and sinister this time 'round.
Relentlessly sinister, filled with an eerily ambiguous sense of unease.
Mystifying psychological drama, mixing the feeling of belonging with the sensation of still feeling lost.
Timely, topical and intriguing - with a release as fortuitous as 'The China Syndrome' was to Three Mile Island.
It's furry, frisky, family-friendly fun - and you don't have to pay extra for the 3-D because the 2-D version is just as good.
During the holiday season, it's joints to the world!
Imaginative and apocalyptic, it's perhaps more admirable than enjoyable.
Banal, bloodsipping installment to this far-fetched fantasy.
Affectionate and amusing, it's uplifting, feel-good family entertainment.
Entertaining if blatantly sexual and sado-masochistic, inducing thrills and chills.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Exhilarating, nerve-wracking, vertigo-inducing, action-packed popcorn picture, filled with spectacular feats of derring-do.
Striking, stirring and sentimental, joining Spielberg's "Saving Private Ryan" and "Schindler's List" in a universal plea for peace.
Meryl Streep delivers an insightful, intimate, incredibly accomplished cinematic portraiture of Margaret Thatcher.
Shrill, silly and furry - these squeaky-voiced, computer-generated rodents are back for their third formulaic frolic.
Steven Spielberg's terrific, fun-filled, state-of-the-art photorealistic 3-D motion-capture animation, laying groundwork for a sequel to be directed by Peter Jackson.
Subtle and sensitive, creating a fascinating, if far-fetched facade.
Solidly stylish, sassy adventure, positioning Downey and Law as the bromance of the year.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Disheartening and dysfunctional, it's distinguished primarily by its remarkable performances.
Crass, ludicrous and disappointing - and, despite its deceptively mainstream title, it's definitely not appropriate viewing for kids.
Cynical and sinister, it's a dreary, confusing, ambiguous, retro glimpse behind the Iron Curtain.
It's timely, festive, star-studded treacle.
It's a disturbing, exploitive, depressing dirge.
Michelle Williams' stunning, captivating performance provides impudent, entertaining observations about a screen icon.
Opulent, dazzling, enchanting screen adaptation of a beloved children's book. It's family-friendly fun.
This edgy, despairing depiction of four men's mid-life crises disintegrates into a soggy mess.
Ethereal, sometimes exasperating - an impulsive, impressionistic romance.
This brutally edgy, biting comedy is slick, simmering and scathing - with a suitably ironic conclusion.
Sweet and silly, this nostalgic reboot is fuzzy, family-friendly fare.
Low-key and curiously cerebral, perhaps too underwhelming to attract much of an audience
Eccentric and engaging - a whimsical treat.
Too tediously bland and banal, lacking the excitement and suspense that this kind of adventure should have.
With slow, deliberate pacing, seemingly endless amounts of paranormal prattle and few spooky scenes, it's quite tedious.
Amusing, ingenious and unexpected, revealing what may really be lurking in the darkness.
Spooky story about an adolescent medium's morbid "Sixth-Sense" encounters...perhaps it should be PG-10, not PG.
Tiresome and shallow, it's only 90 minutes in length but it somehow seems like forever.
Uniquely enchanting, wish-fulfillment fantasy fable
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This is such an obvious black-ops ploy to milk the cash cow...
Exhausting and repetitively reckless - better to watch it - free - on MTV or elsewhere.
Humorous, slyly sentimental romantic fable
Stupidly vulgar, mildly amusing, yet uneven "Saturday Night Live" skit that goes on too long.
Formulaic, family-friendy sequel, as Greg's angst takes a more adolescent turn.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A total waste of time...and best forgotten.
Action-packed and self-deprecating, the geriatric goons are back.
Heart-warming, irreverent and uplifting, it's a downright funny, feel-good romantic comedy/drama for adults.
Ill-conceived and incoherent...
Extravagant yet surprisingly compassionate, it's a unique chronicle of the collapse of the real estate market.
Flimsy and faltering, it's a fraudulent disappointment.
Adventurous and engaging, particularly for those who love Irish cinema
The frantic seventh installment in this highly successful comedy franchise is filled with throwaway gags and self-conscious scenes.
Tense, terrific - and triumphant - it's the best action-adventure of the summer!
Thrilling and transfixing, it's an evocative, contemporary allegory.
