Formulaic, frozen by predictability, alleviated only by a whimsically funny short featuring the Simpsons.
Sequined and sparkly, like Katy Perry, this documentary is aimed at her fanatic preteen fan base.
Fleet-footed yet formulaic and forgettable
Sudsy and spirited, it's Whitney Houston's unintentional cinematic swansong.
Vile, evil and brutal, it's a bloody mess that's only saved by Matthew McConaughey's impressively repellent acting.
A silly, race-against-time thriller, filled with impressive chase scenes and stunt work on a bike without brakes.
Exciting and engrossing futuristic thriller - with a solid payoff.
This slice of American Pie is flaky and flaccid.
Flimsy and fetishized, it delivers little more than a hackneyed skin flick.
Jennifer Lawrence and Elisabeth Shue are trapped in this banal, formulaic, low-budget horror thriller.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Audacious, insidious and serious, detailing how spiritual and religious systems can psycholgically seduce and subversively manipulate vulnerable minds.
Insightful and intense, emphasizing not only the importance of brotherhood and teamwork but also the cinematic chemistry between Gyllenhaal and Pena.
The father/daughter dependency duet forms a delicately balanced, richly satisfying relationship...but falls short of a home run.
Dreary,loud and uber-violent but, having grossed nearly $700 million worldwide, there's no stopping this franchise.
Savvy, slick and suspenseful financial thriller.
Underwhelming supernatural horror picture - somewhat creepy but easily forgettable.
As a romantic drama, it's a tiresome dud.
Fragile tale of how a lifelong friendship forged between two innocent girls is tested when they venture into a volatile, violent world.
Ghoulishly repetitive and gore-laden, it's a flimsy fright farce that eventually becomes the walking dud.
Suspenseful and sinister, making one wary of checking into a hospital.
Smutty, salacious female relationship comedy, appealing to the libidinous 'Sex and the City' and 'Bridesmaids' crowd.
Strange and intriguing, searching for that elusive essence known as 'the perfect truth.'
Cynical and futile - a total waste of time and money.
Uneven yet vividly stylish, filled with brutal bloodshed.
Abysmally dreadful! One of the worst miscalculations of the year.
Silly, sputtering, screeching some lowbrow, low-budget laughs before it runs out of gas.
Amusing and ingratiating, leaving a bittersweet afterglow
Flighty, fanciful and amusing - but quickly forgettable
Silly, sordid and sadistic - filled with gratuitously excessive grisly, graphic violence
Dreadful, dystopian dirge, filled with graphic, gory, gruesome violence - and little else.
A raunchy R-rated beefcake feast
Contrived and cliche-filled, culminating in a predictable conclusion.
Adventurous and exotic, Anglophiles should check in and check it out.
Enduringly escapist, it's a murderously funny fantasy.
Simpatico if shallow, struggling to be a life-affirming, feel-good fantasy.
In this dramedy, Kathleen Turner is sincerely sympathetic, as faith triumphs over religion.
Stylized, slightly surreal, perhaps overdosing with flimsy whimsy
A formulaic action/crime thriller that's all too familiar, forceful and ferocious.
Thrilling, collaborative action-adventure that's amusing and entertaining.
Ridiculous and tedious, this somber historical fantasy tries to transform Edgar Allen Poe into an American version of Sherlock Holmes.
Retro and formulaic, acting primarily as an informercial promotion for Steve Harvey's self-help book.
Poignant and savvy, it delves into the dilemma of what happens when a romantic commitment is challenged by career choices.
Timely and alarming, it's a relevant 'must see' for teenagers and their parents, perhaps opening a dialogue among family members.
Heart-warming and family-friendly, marred only by the banal, cloyingly cute narration which anthropomorphizes the primates.
Sappy and sentimental, melting like a gooey marshmallow melodrama.
Furiously forbidding, filled with a great deal of sinister action that makes little sense.
Frantic and foolishly funny
Emotionally eloquent, awakening awareness for environmental conservation.
Savory documentary, which is especially appetizing for foodies.
Soulful, surrealistic, making an angst-driven declaration about contemporary desolation.
Amusing, irreverent, outrageous - the weirdest, funniest movie I've seen in a long time
Swashbuckling, family-friendly frolic on the high seas, subtly referencing evolutionary science with an insidious spoonful-of-sugar.
A noisy, escapist, action-filled, cinema video game that's filmsy, formulaic and far too long.
Eloquent drama about contemporary issues like immigration, education, integration and the propriety of physical contact with students.
A feeble, floundering mom-com that gives short-shrift to the 'expectant' experience.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An awesome, new spin on the familiar fantasy, delivering emotional truth along with spectacular visual effects.
Simplistic and sentimental, it's an unexpectedly soapy sibling story.
Dumb and infantile, proving that even the most audacious, belligerent vulgarities get boring when you repeat them often enough.
Ridiculous and revisionist, redeemed only by Bekmambetov's inventive, R-rated action sequences, particularly the CGI horse stampede.
A formulaic, predictable romantic comedy with an apocalyptic twist.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A sweet, spirited action adventure introducing a spunky new teenage princess named Merida.
Noisy, insanely fun and shameless - embrace your inner rocker and party on!
Sweet and irresistibly subversive, showing why charismatic Omar Sy won France's prestigious Cesar as Best Actor over Jean Dujardin ("The Artist").
Strained yet saucy, barely skimming the surface of the subject of female sexuality.
Short and silly, it's frenetically paced and visually dazzling, filled with high-flying acrobatics.
Tense and thrilling, it's an awesome 3-D spectacle.
Agonizing, infuriating - and effective.
A fun-filled, feel-good journey...
Low-budget, softcore - destined to make a quick detour to DVD so sneaky, testosterone-propelled teens can easily subvert the R-rating.
Sleek and relentless, it's a provocative, darkly comedic thriller.
Dismally contrived - with formulaic plotting, shaky camerawork, cliched dialogue and repetitive scenes.
Authentic and uplifting, it's a feel-good, family movie.
Tender, melancholy and nostalgic, it's one of Wes Anderson's best fantasy films.
A weirdly wacky black comedy that's affectionately endearing.
Engrossing and entertaining, sizzling with comedy, suspense and intrigue.
Solemn and fervent,delivering an educational history lesson that defeats itself because of its R-rating.
Seriously sumptuous and savage, it idiosyncratically modernizes the alabaster-skinned, ruby-lipped feminist heroine.
Fun for both fans and newbies to the comic book world, the movie may be a lengthy 129 minutes but it doesn't feel like it.
This film doesn't just appeal to budding Vermeers but anyone who likes serious, intelligent drama and gentle erotic tension.
A fun, fascinating tribute to the glamour and giants of a golden era.
As a writer, I admire it greatly...As a moviegoer I'm less certain about the movie's effectiveness.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: What makes Call Be By Your Name stand out from the films it will be compared to is Guadagnino's play on juxtapositions, which go much deeper than merely an angsty teen with an introspective soul.
[Martin] McDonagh hasn't created a movie about murder. It's about about reclaiming a sense of justice when the world seems senseless and cold.
The Shape of Water is transportive.
It's probably the wrong time to release a movie where a victim of domestic violence is the one whom you're going to demonize.

Foxtrot is a smart film, worth the initial onslaught of grief for the puzzle of uncovering the film's hidden messages. God bless filmmakers who trust their audience to be smart enough to figure things out without explicit expository dialogue.
That's why, despite it's empowering theme song, diverse cast, and strong vocal lead in Hugh Jackman, it's impossible to separate The Greatest Showman from what we know of P.T. Barnum the man.

But despite the script's imperfections, Please Stand By is harmless, enjoyable film that loves the kind of characters that are often overlooked by Hollywood (those on the spectrums, those at the extremes of fandom).
To be fair, The Midwife probably isn't a masterpiece but it's satisfyingly thought-provoking.
The final fight scene in an underground Nazi wind tunnel is a work of absolute genius and not to be missed for any reason.
movie_title: Operation Condor (Fei ying gai wak) (Armour of God II) (1991)

movie_review_blurb: Lam brings a welcome kinetic energy to the chase scenes, and his action has that fast and furious quality unique to Hong Kong films.
A super-charged, bang-up action flick the likes of which most Americans still have never seen.
The performances are lovely, the odd characters engaging and the filmmaking interesting.
Despite poetic overtones, this film is a hack job--an overlit, underdirected, barely scripted longform music video celebrating violence and bastard amber gel.
The sharp-edged script by Patrick Sheane Duncan offers a challenging structure, ala Rashamon, to examine issues of courage and truth, but unfortunately the story is never fully realized.
The script is a mixed bag of elaborate and unnecessary pseudo-politics, intriguing ideas and mostly confusing rehashed romantic mishmash.
This feel-good family comedy with a twist is based on the 1978 French film La Cage aux Folles.

The script has interesting comments to make about the expectations people place on love, marriage and commitment, but it fails to follow through; its structure disintegrates just at the point when it should take off...
A clever tale told with a small cast of enormous talent.
Repetitive, slow and surprisingly messy.
It's embarrassing to see Lauren Holly wasting her time as the butt-of-all-the-obvious-jokes female aboard ship.
There are no surprises here except for the indecipherable motivations and exacting length of two hours and twenty minutes.

The great thing about the movie is that, although it's ludicrously predictable along the lines of every 'Die Hard on a [name your vehicle],' the filmmakers still manage to wring every scene for the most thrills possible.
It's just so pleasing that Murphy has cloaked his ego in an effective character and an engaging story this time.
Above Mission Impossible and Twister put together. But being better than two bloated, style-over-substance movies does not equal good.
